name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday 21 May 2015. Before I proceed to the approval of the Minutes, I wanted to inform the European citizens who are following the streaming sitting of the Parliament and the European citizens who are attending today's sitting from the gallery that not all Members are unfortunately present in the Chamber, due to a technical fault that has blocked all airports in Belgium, which we hope will be able to reopen at four this afternoon. It is right, in order to protect the image of Members, to inform the citizens who are following us.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The final draft agenda as set by the Conference of Presidents on Thursday, 21 May 2015 pursuant to Rule 149 of the Rules of Procedure has been distributed. I have not received any requests to change the agenda, so I note that the agenda has remained unchanged. (The order of business was thus established) *****

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I would like to draw your attention to the fact that, as we speak, there is an empty seat over there on my left, and we see that it belongs to one of the leaders of a political party from France, to Ms Marine Le Pen. I believe she is absent from this part-session not because of the trouble at Brussels airport, but because of her trip in Moscow.  According to various media reports, she is visiting Moscow to receive a regular credit line from Russian contacts and banks, and I believe she is there not just for money. She is in Moscow on instructions and we will hear about those instructions later in our session. I call on the French authorities to investigate this very dubious political campaigning and I call on Parliament to support my line.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I do not think that is on the agenda.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, I would like to point out to my colleague that Marine Le Pen is in Paris and that if he really wants to know about the relations we can have with the President of the Duma, the exchanges we have every year with President Naryshkin, that he knows that this is not about funding but about the politics and the relationships that we have in a way - which I have also had a very long personal history. , for twenty years - with this country. Colleagues, please stop telling anything, go and get your information from the gutter and stick to your job as a professional, an honest Member of Parliament.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, this is not on the agenda.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I will also add my voice and ask the Conference of Presidents to consider the possibility of declaring a conflict of interests to be present when any politician or political party in this House gets loans from abroad. This is the case with the Front National and I will ask personally the Conference of Presidents to consider this very seriously.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Boştinaru, this is not on the agenda. The chairman of your group, if he wishes to do so, will raise the matter you raised at the next meeting of the group chairmen. The formal sitting is about to begin. This is not on the agenda. One Member raised the issue, one Member replied. I believe that we must now make room for the formal sitting and listen to our guest, Mr Ban Ki-Moon. So let us suspend for one minute, giving Mr Ban Ki-Moon and President Schulz the opportunity to enter the Chamber. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr President, Secretary-General of the United Nations, I would like to thank the Secretary-General for his excellent work. It is a great pleasure for us to welcome you to the European Parliament once again. Dear Mrs. Ban, a warm welcome to you too. You have accompanied your husband here today – we are also pleased to welcome you to the European Parliament. Seventy years ago, Mr. Secretary-General, in 1945, the United Nations was founded in San Francisco. Today, the United Nations is the most important organization of international cooperation. They are the mainstay of the rules-based world order, and they are essential for safeguarding international security – an international security that is challenged in a wide variety of places in the world as never before, and in which the United Nations plays and must play a central role in resolving conflicts, because they are one of the instruments we need to bring about peaceful solutions. The European Union – and this Parliament in particular – shares the key objectives of your organisation, Mr Secretary-General: to combat the consequences of climate change, to combat global poverty and hunger, to commit to education and sustainable awareness. These objectives alone are fundamental to setting in motion peace processes, which, as I have said, we urgently need. I am sure I can say on behalf of my fellow Members that we are fully at your side in this fight as the European Parliament.  It is therefore a great honour for me to welcome you, Secretary-General, to this House of European democracy, and I am pleased to be able to give you the floor for the second time in the European Parliament. (Loud applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Secretary-General of the United Nations. – Mr President, I am honoured to address the representatives of the people of Europe. I congratulate President Schulz on receiving the prestigious Charlemagne Prize this month for his work to promote democracy and to bring the European Parliament closer to the people of Europe it serves. (Applause) This Parliament represents a wide diversity of cultures and traditions bound by a common belief that we are stronger and better when we work together. You play an important role across every aspect of the United Nations agenda. The European Union is a pillar of international cooperation for peace, development and human rights. The United Nations simply could not do what it does without the support, encouragement and engagement of the European Union. I am deeply grateful for your strong commitment. Today, I would like to highlight three dominant and interlinked challenges that must command greater collective attention: first, preventing violent extremism; second, addressing the migration challenge; and third, building a sustainable world for all. First, the growth of violent extremism is a grave threat to international peace and security. The unspeakable wave of brutality against civilians being perpetrated by extremist groups is a direct challenge to the universal values of peace, justice, tolerance and human dignity. The wanton destruction of cultural heritage is another affront to our common humanity.  I remain fully committed to working with the European institutions to address this challenge. I will present a comprehensive United Nations Plan of Action to Prevent Violent Extremism to the General Assembly later this year. Our long-term response needs to focus on fostering inclusive governance, accountability, respect for universal values, and dialogue among communities. Upholding human rights and the rule of law are essential. We must always be mindful of our special responsibility to avoid responses to terrorism and violent extremism that make the problems worse. We need to empower young men and women, and harness the influence of leaders from the cultural, religious and educational spheres. And we need to reflect on what motivates young men, and sometimes women, to become so alienated and radicalised that they are prepared to inflict harm on others and even end their own lives in the process. We see violent extremism most vividly in the atrocities committed by Da’esh, Boko Haram, Al Shabaab and other sectarian and terrorist groups. But it is also evident in racist acts and hate speech – including by some political figures and parties. Minorities and migrants are among the most frequent targets. Let us work together to address all of these ills at their roots. The challenge of migration is of great concern to us all. From the Mediterranean to the seas of Southeast Asia, too many women, men and children are losing their lives in perilous journeys of escape. This year, some 1 800 migrants have drowned in the Mediterranean – a twenty-fold increase over the same period last year. Half of those crossing the Mediterranean are fleeing war or persecution or human rights abuses. They qualify for international protection as refugees. Europe has an important role to play and a collective responsibility to act. Saving lives should be the top priority.  (Applause) While we need to see more effective law enforcement actions against traffickers and smugglers, we also need safer alternatives to dangerous voyages, as well as legal channels such as resettlement, family reunification and work and study visas. Two days ago in Ireland, I met with people from Syria, Afghanistan, Myanmar and the Democratic Republic of the Congo who had been successfully re-settled. Their new lives are not without difficulty, but they have found safety – and their new home is glad to have extended a helping hand. I know there are many more such examples across Europe – and we need even more at this time. This morning I had another opportunity, of meeting a nine-year-old Syrian girl who escaped atrocities and violence in her home country. I was so moved and touched when she was appealing to me and explaining her dream. I encouraged her not to despair; that the world is with her. The United Nations and the European Union are with her and her family and the Syrian people. It was one of the most touching and moving moments for me. I welcome, the United Nations welcomes, the proposals by the European Commission for a new migration policy. Today’s announcement by the European Commission of a proposal for the relocation of 40 000 asylum-seekers is a step in the right direction. I encourage EU Member States to show compassion as they consider this important proposal to share their responsibilities.  (Applause) Successful burden-sharing can enable the European Union to address the dramatically increasing flows of people while setting an example for other regions of the world facing similar challenges. The United Nations, the UN High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Organisation for Migration will continue to work with European leaders to address the crisis in a way that upholds human rights and international law. Our approach must be comprehensive, looking at countries of destination, transit and, above all, origin. We must work to end the conflicts and development failures that have displaced more people today than at any point since the Second World War. We must work together in Europe and elsewhere to address the worrisome increase in stigma and discrimination against migrants. Europe is experiencing low population growth and demographic transition to an aging population. The equation is clear: to meet its workforce deficit and maintain its economic dynamism, Europe needs migrants. (Applause) The post-war history of Europe offers one of history’s great examples of cooperation for peace and prosperity. Europe’s success has become a powerful draw for migration. Europe’s values and guiding principles must guide the response. I encourage you to live up to the standards you have set for yourselves and for the world. Let me now turn to the third and overarching global challenge on which we count on European vision and leadership: achieving landmark advances in this critical year for sustainable development.  This must be a year of global action. In 2015, we have three historic opportunities to put the world on a sustainable, prosperous and equitable path. The first is in July, where we must renew the global partnership for development at the International Conference on Financing for Development in Addis Ababa. Developed countries have a responsibility to lead on providing the funds for eradicating extreme poverty and addressing climate change. Official Development Assistance (ODA) will remain a necessary part of the financing agenda, particularly for the Least Developed Countries and Small Island Developing States, which urgently need continued and increased support. I commend those countries which have met the target of committing 0.7% of their gross national product to Official Development Assistance, including 0.2% for the world’s least developed countries. I urge other OECD countries to follow that example. I welcome yesterday’s decision by EU Member States to re-commit to that target. I urge them to spare no effort to reach it as soon as possible. At the same time, we know that ODA by itself is not sufficient. We must mobilise financing from a variety of sources, both public and private. The fundamental responsibility for financing sustainable development lies with governments. Thus we need to support the improvement of effective and fair national tax systems. We also need to commit to more concerted international tax cooperation, as well as to combat tax evasion and illicit financial flows. A successful outcome in Addis Ababa is crucial for building trust, generating momentum and translating our future plans into reality. This year’s second development milestone comes in September in New York, when countries will adopt a bold post-2015 development agenda and embrace a new set of sustainable development goals which will be called SDGs. This is a universal, people-centred and planet-friendly agenda. All countries must transform their economies to end unsustainable consumption and production patterns. Europe can lead the way in transitioning to a low-carbon economy. Third, in December in Paris, governments must make good on their commitment to adopt a universal, meaningful climate change agreement at the Paris Climate Conference. Strong European leadership is essential to deliver a new climate agreement that will enable Europe to manage climate risks, enhance its prosperity and strengthen its security, including energy security. Through its national commitment and climate and energy policy, the European Union is blazing the trail to a safer, more prosperous low-carbon future for its people and our world. I thank the European Union for being among the first to issue a climate target in March of this year, and for the generous contributions of many EU Member States to the Green Climate Fund. Finance is critical to securing an ambitious agreement in Paris. There must be a politically credible trajectory for mobilising the agreed USD 100 billion per year by 2020. And the Green Climate Fund must be up and running before Paris so that it can support Small Island Developing States, Least Developed Countries and Africa. I request the European Union’s strong support in ensuring this. I am also asking for the European Union’s support on designing and delivering a special package for the most vulnerable countries, including the Small Island Developing States and Least Developed Countries, that addresses their concerns across climate and development. This package would focus primarily on finance, resilience, adaptation and energy. Finally, I urge the EU to continue to champion higher ambition in the context of a Paris agreement, both through strengthening its climate target for 2020, as well as considering more ambitious targets in the post-2020 period. (Applause) Thank you for your support. This year marks the seventieth anniversary of the United Nations. Our organisation was born from the ashes of the Second World War which laid much of Europe to waste. Your peace and prosperity offer a concrete symbol of what can be achieved, even after the greatest devastation. We live in a complex and troubled world. But I believe we also live in a world of possibility, and that you are among the guardians of that promise. You are a locomotive with a most powerful engine. I urge you to pull the world from ahead and to push the world from behind with your strong engine power. Together, we can prevail in providing a more just world for this and future generations. I thank you for your strong commitment to and leadership in democracy and for the spirit of service you bring to the important job of representing the European people. I thank you as well for supporting the ideals and objectives of the United Nations – and for this opportunity to address you.  Let us walk together to make this world better for all, where all the people, regardless of where they come from, can live with dignity; where nobody will be left behind. That is our, my and your moral and political responsibility in this 21st century. I thank you for your attention and leadership. (The House accorded the speaker a standing ovation)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Thank you very much, Secretary-General. You understand German so well, Mr Ban, you do not need a translation. Thank you, Secretary-General. I believe that the agreement of the House has shown you that the points you have raised are also the points that move us. We are grateful for your second visit to the European Parliament. I would like to take this opportunity, Mr Secretary-General, to tell you that the Members of the European Parliament – I believe I can say this on behalf of all my fellow Members – thank not only the United Nations, but also you personally, because I believe that you are one of the truly credible representatives of the idea of peaceful cooperation between all the peoples on this planet. For this, Mr Secretary-General, a great personal thank you too. (Loud applause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on Preparation of the G7 Summit (7-8 June) (2015/2609(RSP)).

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the European Parliament for the opportunity for this timely discussion. I am here on behalf of President Juncker who had to leave for Tokyo for the EU-Japan Summit, and today leaving for Tokyo is even more difficult than usual because of the impossibility of leaving Belgium by air. On 7 and 8 June, President Juncker will represent the European Union at the G7 Summit in Schloss Elmau, in Upper Bavaria, together with President Tusk. This is the 41st Summit since the leaders of the ‘Group of 6’ gathered for the first time in Rambouillet, in November 1975. This year, under the leadership of Chancellor Merkel, G7 leaders will discuss a number of traditional topics and some relatively new issues. They will take stock of the situation of the global economy, they will assess progress on the global trade agenda and on their respective bilateral negotiations, and they will exchange views and seek common ground on the most pressing foreign policy challenges. Both President Tusk and President Juncker intend to engage in discussions with their international partners and to use the opportunity, inter alia, to share the latest information on major European projects and initiatives, such as the Investment Plan for Europe. They will also highlight current efforts to build a European Energy Union and illustrate the key elements of the recent European policy on migration. The G7 is expected to discuss and take an ambitious position in support of the negotiations on the Post-2015 Development Agenda in New York and in view of the Climate Change Conference of the parties in Paris at the end of the year. The EU will bring into this discussion its high expectations for both outcomes, consistent with the positions expressed by this Parliament. The G7 Presidency has also sought to use the opportunity of this Summit to shed international light on other important issues such as the protection of the marine environment, marine governance and resource efficiency. (Disruption in the Chamber: the President asked the speaker to pause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am sorry, Mr Timmermans, there is a slight disruption in the Chamber. Could I please ask for silence in the Chamber, we are in the middle of a presentation from the First Vice-President of the Commission. Mr Buonanno, could you please leave the Chamber.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – The Summit will address the health-related issues of antibiotic resistance, neglected and poverty-related diseases, and the lessons learned from the recent Ebola outbreaks. Against the backdrop of the Rana Plaza tragedy in 2013, G7 leaders will recall the importance of respecting labour and other fundamental health and safety standards throughout the entire supply chain. We fully support the focus on these issues, which are high on the European agenda and embedded in EU policies, with strong support, may I say, from this Parliament. (Disruption in the Chamber: the President asked the speaker to pause)

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I am sorry, Mr Timmermans. Mr Buonanno, could I please ask you to leave the Chamber. We are in the middle of a debate and I would ask you to respect the debate and leave the Chamber. Do I have the support of the House for that? Yes? (Applause) Thank you. Can I ask the ushers ... We will not resume the debate until you leave the Chamber, Mr Buonanno. I would ask the services to please ask the Member to leave the Chamber because he has three times disrupted the debate. Colleague, I ask that you leave the Chamber.  (Applause) If you are listening to me now with your earphones: please leave the Chamber because we need to continue our debate in a respectful manner, and until you leave the Chamber that cannot happen. Please leave the Chamber. I would ask you, Sir, to leave the Chamber. Can we please organise this?  Mr Timmermans, I apologise. No, Mr Buonanno, it is not possible because we have had a disruption three times. We need you to leave the Chamber now so that I can continue to chair this debate. It is an important debate. We can have a discussion afterwards but there cannot be a discussion after a disruption.  Could we please organise that and I will then resume the debate. Mr Timmermans, I am going to ask you to continue and I hope that this issue will be resolved as I have requested. Thank you for your patience.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Thank you, Madam President. I was on the verge of telling you something about the second day of the summit when the Heads of State and Government of a number of African countries and representatives of international organisations will attend what is known as a ‘G7 Outreach’ meeting. The G7 supports African countries in their reform efforts and in their efforts to strengthen peace and security, growth and sustainable development. The G7 countries will therefore engage in dialogue with their guests on their common challenges, including on food security and the empowerment of women. And there is, may I add, a direct link between this effort and the need to tackle the issue of migration in a comprehensive way. The preparation of the summit is now entering the final phase. The EU hopes for high-level deliberations and an ambitious communiqué, where its strong positions can become G7 positions. In Schloss Elmau, the EU will advocate for the G7 to reaffirm the need for urgent and concrete action to address climate change, to confirm its commitment to fighting protectionism, to continue its engagement to strengthen health systems, to fight antimicrobial resistance and neglected tropical diseases, and to learn lessons from the Ebola crisis on how to respond to public health emergencies. We also expect the G7 to strongly support the UN negotiations to achieve an ambitious Post-2015 Agenda for Sustainable Development, to take action to promote women’s economic participation and entrepreneurship, and to step up its efforts in support of food security and nutrition. We also hope that the summit will contribute to raising public awareness about the global challenge posed by marine litter, in particular plastic litter, about the opportunities and constraints of deep-sea mining, and about the importance of protecting and using efficiently natural resources. Last but not least, it is inevitable to note that, for the second consecutive year, this group meets without Russia. Following the illegal annexation of Crimea, G7 leaders decided to suspend their participation in the G8 until Russia changed course and the environment came back to a situation where the G8 would be able to have a meaningful discussion. This is clearly not yet the case and a return to the G8 format is not on the agenda. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Many of the tasks before us today are no longer solvable without a global perspective, without a global dimension. We are thinking only of the experience of the financial and economic crisis: closing the casino in which the financial markets have worked is now a European task, but it will ultimately only be possible if we act globally. That is why speech at global level is so important. That is why the G7 meeting is so important. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and EuropeanS have the hope that we Europeans will be there with one voice. There are a number of European Union states there, and we ask and hope that Europe will be able to speak together with the voices that are present there. First of all, I would like to say a few thoughts about the event as such. We all know that, in the context of this event, many citizens are also taking part in the G7 summit, expressing their opinion through demonstrations. And that is welcome, it is desirable for people to get involved, and also to express their perhaps different views on global developments. However, I would like to say on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats that we hope that this will be peaceful. Violence is not possible! And violence does not come from police forces either, but violence emanates from demonstrators who, unfortunately, promote their positions with false arguments. I also appeal to those responsible for non-governmental organisations to promote and ensure non-violence. Secondly, we have the open approach of the G7. G7 does not close, but opens the doors. The welcome of the Prime Ministers and Prime Ministers of Ethiopia, Iraq, Liberia, Nigeria, Senegal and Tunisia makes it clear that the G7 do not want to discuss among themselves, but want to remain open to all the other arguments that exist. Thirdly, as a general remark on the G7 procedure, I would like to emphasise and take up the argument of Frans Timmermans: Russia is no longer at the table. It must be made clear that anyone who breaks international law isolates himself from the international community. (Applause) Beyond the procedural rules, of course, it is first and foremost about the content. For us as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, the focus is first and all on growth and jobs. We need work for Europe's youth. We are committed to market opening, to free trade. Opening up markets has always led to more growth in the past, both in Europe and globally. That is why we want to continue working on this area. We are committed to stable budgets because only where there are stable budgets do investors have enough confidence to invest in locations and create jobs. And, as a third party, we need openness to reform – a reform agenda in the internal structures of states – to take up the developments of the new century. The second major issue I would overwrite is the area of stability. How can we ensure that global development takes place in an orderly fashion, as far as possible, without major crises? One of the big issues is the issue of radicalisation. How can we prevent people from becoming radicalised, perhaps even weaponised, and violent in our societies. The fight against terrorism is important, but only the fight against the symptom. The cause is precisely radicalisation in societies. What invites young people in particular to get on the wrong track? These issues need to be addressed. Secondly, stability also includes proper environmental protection. Climate change in the areas where Europe is leading the way, where Europe sets the standard in many areas, is on the agenda. We also very much welcome the fact that there are areas such as the protection of the environment, which is perhaps not so much on the agenda today, which will be discussed as a priority at the G7 summit. Thirdly, in the heading of stability, we have seen that health crises, such as the Ebola crisis, can cause great global uncertainty. That is why we need common global responses to the safety of the health of our citizens; in particular, the focus on addressing the issue of antibiotics is to be welcomed. Last but not least, I would like to point out that the issue that has moved us in Parliament over the last few months, namely migration issues, is, of course, also a question of stability in the world. That Europe is ambitious, that we meet the 0.7% target, as UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is now doing It is one of the benchmarks for whether we are serious about fair development at global level. There is much to be done, and it is good that the G7 is meeting, talking to each other and that we are considering giving global answers.

name: Matthias GROOTE
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is good that the G7 is addressing the issue of climate change. We have just heard from UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon in the previous speech. The three points he raised are related like on a pearl necklace. These are the major challenges we have to face. I believe that we Europeans must be able to show that we are not just pursuing climate protection on the one hand and then having debates here – climate protection versus growth versus jobs – but summarising the whole thing. The fact that growth and economic prosperity are decoupled from carbon emissions is the great challenge in the future. The big challenges ahead will also be when it comes to resource consumption and resource use. Frans Timmermans also has the topic of sustainability in his portfolio. I believe that we need to think more holistically, not only in individual areas such as the circular economy – the package is due to come this year – but to take a holistic approach to finance, the economy, but also climate protection. Because we are debating refugee flows – last part of the week. How do we want to respond? The influx of refugees will increase even more. And one reason that will further push these refugee flows will be the issue of climate change. Jobs and prosperity - right. But this cannot be built at the expense of others. And that is also the continent of Africa, which is hit hard when it comes to climate change. We are all in demand here. It is not just Europe that is needed here, but everyone is asked to change direction there so that we can take a different direction. I hope that the G7 meeting will pave the way and that this circle will then be closed – that a holistic approach will be found at the site and that it is not always just individual issues that are singled out and discussed.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: for the ECR Group. Madam President! Free world leaders come together at a time when challenges, threats and problems are rises. Challenges that seriously raise questions about our security, independence and fundamental values. I am pleased to see what both Mr Timmermann's, Mr Timmermann's and the President-in-Office of the Council, have said. As Mr Weber and others have said in relation to Russia, we also have problems and challenges in relation to our economies, in terms of security around the globe and in relation to the terrorists who are both in our own countries and also externally gaining ground.  The G7 leaders must find a way to deal with the threat posed by the so-called Islamic State in Syria and Iraq. It is horrifying to see how a darkened ideology is allowed to occupy one city after another, implement its ideology of horror and almost no resistance few. The free world must take the initiative to curb the terrorist movement that we are witnessing here. Here in the European Union, at least we could do more to find and punish those who, from their exiles in our countries, help and support the sick ideology that 'Islamic State' propagates with violence and weapons. It is intolerable to see the many civilian victims of the many massacres. It is intolerable to hear about the cultural treasures that are threatened and at risk of being destroyed. It is intolerable that the "Islamic State" can find supporters in our own countries who are willing to fight their cause.  Unfortunately, the threat posed by the terrorists of this world is not the only thing we have to deal with. The entire global economy remains under threat, including by the instability of the euro zone. While most of the world outside the euro zone has been able to put the financial crisis behind it, key parts of the European economy continue to be hit by recession – Why? Because the euro puts an iron ring around the countries whose only medicine appears to be internal devaluation or cuts, "austerity" as we call it. It is time for world leaders , not least those representing our countries, to realise that the rhetoric of a common policy as a necessary solution to all the world's problems is wrong! Our countries are not created from the top down, like, for example, the United States. Therefore, there is a limit to how much common policy it makes sense to pursue when the differences in taxation, in labour market policy and in terms of how economic and financial policy are run are obviously large. It's not just about economics, it's also about influence. The negotiations between the United States and the European Union on a free trade agreement are a clear example of the EU losing its breath. The United States has alternatives, and if we miss the chance of a free trade agreement across the Atlantic, well, then the Americans simply turn our eyes to China, India or other economies. The EUROPEAN Union is second-choice because the euro has destroyed our economy.  There are many things for the G7 to deal with. These are just two of them.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, first of all let me start by saying that I highly appreciate that this is a G7 Summit and not a G8 summit for the reasons that you have expressed, and I do appreciate the consistency that we are able to apply for once.  Now, in terms of the G7 and the reading of the public and their expectations, for the public this is a global forum, a global forum to debate issues of global importance, where vision is necessary and vision is sought, where concrete issues are debated and solutions are tabled. This is the expectation. And I think that in this respect, the agenda is fine. I do not think I will comment on the agenda, I see it there and I think that a lot is hidden between the lines. There is, though, one issue which we feel, and rightly so, has a European dimension. But this is not just a European issue, it is not an issue of Libya, Syria, Eritrea or the Middle East, it is an international issue. Today it might be Libya, Syria, Eritrea, and the most affected countries such as Malta and Italy, but also Germany and Sweden. But it is also Myanmar today, and tomorrow it might be something completely different.  So I think this is a serious issue. If we look at the topics – and again the agenda is right, with foreign policy, climate change, poverty, development aid and many other issues – I think we are talking about policies which lie at the heart of this problem, which in fact we partly co-created. We had a ‘plan A’ in some countries, but we did not have a ‘plan B’.  So my plea really would be – and I have to quote you, Mr First Vice-President, as you mentioned this in the context of the summit with the African countries – that there is a direct link to immigration. I would say it has to be a topical issue in the debate, across the board, in all the policies. It is an international issue and unless we treat it that way we will not succeed. That would be my message on behalf of my Group.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, and I am also addressing the empty seats of the Council, the agenda is complete. But the key question is: will the next G-7 summit make any decisions or will it come up with a painless wish list? Because, it seems, the world economy, but also the European economy, has not learned the lessons from the great crisis of 2008-2009. What happened to these promises to reform the financial system so that it serves growth and societies, not casino capitalism? Where are the global tax rules measures that will combat the huge tax fraud and tax evasion of large multinational corporations? Even the International Monetary Fund is spending weakly, economic growth is uneven, the risk of deflation and the European economy is a weak link within the global economy. The International Labour Office has shown with studies that full deregulation of industrial relations has not helped either to reduce unemployment, to boost demand, or to growth. Will what the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon, rightly point out about immigration and the environment, turn, this time, into decisions, into action, into measurable results, or will we simply stick to painless wishes? This is the crucial issue and, I hope, in your suitcases, Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk, on your return from Bavaria, you will bring results and not just wishes.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Mr Timmermans, you are obviously speaking today on behalf of President Juncker. I think that you and the European Union have a credibility problem, not only because, in your speech, I acknowledged verbatim the press release on the G7 meeting programme - it is nice to have read it to us, but I was able to read it before you read it to us - but, above all, when we analyse the European contribution to the debate that you have announced to us.  Let's take the subject of climate. I note that the European Union, with its recent decisions on the targets, has decided on a less ambitious and less restrictive programme. Yet we will say that the Paris summit must be a success. Also in the field of the environment, I observe that we will be talking about marine pollution, especially by plastics. However, I note that when this Parliament adopted a regulation on the disposal - hopefully - of plastic bags, it was your Commission that, through your mouth, objected to our desire to show more ambition than the Commission in its proposal.  Let's move on to the issue of development. If this is true, the Commission has expressed legal reservations about Parliament's and the Council's decision to be more ambitious than the Commission in its proposal. If we look at development aid, we realize that the European Union not only does not meet the 0.7% target for direct development aid but also pursues policies, particularly in the trade field, which naturally refrain from binding compliance, for example, with internationally recognised standards, such as ILO standards, as a condition of access to the European market. You tell us that you want to impose, that you want to discuss respect for social and environmental standards throughout the production chain, but when you want to impose constraints as in the case of minerals mined in conflict zones, you see all the resistance that this creates. We can talk about Ebola and global health problems. What is there in the Ebola crisis? Europe's contributions to WHO are riquiqui, far below what the European Union, a rich continent, should be able to do in terms of global health.  I could talk about a subject that is not on the agenda, which is all the more worrying, it is financial regulation. That has been talked about. We used to say, "Never do that again." Today, however, a whole series of indicators show us that we have returned to levels of tension in financial markets, to levels of inflation, to bubbles, particularly in equity markets or in real estate markets, similar to what we observed in 2007. Now it is no longer a topic of discussion. Yesterday, a timid European attempt to split retail and investment banks was rejected, an issue that should not be discussed. Each continent, arguing that the neighbouring continent does not take such strict measures, concludes that the competitiveness of its banks cannot be penalized and that, of course, it cannot be imposed on rules that others do not adopt. I listened to Ban Ki-moon's speech and heard two words several times: leadership and ambition. I am sorry, but today, when I see the positions taken by the European Union - not only the Commission, it is of course also the Member States - I see that, increasingly, we lack ambition and leadership in Europe. I'd like to finish - I've got 30 seconds left and I'm sorry Manfred Weber's gone. I heard the words "Gewalt geht nicht" in his mouth, and I agree with him. Among the conquests of the European Union is the resolution of conflicts peacefully, including between us. But when millions of young people find themselves condemned to unemployment in a sustainable way, when British workers are excluded from unemployment statistics because they have zero-hour employment contracts, and worse, when Greek citizens - three million of them - are faced with the loss of health and disability coverage or health insurance that condemns some of them to death, especially those with cancer or AIDS, I see that this is also violence.  It must therefore be understood that if we say 'Gewalt geht nicht', violence should not be observed anywhere and certainly not in the policies of the European Union.

name: David BORRELLI
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the forthcoming G7 summit is of particular importance because it is taking place in the year that Europe has devoted to development. I would therefore like to draw your attention to a number of fundamental principles relating precisely to the issue of development and security. It must at least ensure, for example, that tragedies in Europe, such as the drug of talidomide, which has only recently seen the seriousness of this trial recognised, do not happen in weak areas of the world. Often, pharmaceutical multinationals experiment with their drugs in developing countries where this type of activity is easier and there are fewer controls. We must prevent profit and the search for profits from coming before respect for the person, including his health. Development and security are two sides of the same coin. It is important for this Parliament to send a message to those who will represent the European Union at the next summit. I would therefore like this message to contain some strong indications, such as the need to strengthen dialogue with our African partners, which would impact on many things, from monitoring the exploitation of migrants to substantial control over medical trials, the need to strengthen the process of economic emancipation of women who, in areas of poverty and crisis, are the real resource for improvement and the need to develop a modern and concrete security strategy.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab As Ronald Reagan once said, the government can't solve any problem, the government can only create problems. We are constantly hearing that problems are growing in the world. Perhaps this has to do with the fact that the G7 meets quite often, and perhaps not. In any case, problems are growing. We have heard here that we renece the use of violence. Well, we had a case in this room where the President called on the Member to leave the Chamber. She did not use violence and as a result had to allow Mr Timmermans to speak without following her instructions.  We are surprised that ISIL , the caliphate, is winning with us. He wins because they use violence, and we don't. If we preach the slogans of non-violent action, we must lose. Only a moron can renduce the use of violence. Whoever tries to impose a life without violence on Europe wants the undoing of Europe. More besides, I think that the European Union must be destroyed!

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. Of course, climate change issues are very weighty. But when we think about the energy issue, we must also not forget about energy security, which is just as weight for Us as Europe. Let us remember the basic fact that in the European Union we are dependent on energy imports. The main country from which we import energy is Russia. Russia, the same country that, because of its military aggression in Ukraine, is not only destabilising the security situation across Europe, but also, of course, not invited to a meeting that was formerly called the G8, but now and now only the G7. What I think should be done at this meeting on the part of the European Union is to emphasise the need for the G7 countries to cooperate with each other directly on the issue of energy security. And here, the European Union has a very important role to play with the United States, which, thanks to their extraction of shale oil and shale gas, has a very large resource that they cannot export at the moment because of their own closures. It would be in Europe's interest to have these export restrictions lifted in the United States so that Europe can import natural gas, for example, not only from Russia, but also from the United States, thereby jointly increasing its energy security. So when we think about energy issues, of course, climate change is very weighty. But equally weighty — and it should be said during the G7 meeting — are energy security issues where we need cooperation. Thanks for the attention!

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Just good work for everyone in Europe and worldwide we achieve in three ways. Firstly, by ratifying and complying with workers' rights, as laid down in the ILO's core conventions. Secondly, through sustainable international supply chains with mandatory corporate liability for what is going on in their supply chain. And thirdly, by providing transparency to consumers by labelling products made under decent working conditions. It is precisely those three issues that Germany has raised for next week's G7 conference. My call is: let Chancellor Merkel's invitation to the trade unions to speak about this turn out to be a mere policy. Only through the right to association can workers force a positive change in their working conditions, and only through collective bargaining do they guarantee themselves a fair wage. Too often there is a paper reality and workers' rights are violated. So there is more to it than just voluntary action in the countries where many of our products are made. The G7 will be able to increase its legitimacy by using its economic power for real economic change. Only through hard international agreements is something done for the girls in the garment factories in Bangladesh and for the bowls that bring out the conflict minerals for us. It would be nice if Commission President Juncker and Council President Tusk supported this mandatory method.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As always, the organisation of the G7 summit involves a great deal of effort and money. It is particularly interesting that even the Schengen Agreement is temporarily suspended in order to protect this meeting. I note that it is possible to suspend the Schengen Agreement for the protection of politicians, but not for the protection of citizens. In Germany, burglary crime by professional Eastern European gangs is exploding, and politicians are negating this problem. While saving police posts, the German government is providing EUR 10 million to help citizens better protect themselves. This is an admission that the state is failing here and cannot or does not want to protect its citizens. Equally problematic is uncontrolled immigration across the Mediterranean. The EU now wants to introduce a quota system to better distribute refugees in Europe. In the case of the free movement of persons and without border controls, this system is completely useless. We have already seen that the Dublin Convention is not working and that individual states are simply pushing refugees on. The Security Policy of the West is a heap of rubble. They wanted to get rid of disliked dictators – in Libya or Syria, for example – and are now facing a humanitarian catastrophe.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, the G7 will meet and it is not going to say a word about the humanitarian crisis in Syria? It's just impossible! On behalf of our Parliament, I ask that the European Union remind us at this summit of this demand and this urgency. Today, as you know, there are millions of displaced people inside Syria. Eight million Syrians have been forced to leave their homes and are living in increasingly degraded conditions. In neighbouring countries, four million refugees also live, most of them, below the poverty line. All religious minorities, whether Ismaili or Christian, are likely to be hit by the advance of the Islamic State in areas where the group will now arrive. Thousands of Syrians are trying to leave Syria by all means, whether maritime or land, and are losing their lives. And the G7 wouldn't say anything?  This humanitarian crisis is the worst of our time, as the United Nations tells you. The Secretary-General rightly talked about that earlier. This crisis should trigger a global mobilization and mobilization of the whole of Europe. I ask you to do that. Today, you need to know that aid is decreasing, it is decreasing and that all humanitarian needs in Syria are systematically underfunded. I ask you to take this message to the G7 and I thank you in advance for doing so.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL). – Ladies and gentlemen, the G-7 summit will discuss budgetary policies to deal with the crisis. But as long as the blind adherence to the neoliberal policies of harsh austerity continues, not only will there be no growth but unemployment, poverty and the impoverishment of peoples will continue to rise. The concentration of more and more wealth in the hands of a handful of people must be stopped, as this is the root cause of the economic crises that are driving countries into bankruptcy and peoples into poverty, while large multinational corporations are increasing their profits. First of all, the public debt imposed on the peoples through dependency policies and enlarged by memorial policies must be effectively addressed. Its neoliberal management leads to the deadlocked path of recession and crisis. Today, therefore, it is more necessary than ever to promote policies to reduce the public debt immediately, either by renegotiating it or by deleting it. Otherwise, no country will be able to leave the vicious circle of crisis.

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: – Madam President, one of the main topics that will be discussed at the G7 is Greece, but even a high-school economics student could tell you what is wrong in Greece. Greece is a member of a currency that does not work for a country with its economic profile, and none of the debates, promises or strategies the G7 will discuss will change this fact.  The US delegation to the G7 has expressed concern that Greece could turn to Russia, but can you blame a country that has been economically martyred on the altar of the euro for looking for alternatives? When you look at the real human suffering in Greece, when you look at youth unemployment, when you see soup kitchens and rocketing suicide rates, then Russia could seem like a realistic option.  Indeed, Russia and its partners China, India and Brazil, have set up the BRIC network, which is providing an important alternative pillar of political leadership in our world, in comparison to the G7. For example, the BRIC countries have swept the oceans of Somalia almost entirely of pirates; they have pioneered high-yield crops in Africa; they have built infrastructure projects in some of the world’s poorest countries. Meanwhile, the G7 pontificates on the world’s problems and it is mostly talk and not walk. It is the old world versus the new, and the old is losing. And if the best that we can come up with is threats against Greece then maybe the G7 needs a rethink. World leadership is shifting to the BRIC nations and we have a choice. Either we engage constructively with these powers, or watch as more countries flock to BRIC. If we continue on the road we are on, I fear that Greece might just be the first of many. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), "blue card" question. Mr Nuttall, you said that Greece is in a currency that it should not be in and has reached this situation. Has it never occurred to you that Greece is experiencing the effects of the policies decided here in the European Parliament, when the imposition of quotas effectively prohibits Greece and its farmers from cultivating and planting what they want? So the European Union is uninvolved in greece's problem?

name: Paul NUTTALL
text: blue-card answer. – Absolutely – I totally and utterly agree with you. Greece is trapped within a prison of a currency that it should not be in, and if Greece wants to get itself sorted, if we were good Europeans, we would support Greece. Greece needs to set its own interest rates, set its own exchange rates, get its exports moving, and the only way it can do that is by leaving the euro and going back to the drachma.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Madam President, Mr Timmermans, on 8 and 9 June the Friends of America Club summit will be held. But today, the world has changed. What is the meaning of discussing world affairs without China, Russia, India, Brazil, South Africa or Iran? As my colleague said earlier, let us be careful that the logic of the clubs - G7 on the one hand, BRICS on the other - does not lead to the logic of the blocs, the logic that prepares for war. None of the questions that the Secretary-General of the United Nations is proposing to reflect on - immigration, sustainable development, health, development aid - can be answered in the logic of the blocs. Let us enter into a logic of cooperation between nations and not confrontation.  This parliament has chosen a side. See how he demonizes Russia, more than Kerry, more than the United States. Unfortunately, by choosing a camp, he is no longer able to promote peace!

name: Peter LIESE
text: Madam President, Vice-President Timmermans, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to thank Vice-President Timmermans for clearly mentioning two priorities in his opening speech, which are also very important for my group and, in particular, for my colleagues in the Committee on the Environment. The first is the issue of antibiotic resistance. It really is high time that the issue was at the top of the agenda of international and therefore also European policy. Angela Merkel gave a speech on 18 May explaining why Germany is putting this on the G7 agenda. We have 25 000 deaths every year in the European Union alone because antibiotic resistance means that they can no longer be treated. And in other parts of the world, that's much more. That is why we must act. The Commission has put forward a number of things on this. To this end, we are working on a report by Francoise Grossetéte on agriculture and veterinary medicine. I would encourage Vice-President Timmermans to address the issue with a view to the Commission's work programme for 2016. In the field of human medicine, for example, we must also ensure that new medicines are developed – new antibiotics – and that the antibiotics we have are used more responsibly. The second issue that has already been raised a lot, including by Ban Ki-moon, is climate change. In This regard, we urgently need to make progress in Schloss Elmau on the way to Paris. I would like to emphasise two points raised by President Hollande and Chancellor Angela Merkel in their statement last week: we need a long-term decarbonisation target on the way to Paris – and for this the G7 summit is an important intermediate point. And we already need a mechanism for achieving what we are not achieving in Paris at the latest five years later. We must now also be sustainable with the method. We are not going to solve all the problems, but we must go down the road to this in a very concrete way.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: – Madam President, the forthcoming G7 meeting will take place in the context of the extremely challenging geopolitical situation both in Europe and worldwide. I would like to single out three top priorities which must be properly addressed at the G7. First, the ongoing crisis and military conflict in Ukraine; second, the spread of ISIS and destabilisation of the Middle East; and third, the top priority, the refugee crisis on European shores. The entire world is watching with worry the situation in Ukraine from where, unfortunately, we have received this news about the ongoing destruction of Ukraine and the ceaseless efforts of Russia to destabilise Ukraine, both politically and economically. The G7 must objectively evaluate the real implementation of the Minsk agreement and fully support Ukraine in its fight for its territorial integrity and freedom. Another urgency is the global threat posed by ISIS and the spread of terrorism, both regionally and globally. Not a single country in this world is free from the danger of terrorism, and so the security tension in the Middle East will continue to grow and will pose immeasurable threats to global security. We have to be realistic that Europe will not be able to cope with the continuous influx of refugees and prevent thousands of deaths on its shores as long as the crisis in the Middle East is not addressed in a global, coherent manner.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: – Madam President, in June the G7 – the meeting of the 'club of the rich', the most impoverished, the most exploited and the polluting, and those who underpin their wealth with war and expolium – meets in Bavaria.  A meeting where decisions on climate change will be made or how to continue to wipe out our planet; about international policy or how to keep bombing; or about energy policy or how to keep stealing natural resources. Issues that affect us all, but in this meeting only the elected have a voice and a vote, usuring the voice of the international community to impose their privileges.  The G7 aims to replace the United Nations General Assembly, which would be the place to take all these decisions. They will also gather hidden behind a wall of 2,500 policemen who will prevent the powerful from hearing the voice of a people who are fed up with those who rule for the elites. But even by murdering, as Carlo Giuliani was murdered in Genoa in 2001, they're not going to shut us up. Carlo: we don't forget.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). Madam President, the next G-7 summit reflects the virtual reality of so-called globalisation. The German Presidency's agenda, which includes common values such as security, development policy, environmental protection and support for African countries in reform efforts, is meaningless. Common values are not mean without the participation of Russia, Europe's main geostrategic and economic partner. 'Security', with jihadists and Isis fighters having invaded European soil! 'Development policy' when, only in Europe, unemployment and poverty are galloping at an ever-increasing rate! 'Environmental protection' when a G-7 Member State – the USA – has not signed the Kyoto Protocol! 'Support for African countries' when, for centuries, the G-7 countries, applying brutal and man-made colonial policy, were delving into wealth and resources: Decisions are already being made and the summit is for the eyes of the world and the flashes of photographers.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: - Madam President, there will be 3 topics at the G7 in Bavaria that are closely linked, i.e. development goals after 2015, migration policy and relations, i.e. dialogue with Africa. Of course, there is a responsibility of the most developed countries in the world to support the development of those who are the poorest, but of course there is also a strategic interest in this, because to support sustainable development and eradicate extreme poverty in our neighborhood is extremely important for our own safety and the safety of our citizens.  Ensuring conditions of peace and stability in our neighbourhood is what ensures our security as well. But to achieve this, at least two things are needed, which are the right policies and on the other hand financial resources. As for the right policy, I think at least part of it has to be refocuxing our development aid policy. We need to focus much more on building inclusive and effective institutions in combating corruption in developing countries, in promoting good governance of peace and stability in these countries.  Of course, we need financial resources, and yesterday the Council reaffirmed the European Union's commitment to allocate 0.7% of national revenues for development aid. However, the Council yesterday did not set a date for when it would do so. So we can achieve this goal, but maybe not until 2030. That is why we must say here today that this will not be enough if we are to eradicate extreme poverty by 2030.  We need to reach the 0.7% target much sooner. We need to include other developed countries and that is why the G7 is a good format, and we need to mobilise funding from both the private sector, but also mobilise the resources of developing countries to achieve development goals under the new development framework after 2015.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – One of the themes of the planned G7 summit should also be women's rights and the possibility of their further development. It is symptomatic that the subject of gender equality and women's rights will be given space at the very time of Germany's annual Presidency of the G7, and it is German Chancellor Angela Merkel who has just been in the last few days, I think, being assessed for the fifth time as the most influential politician and woman in the world.  I therefore firmly believe that he will use this position at the forthcoming summit to unequivocally stand up for women's rights, especially for adopting more effective solutions to women's social rights within the European Union.  In these discussions, we always have a lot of suggestions on how to improve the situation in other parts of the world. How to help change the situation elsewhere. However, let us look at how women live in our countries, the Member States of the European Union. So we cannot endlessly preach to the whole world how to behave and turn a blind eye to the many cases of the catastrophically poor social situation of many women in our EU Member States, who are often driven to leave their families, look for work abroad, could not be in the upbringing of their children.  I also find it totally unacceptable for women in different Member States to have to do the same work for several times less pay than their female colleagues in the more advanced Member States of the European Union. That is why, from this forum, I would also like to call on Chancellor Merkel to also devote herself to the lives of women in EU Member States, and then we will all use energy together to help women elsewhere in the world.

name: João FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the meeting of the Ministers of Economy and Presidents of the G7 central banks in Dresden already anticipates what will become yet another space for reaffirmation of the policies and guidelines that have led the peoples of Europe and the world to disgrace, economic destruction, social and environmental devastation. A sure space for reaffirmation of blackmail and pressure on Greece and the Greek people. A space for reaffirmation of all fallacies on the fight against terrorism and climate change.  But they will certainly pass alongside the final statements of this summit some facts as unavoidable as they are inconvenient for the Lords of the G7. From the outset, the obvious economic decline of the G7 itself; then, also the evidence of a capitalist crisis that, instead of the thousand times proclaimed resumes, what shows us is still deepening, and with expressions at the social level that are increasingly worrying and that are, at the same time, the most alive libel accusatory about all that the G7 represents and defends.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I wonder what kind of spirit child is actually behind a strategy in a security situation that is becoming increasingly risky, with Russians and Americans putting more and more military equipment around Ukraine in place. In this situation, priority should be given to climate protection and, in addition, to the successful concept of a G8 summit, where the Russians were involved in deliberately ignoring the idea of reducing it to a G7 summit, that is a slick mishandling of the issue. That is also bad and we should do it accordingly. Similarly, I expect that we will finally put the financial and banking system on a leash on the part of the powerful states and communities of the world. Since 2008, we have been talking about implementing a separation banking system, regulating financial and high-speed trading in the financial systems sector. Nothing is happening for that. Half a billion euros in security costs, 20 000 police officers! And then the community goes on from Germany to my home country, Tyrol, where the Bilderbergers debate in camera. Those who do not know how to involve the peoples of Europe in decision-making will not succeed and fail in the medium term.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, the increase in terrorist threats must lead to the work of the G7 summit having as its main item the tightening of rules against terrorist financing at international level. In this respect, there is a need for effective analysis on tracking and combating payment methods and instruments aimed at terrorist groups. We note today that fundamentalist Islamic State militants provide consistent revenueto finance military campaigns in Syria and Iraq, from trading in various forms of crude oil and natural gas from ISIS-controlled territories. This urgently calls for strong measures to ban these transactions, noting that blocking the accounts of those who cooperate with Islamic militants is a necessary solution to eradicate these actions. Unfortunately, some European Union states are unable to effectively protect their borders, forming open doors for waves of migrants, while creating vulnerabilities for the entire European Union, given that Islamic State fighters can hide under the guise of migrants. Furthermore, we note that suspicious persons related to the Islamic State have been identified in the vicinity of the European Union, namely in the Republic of Moldova. Encrypted virtual currencies are another vulnerability that terrorist groups exploit. All these issues must lead the work of the G7 summit to focus on what it means to combine efforts for all states to strengthen security in order to effectively combat terrorist groups.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, with the need for financing development and cooperation with Africa, what we have the right to expect from the European Union and the G7 is not too little, but it is not too much either. And what we hope is a clear political signal of an effective commitment to building a more just and sustainable world capable of tackling the tragedy of poverty that calls into question the dignity of the human person, and that is what will be decided at three very important conferences, starting now with the Ababa Conference on development financing.  The European Union's duty was to respond positively to the call of the Secretary-General of the United Nations and to present itself before the G7 and in Alse Ababa with a concrete proposal, capable of inspiring concrete commitments on the part of other international partners.  Unfortunately, that's not going to happen. Yesterday's Council conclusions on the new global partnership and the post-2015 agenda are deceitary, fall short of what is necessary and run counter to the position of this European Parliament which, by a large majority, has called here for more ambition and more commitments in the report that I myself have presented. It is certain that the Council confirms the 0.7% target, but indicates not 2020, as proposed by this Parliament, but the very horizon of the 2015 agenda, i.e. it throws any financial commitment for 2030 by the end of the period. What is discussed now is not sustainable development in 2030, it is the financing of development in each of the fifteen years that separades us from 2030, and for that the European Union does not make any concrete commitment. Commissioner, the talks on sustainable development and cooperation with Africa are very beautiful, but they will not pass that even if these commitments are not to be taken seriously and if they are not accompanied by financial commitments appropriate to our ambitions.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: Se nitkellem fuq suġġett spe大ifiku għax fl-opinjoni tiegħi huwa pożittiv li fuq l-Aġenda tas-Summit tal-G7 hemm propjament l-ambjent marittimu u anki l-ħtieġa li nnadfu l-ibħra tagħna mill-iskart tal-plastic u dan hu suġetti importanti b'mod partikolari għal dawk l-Istati li jmissu mal-baħar. Huwa stmat, biex nagħtu stampa, li hemm aktar minn ħames triljun bi大大a plastic fil-baħar b'piż ta' mitejn disgħa u sittin elf tunnellata. Dan l-ammont re大entement kien deskritt ekwivalenti għal fliexken taż-żewġ litri fuq xulxin minn hawn sal-qamar u lura għal darbtejn. Il-plastic b'mod partikolari il-microplastic, huma ta' theddida diretta għall-bniedem hedge kif dan jista' jispi大大a wkoll fl-ikel tagħna. Għalhekk li neħtieġu b'mod urġenti politika effettiva biex innaqqsu l-iskart tal-plastic mill-ibħra tagħna flimkien ma' linji gwida internazzjonali biex inibħra tagħna li huma wkoll sors ta' żvilu soppstenibbli. Il-Ġnus Magħquda wkoll re大entement appellat favur ekonomija ikeirkulari ibbażata fuq ir-riiħklaġ bħala bħala l-aktar mezz effettiv biex innaqqsu l-ammont ta' plastic microplastic li jakkumula fil-baħar. Irridu politika li verament tħares lejn l-ambjent marittimu. Irridu nsaħħu l-kompetittività tagħna u ntejbu l-livell ta' għixien tagħna. U nagħmlu li nistgħu biex nilħqu dawn iż-żewġ għanijiet flimkien għaliex m'humiex kontradittorji għal xulxin. Jista' jkollna tkabbir ekonomiku u ninvestu fi proġetti li jtejjbu l-ambjent ta' madwarna. Huwa d-dmir tagħna li nippreservaw il-kwalità tal-ibħra li ji大大irkondawna għal ġenerazzjonijiet tal-lum u anki dawk ta' għada. U għalhekk neħtieġu strateġiji li jattiraw kunsens fuq livell nazzjonali, Ewropew u internazzjonali. Għalhekk li qed inħares il-quddiem lejn is-Summit tal-G7 b'mod partikolari lejn konklużjonijiet pożittivi dwar dan is-suġġett.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, the Summit of Heads of State and Government is always an opportunity to discuss and draw important conclusions and guidelines that affect the whole world. Topics such as the world economy, foreign, security and development policy are a common topic of discussion. The German Presidency and its partners are determined to address climate and environmental issues, not least with regard to sea pollution and social and environmental standards in the supply chain.  This should be added to the topic of fostering women's vocational education and bringing entrepreneurship closer to women. I am pleased that Chancellor Merkel has decided to conduct an open dialogue with civil society, and in this context I consider the meeting with young people hardest hit by the protracted recession important. Openness to the public and the availability of politicians to citizens is the direction in which politics should move, and certainly the institutions of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the measures taken by the G-7 to tackle the global economic crisis have made the poor poorer and the rich richer. They filled the world with armies of unemployed people. In a phase of global technological development, 1.2 billion of our fellow human beings live in extreme poverty. At the same time, in 2016, 1% of the richest in the world will surpass the property held by the remaining 99% of the world's population. The G-7 Conference is incapable of solving the problems of the world economy, because it insists on austerity and supports the casino economy. In a multipolar world, it is naïve to think that the smug shape of the G-7 can provide answers to the modern economy without taking into account the rising power of the BRICS. A new global architecture is therefore needed to solve the problem of poverty, to promote the write-off of the shameful debt that is being used up by states and to ensure the fair distribution of the wealth generated.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, there are two topics that I would like to highlight in particular, which I consider extremely important at this G7 summit. The first topic is related to migration, related to Africa, related to Ebola, related to everything we often talk about in Parliament and concerns of course those tragedies that we have seen in the Mediterranean Sea. That is why I want to believe that the G7 will also have concrete results when we talk about all those topics that matter, and we are talking of course about migration policy and the topic of Africa.  Another topic that is also extremely important for me, as the rapporteur in this Parliament for the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy, I want to underline the importance of European seas, world seas for prosperity for those countries that are at sea and I believe that the seas can be those sources of new development, because I am sure that this is one of the absolute strongest resources that our planet has.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). – A moment ago, we were faced with a solemn meeting where there were a lot of rhetorical speeches to present real events. In my opinion though, this should be a meeting of humanity's agony if it really wanted to face reality. I appeal to all of us to come together! Because the rhetorical discourse has reached its fullest and for the first time the difference between the meaning and what is meant, the apparent element and the actual element is presented in such a large dimension. I appeal once again: come to your meeting! We don't need celebrations. We need anxiety about reality, anxiety to deal with the humanitarian crisis.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what an incredible debate! Before, I heard President Weber – too bad he is no longer there – wondering what drives tens of thousands of young people to become radicalised. I try to answer him, even if he's not there. Destabilisation, inequality, poverty, exploitation and marginalisation are certainly not the only causes, but they are certainly the causes that transform it from a disease of the few to a mass epidemic. Our European epidemics, on the other hand, are two others, they are called inconsistency and hypocrisy. As long as we adopt a model of austerity that stifles and denies the rights of millions of our citizens, as long as our foreign trade policy is inconsistent with European principles and values, until we demand from our partners on climate change not propaganda and downwards but concrete commitments, and as long as it is possible not only to tolerate but to encourage financial speculation and tax havens , inside and outside the EU, we will not be the locomotive of the world at all – as Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon rightly said earlier – but rather we will take this locomotive to a dead and rusty track. Commissioner, that is the message I would like you to take to Mr Juncker and then to the G7.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, an méid a bhí le rá ag an Uasal Timmermans tháinig sé leis an méid a bhí le rá ag Ard-Rúnaí na Náisiún Aontaithe anseo inniu. Bhí an t-ádh ormsa bualadh leis in Éirinn ag an deireadh seachtaine, nuair a fuair Ban Ki-moon gradam síochána Thiobraid Árann.  Dar ndóigh, tá an cheist faoi athrú aeráide thar a bheith tábhachtach, go háirithe sa lá atá inniu ann. Dá bhrí sin, mar a dúradh, tá sé cinnte gur gá dúinn teacht ar chomhaontú insan gcruinniú i bPáras i mí na Nollag. Níos tábhachtaí ná sin, is gá go nglacfaidh na tíortha go léir le sprioc cheangailteach maidir le hastaíochtaí CO2. Mura ndéantar san ní fiú biorán aon chomhaontú a dhéanfaimid i bPáras. Tá mé ag súil go dtabharfaidh an cruinniú de thíortha G7 leid faoi sin agus go gcuirfidh sé sin feabhas ar an scéal.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – The expectation is that the G7 will also address important security concerns at its meeting. Thus, one outcome of the G7 meeting should also be a clear message to Russia that continued aggression in Ukraine will lead to a second flush and much more severe restrictions and sanctions than they have done so far. There is, of course, no reason to talk about easing sanctions, as long as their causes have not fallen away. The G7 is a country that shares common values, and as long as Russia does not share these values, it cannot have a path back to the G countries. It is also important to address free trade agreements, because the aim could be that free trade agreements exist between all the G7 countries, and it is particularly important to move forward now with free trade between the European Union and the US.  Energy security is an issue where new solutions would be expected and, of course, the situation in Africa and the wider Middle East, in order to put the border on a wave of refugees and a desperate situation for people.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the contributions from your Members. Many of them have already left so I will not address them individually, but I can assure you that I will take the messages back to President Juncker.  Let me be specific on a number of issues.
