The Commission, as you know very well, shares Parliament’s ambition as far as sustainable development is concerned, as far as ambitious climate change goals are concerned, for Paris and beyond.  The MDGs were raised. This is something that Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon also mentioned in his statement to you. Certainly this will also be very much on our agenda. If I listen carefully, I think that much of the ambition that Parliament wants injected into the G7 meeting is directed at the other members of the G7, but I would gladly pass that message on to President Juncker to take on board.  I also fully share the views expressed that, if we want to really do something about the position of people in the workplace and about honest relationships in the economic chain, we need to have a holistic approach to the issue and look not just at the situation outside of the European Union but also at the situation in the European Union. I think this is a message that came across quite strongly.  Where I have more difficulty in understanding the message, frankly, is with regard to Russia. I think the G7 took a clear position. If there is such a flagrant violation of international law, if you simply take away part of another country’s territory, there has to be a reaction. I think the G7 has taken the right reaction, and as long as the reason for taking this reaction is not resolved I think the G7 has no other option other than to maintain that position; and I do believe that the onus here is very much on the Russian Federation and not on the G7.  What I find surprising is that some Members in this House representing parties who are always on about national sovereignty, about non-violation of borders, etc., forget completely about the violation of the borders of Ukraine when Russia does it. There is a slight inconsistency in that position, I would say.  Finally, on this point – and I cannot repeat this enough – how far do you have to be encased in your ideological position to prefer the model of President Putin to the most successful peace project in European history, which is the European Union? Only if you are so enclosed in your ideological view – which is anti-EU – could you prefer the model that President Putin has put in place for his country to the model which 500 million Europeans have chosen freely and which has brought freedom and prosperity to so many people.  And yes, there is a terrible crisis; yes, it is unacceptable that so many of our young people are unemployed today; yes, this is sometimes driving them to radicalisation; and yes, they have sometimes lost trust in the future. However, it is our collective task to create realistic prospects of reform, of inclusion, of democracy and openness as a solution to this problem. Going towards an authoritarian path is never, ever, going to provide the solution we need to provide for our younger generation and for our future.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Guillaume BALAS
text: In writing. The 41st G7 summit is expected to build consensus at the international level on development and environmental protection policies. The summit is expected to prepare for the next two UN conferences, the Paris Climate Summit (COP 21) and the Post-2015 Development Agenda Summit. Germany believes that it will be essential to find common foreign and security policy commitments. The German Presidency wants the focus to be on issues such as strengthening the role of women. While international news points to the negative consequences that social, economic and political crises have for peoples, this summit cannot be used as an excuse for the Union to absolve itself of these responsibilities. The European Socialists stressed that economic growth was in no way at odds with environmental protection. On the contrary, the establishment of the circular economy demonstrates that both are linked. It's up to Europe to seize this opportunity!

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. Today we are debating the G7 Summit to be held in Germany on 7 and 8 June. The central themes of the meeting will be development and economic growth at the global level, followed by an important focus of discussion with the Heads of State of African countries on the theme of sustainable development. I remain convinced that the combination of growth and sustainability is the compass for the policies of the European Union and its member states, the importance of which is even greater by its strategic role and growing interconnections with the various international phenomena. Just think of the socio-economic effects of climate change and its effects on migratory flows and people's safety. On this very morning we were able to hear an important reflection by the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Ban Ki-moon. Looking ahead to next November's COP 21 climate change meeting in Paris, we therefore hope that the forum's work will strengthen the prospect of an effective global agreement.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. – Responses must emerge from the G7 Summit next June to meet the enormous challenges of our time. World leaders are required to give an important signal and renew their shared commitment to growth, development and foreign policy. Growth and employment issues must remain absolutely at the top of the world agenda. Although the economies of the advanced countries are showing signs of improvement, we need to be able to count on constant and sustained long-term growth, in order to get out of the current economic situation once and for all and to succeed in reducing the unemployment rate, particularly among young people who unfortunately look to the future with too much uncertainty. World leaders must also commit themselves to sustainable development leading to greater prosperity, the eradication of extreme poverty and also the promotion of peace and security. Development is, in fact, a prerequisite for achieving greater stability in the regions affected by the tragedies of war and terrorism. The situation in some parts of Africa is showing that the instability of those areas can no longer be seen as an isolated and marginal issue, but as a concrete and cannot be postponed issue on which world leaders must intervene immediately.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. The G7 meeting in Bavaria, under the German Presidency, is particularly significant given the importance of the issues on the agenda. A crucial part of the summit will, in fact, deal with climate protection and the fight against global warming, but also with the fight against epidemics and the improvement of health systems and standards in supply chains. Decisive challenges for the international community of the twenty-first century, to which we can only find effective responses in multilateral forums.  I therefore hope that the next summit, also under the impetus of the European Union, will be able to adopt a precise road map to address these issues, also with a view to a hoped-for success of the important climate conference in Paris next year. Finally, in the European Year of Development, we must also put the issue of cooperation with third countries at the centre of this summit, aware that the great challenges of immigration and terrorism can only be tackled through a strong political dialogue with developing countries and countries affected by instability and war.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On 24 March 2014, it was formally recognised that, due to the unlawful annexation of Crimea, the G8 meeting could not be continued. This is a very right decision. The great democracies of the world must remember that Russia's argument about the right of peoples to self-establish is clearly implemented in its immediate vicinity: first destabilisation, then ethnic cleansing, then the exploitation of the Russian minority in the neighbourhood. Now we can talk about hybrid warfare and aggressive propaganda. In the post-war order, however, the territorial integrity of states is part of the international legal order, and the right of peoples to self-establish is limited by certain criteria. Before the annexation, Crimea was not ethnically homogeneous territory. However, the Russian minority did not raise serious objections to Ukraine's respect for human rights internationally. After the annexation, the policy of the Russian authorities tends towards ethnic cleansing, aimed mainly at the indigenous people of Crimean Tatars and Ukrainians. In support of the dialogue with the African countries, I consider it wrong to omission in the agenda and in the preparations for the summit of the clearly isolated situation in Ukraine and the absence of an invitation from President Poroshenko. I agree with the prevailing view among NATO commanders that the illegal annexation of Crimea and the war in eastern Ukraine are the biggest threat to global security since the Cold War. I hope that these arguments will be taken into account in the work and documents of the summit.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. – I believe it is of the utmost importance that, at the next G7 summit, world leaders will discuss how to achieve sustainable growth in the face of record debt levels, as well as how to regulate the financial markets and how to improve cooperation on international tax policy. I hope that the G7 ministers will follow up on their commitment to reach a deal on climate change that is ambitious, robust and inclusive, in order to be effective in limiting the increase in global temperature to 20C above the pre-industrial level.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – This summit takes place against a background of increasing geopolitical tensions, and it should tackle the pressing issues of our time. I consider that there are some priorities which should be addressed at the forthcoming summit besides foreign and security policy and sustainable economic growth. Of course, the G7 should work to ensure peace and security: the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and the threat posed by ISIS should be at the top of the agenda. The implementation of the Minsk agreement should be evaluated, and we must tighten checks on suspected terrorist financing. However, infrastructure modernisation and development research should also be on the agenda, and we should not forget the struggle against tax fraud and tax avoidance. The initial expectations are high and we need to see concrete results.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. – I would like to begin by expressing my surprise at the ways in which the Commission challenges us. It is not normal for us once again to discuss an agenda which the Commission partially and without prior debate raises for which it is not even obliged to be accountable to the European Parliament. Nevertheless, I would like to express myself on one of the topics that will undoubtedly focus the discussions: the global economic crisis. The difficulties imposed by difficult access to public and external financing, as in Greece and the European periphery, and the negative impact of competition between States on global social and environmental standards requires a reform of global trade and financial institutions. The G7 should push for reform of the IMF and World Bank institutions to restore their initial objectives: to facilitate credit and technical support to those States implementing social and productive development strategies, rather than strengthening the continued blackmail of markets on peoples.

name: David McALLISTER
text: Writing. – This year's G7 summit in Elmau (Germany) is under the motto "Thinking of tomorrow. Act together." "Thinking about tomorrow. For me, acting together" means finding sustainable answers to the global challenges of this time. We, as the European Union, cannot meet these challenges alone. Closer cooperation with our international partners is necessary. This includes well-negotiated free trade agreements. The TTIP free trade agreement, to put it into practice, offers more product diversity and falling prices for European consumers and great opportunities for our European economy. It is necessary for growth in Europe and for the innovative strength and competitiveness of our companies. Without tariffs and unnecessary bureaucracy, it will be much easier for our companies to unlock the enormous potential of the American market. At the same time, it is important to ensure that our high European quality standards are maintained. "Thinking about tomorrow. Acting together" for me also means a return to the G7 as a community of values. Russia's violation of international law by the annexation of Crimea has made further Russia's membership impossible. The G7 stands together as a group of common values. That, too, should be a message from the G7 summit in Elmau.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – As globalisation accelerates, the widening of economic divergence between regions in some of the large trading blocs is being overlooked. Meanwhile, the financial system remains predominant over all other economic sectors, because it serves to run and monitor globalisation. It is allocated resources and rewards proportionately far above its contribution to real value added. Wealth and decision-making influence are again concentrated within a very narrow band of individuals and institutions. Global and regional outcomes are assessed according to macrofinancial benchmarks that fail to capture the growing divergences, or minimise their importance. Yet such divergences are provoking interregional, interethnic and intergenerational injustices. Economically, they are root causes of the stagnation that undermines the growth-potential of regions in the developed and developing worlds. All these tendencies are already contributing to destabilisation. They might not appear to offer material for the agenda at meetings of leaders from the world’s largest economies, so they have been taken over by extremist and so-called populist forces. Globalisation needs to be managed. It should not happen all by itself, as if it were a force of nature. The target should be the gated development of globalisation. This should be an item on the G7 agenda.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – It is the task of the world's most developed countries, including the EU, to find solutions to development policy and environmental protection problems. I firmly believe that the G7 summit in Germany will give us the space to discuss these topics and will also contribute to addressing the current international challenges.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. – Last year, the leaders of the international community made an important and courageous decision to exclude the Russian President from discussing global issues in the wake of aggression against Ukraine and the international illegal annexation of Crimea. The decision strengthened the primaries of democratic values in international relations, of which the EU as a community is now the most indoctreet representative. I think it is important that this is also confirmed at the G7 meeting in June, in particular with regard to energy security, another issue that defines Russia's international role as a major player in Europe, besides Ukraine. It can be said that the Energy Union, which has been drawn up by the Commission's package of proposals and has the convincing support of this Parliament, makes the EU a leading global player in energy efficiency and security. I think it is important that the President of the European Council and the President of the Commission can act in Schloss Elmau with this global example and guiding ambition, with convincing political support behind them. At a time when some members of the European Council, in particular the Hungarian Government, are facing serious challenges for the unity of the Union, including in terms of combating Russian expansion efforts and developing a more effective common energy policy, we must secure this political support from the European Parliament. This is also essential to strengthen the credibility of the EU as a global player and as the only participant in the G7 integrating different national interests.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – This is the 50th, and hopefully the last, time that I will address you about the Mistral warships that France initially intended to sell to Russia. I started expressing my deep concern about this deal in February 2010, when it was first announced. It took more than five years, and a serious armed conflict, for most people to come around, and understand our concerns. It is unfortunate that our allies had to learn about the security threat posed by Russia in such a shocking way, but at least we can take some slight consolation from the fact that the suffering of the innocent people affected was not totally in vain. During the past five years I have felt a sense of duty constantly to keep reminding Parliament about these concerns – even, occasionally, when it had to be done under points of the agenda unrelated to this issue. Therefore, I welcome with great joy the fact that France seems definitely to have cancelled the delivery of these additional weapons to Russia. I also understand France’s problem of having two expensive ships collecting dust, which is why I believe that the EU should acquire the vessels in the framework of the common security and defence policy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. – This meeting of g7 economic ministers and central bank presidents in Dresden makes it possible to anticipate the confirmation of the policies and guidelines that have led Europe to economic destruction and social and environmental devastation. Blackmail and pressure on Greece and the Greek people will continue. Let us hear the usual fallacies on the fight against terrorism and climate change, and we will like to see some uncomfortable, albeit unavoidable, facts for the G7 masters. Nothing will be said about the obvious economic decline of the G7 itself, which also reveals evidence of a capitalist crisis. We do not see the proclaimed resumption, on the contrary, its deepening, and with expressions at the social level that are increasingly worrying and which are, at the same time, the most alive libel accuser against all that the G7 represents and defends.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. – The g7 meeting of ministers of economy and central bank presidents in Dresden already anticipates what will become yet another space for reaffirmation of the policies and guidelines that have led the peoples of Europe and the world to disgrace, economic destruction and social and environmental devastation; a space, certainly, of reaffirmation of blackmail and pressure on Greece and the Greek people and of reaffirming well-known fallacies on the fight against terrorism and climate change. On the one hand, will be this summit and, on the opposite side, the will and struggle of the people.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the motion for a resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1306/2013 as regards the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in the educational establishments (COM(2014)0032 - C8-0025/2014 - 2014/0014(COD)) (2015/2659(RSP) (B8-0362/2015).

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is with great pride that I come to present this report on the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools, which is the first legislative report of the legislature on agriculture. This report is the result of intense collaboration with the rapporteurs of the political groups: Mrs Ribeiro for the EPP group, Mrs Muller for the ALDE group, Mr Nicholson for the ECR group, Mr Zullo for the EFDD group, Mr Ropé for the Greens/EFA group and Mr Carthy for the GUE/NGL group, whom I thank very much. With more than 22 million overweight children in the European Union, it is essential to change eating habits while promoting a healthy and balanced diet from an early age. Children's health, food education, support for agricultural products, these are the objectives of my report.  In order to meet these goals, priority should be given to fresh fruits and vegetables as children tend to turn more easily to compotes and fruit juices rather than eating fresh fruit. By focusing distribution on fresh fruits and vegetables, the new proposal will meet one of the objectives of school curricula: to reconnect children with agriculture and to support local and European producers since it was intended to give preference to local or even organic products. For milk, I believe that Member States should be allowed under conditions to distribute, in addition to milk, cheese and yoghurt, in order to normalise calcium intake in school-age children and to provide milk substitutes for lactose intolerant children.  However, I am against the distribution of chocolate milk. I do not want to offend Mrs Kostinger, my excellent colleague, but it would open the door to other products and, clearly, to flavoured products of all kinds with a sugar overload. As Members of the European Parliament, I believe that we cannot claim to fight obesity and promote both the consumption of various flavoured milks containing added sugar.  On the other hand, consumption of this type of product is not decreasing among children. It therefore needs less encouragement than others. That is why, sincerely, I continue to advocate voting against Amendment 49. Educational measures represent a fundamental dimension of new programmes with a financial envelope ranging from 10 to 20 per cent of total budgets. They will be designed to bring young people closer to local producers and to raise children's awareness of issues such as the variety of agricultural production, sustainability, environmental issues and food waste. In addition, as part of the same educational measures, children will have the opportunity to get to know local and regional specialties such as olive oil, honey, olives or Agen prunes, which I have not forgotten.  Let us not forget that school plays an important role when it comes to training young people in life and encouraging them to develop healthy eating habits. The reduction of administrative burdens, especially for schools, the improvement of the visibility of programmes, and the balanced distribution of budgetary envelopes between Member States are all other points that we have improved through the vote in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. By always pursuing the same goal, we are ensuring that more children and schools benefit from this program. It was clear that we had to try to gradually turn our backs on historical references - since Croatia (and Mrs Biljana Borzan was still telling me about this earlier) has a reference of zero - to move towards an objective criterion of number of children. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take advantage of the Commission's presence , and I welcome commissioner Hogan's presence - to remind us that there are still two threats to this report. The first is the legal basis. I will not go any further, but you are, Commissioner, that is Article 43, paragraph 2, or Article 43, paragraph 3. Will Parliament have the prerogatives it deserves on this issue? Will the Council want to arrogate them, which is obviously at odds with the Lisbon Treaty, which gives Parliament - as you know - the power of co-decision? It is therefore quite unacceptable to hear this from the Council. Then, in the Commission's work programme for 2015, this proposal was put on hold pending the results of a new evaluation.  Therefore, can the Commission reassure us or give us information about the outcome of this assessment? Perhaps then we can hope for the continuation of this case.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate Mr Tarabella and all the shadow rapporteurs on the work done on this proposal. I understand that you did a lot of preparatory work and consultations with different parties in order to understand the real needs of those directly involved and who are affected by the proposal.  I am aware that the Commission’s decision to further evaluate the school schemes and recommend to the legislators to put on hold their discussions on the proposal caused some early concern in Parliament, but I want to assure you that this move was not done to ‘dictate’ or interfere with Parliament’s agenda. The Commission as a whole wants to make sure that what we are doing is in line with the key principles of EU law-making, which is to deliver on the objectives of having better and fewer rules, and enjoy strong public support.  The evaluation is in fact in line with the broader Better Regulation Agenda which was adopted by the Commission recently on 19 May. And the review of existing EU laws, simplification, greater transparency and public scrutiny will be a norm for the systematic decision-making process rather than an exception. My services have respected the will of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development to continue working on this proposal and provided all the necessary assistance in this process.  The evaluation of school schemes as regards subsidiarity, proportionality and better regulation is in its final stages. The process has been open and transparent, and has taken due account of stakeholders’ views and the positions of all institutions. If you have had a chance to look at the draft report which was published on the Commission website on 12 May, you will see that Parliament’s position is very well reflected and will be updated based on your decision today.  To ensure full transparency and allow the public to comment on the preliminary findings of the evaluation, the draft report is open for consultation until 3 June, and I expect that my services will therefore finalise the evaluation shortly thereafter.  I will duly inform you and the Council of the outcome of this process and the further steps that are envisaged by the Commission. I am here today to listen to your debate and will make sure that your position on this proposal is taken on board and conveyed to the rest of the College.  I am pleased to hear that the position you are voting on today largely supports the framework of the Commission’s proposal. Of course I am aware that a lot of work still needs to be done in the case of possible trilogues, especially once the Council resumes its examination of the proposal in due course. While there are certain elements of your position which go beyond what the Commission has proposed, namely on the list of core products, the milk budget and the allocation criteria, I take your position on board and I am confident that if we engage in further negotiations, we will be able to come to a reasonable outcome.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the other shadow rapporteurs for the enormous and hard negotiating work that has enabled us to come to this point with a better and more complete proposal than the Commission. In fact, it was a very difficult process to try to bring these two programmes together, which had different main objectives, into one, and would treat them in the same way. Nevertheless, I believe that the future programme will be more attractive to The Member States, as it eliminates the principle of co-financing and gives preference to short supply chains, as soon as local products.  It has a strong educational component, encouraging young Europeans to have healthy drinking habits, preventing obesity and bringing them closer to farmers and the European way of production. It is essential that they realize that agricultural products are not born on supermarket shelves, but are the result of enormous effort and dedication on the part of farmers. This programme also represents a huge asset because, in many cases, it is the only meal and food for many young people who, being most deprived, also need to be supported in schools.  Parliament also proposes an increase of EUR 20 million for the milk programme, thus allowing, during the transition to the future objective criteria of the allocation of funds, no Member State to lose funding. I reinforce here that, only through this increase, we accept the new key of eligibility criteria. There is also in the report the possibility of transfer between the two pillars up to 15% of the financial allocation, according to national strategies. It is up to the Member States to decide.  I would also like to highlight, and I would like to thank you, for the enormous support and solidarity of almost all political groups with regard to the positive discrimination given to the outermost regions. We therefore comply with the Treaties and show that this is also a Europe of the regions. Finally, I would just like to say that there are some aspects to be improved and that the EPP tabled amendment 49, for which it asks for the support of this Parliament, since we believe that it should be the Member States who decide and, I repeat, the Member States and not the Commission to decide what should be distributed in our schools.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the programme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools is a fair programme, which Parliament wholeheartedly supports. That is why we do not understand the Council's position of blocking the democratic process with a quibble over the legal basis that wants to deprive Parliament of its role as co-legislator. We therefore call on Commissioner Hogan to put pressure on the Agriculture Council to maintain the same legal basis as that proposed by the Commission. We cannot afford to block a programme that has an ethical value, which is certainly important for our farmers, but it is also important for all European students. As the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, we have succeeded in introducing a minimum threshold of 10% of the budget for food education programmes. This is a first step towards strengthening the educational component in the future, in order to make this programme a major educational action to encourage young people to have a healthy diet, knowledge and consumption of traditional products of our land.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I congratulate the rapporteur for the fine work that he has done on this report, the shadow rapporteurs and all involved. It has been a pretty good way of working together. At the end of last year rumours persisted that the proposals for the merger between the school fruit and vegetable scheme and the school milk scheme faced the chopping block. While the desire for better regulation is of course to be welcomed, the Commission has not completely withdrawn the proposals but instead left them in limbo pending the results of an internal evaluation. I welcome the Commissioner’s comments on that today and I hope we do get a final resolution. While Parliament has decided to proceed with its consideration of the scheme, and I think rightly so, rather than pause knowing the carpet may or may not be pulled from under our feet, this is ultimately not a satisfying business that we have been involved in. I find the uncertainty disappointing. There are a number of elements of the Commission’s proposals that are to be welcomed. The merging of both schemes under a joint legal and financial framework could reduce the administrative burden on bureaucracy for the schools that wish to utilise the scheme. This is welcome news for many schools in my own constituency that are currently using the school milk scheme. Over 70% of nursery, primary, and special-education schools are making milk available to their pupils. And I think that is to be welcomed. We must ensure that the joint legal framework reduces red tape. For instance, I welcome amendments that would prevent schools from needlessly filling in two separate sets of forms in order to apply. At the committee stage I submitted amendments to broaden the scope of the dairy products that would also be included in the scheme, such as yogurts and cheese. I consider this to be very important for the dairy sector, not only in this current crisis. I also believe schoolchildren should be better educated about the supply chain – the fact that food just does not come off a supermarket shelf. I think it is very important that they are aware of the food chain. My group will be voting against. I personally will be voting in favour because I believe this to be a good report.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, Mr Hogan, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which he has been a member of the European Parliament. We are voting today on the aid scheme for school milk, school fruit and vegetables. Both are established programmes; the school milk programme has been in place since 1977 and it is a very complicated application procedure. The school fruit programme has been in place since 2007. In total, we reach 30 million children between the ages of six and ten every year within the European Union. And today we are deciding to merge the two programmes in order to reduce bureaucracy. As responsible here in the European Parliament – and also in local politics in Europe – it is very important and necessary for me, for practical reasons, considering implementation, to bring these measures together in a meaningful way. The latest figures clearly show that 70% of school children come to school without breakfast. In addition to the distribution of products in schools to the children, it is personally very important to me to establish the knowledge transfer about healthy eating here. It is particularly important that this nutrition education in schools can be taken over not only by teachers, but also by housekeepers and nutritionists. I would like to see a clear vote by the European Parliament today in favour of this programme and I urge you, Commissioner, to press for simplifications and also to implement them effectively in order to achieve real added value for the health and well-being of our children. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, and the co-rapporteurs for their cooperation and good cooperation, and I wish you a good vote.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I want to thank Mr Tarabella and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their work on this report. The proposal to streamline two separate schemes – the school milk scheme and the fruit and vegetables in schools scheme – makes sense. The promotion of healthy eating among children is an important and laudable objective.  In reality, it should be said that Member States should not need an EU scheme to prioritise initiatives aimed at making children healthier but, recognising that these schemes are in place, Parliament should be using our efforts to make sure the schemes are as uncomplicated as possible and as fair as possible. Funds should be allocated in proportion to the number of children in each country, and should be targeted at promoting local produce. The promotion of fresh produce and especially the consumption of fresh milk, which is in decline, should be prioritised. The principle of subsidiarity should mean that the key decisions should be made at national and regional level as it is here that the needs of local communities can be best addressed. I have to say that I have a fundamental disagreement with some of the committee amendments which would see more funds being spent on advertising EU involvement in the scheme rather than on promoting healthy living. The scheme, in my view, is at risk of becoming a very expensive and elaborate PR exercise if these amendments are passed, and I do not believe that this would be the most beneficial use of funds. On the other hand, amendments that we put forward would allow the scheme to be fair while minimising the wastage of public funds and increasing flexibility at national level. I look forward to the ongoing debate.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – I would like to thank the honourable Mr Tarabella, the shadow rapporteurs, for their cooperation and advice in the drafting process. Although I cannot thank you for the full listening and the comments made by the other groups, it must be acknowledged that the document itself is well designed. It reflects the need to continue and effectively promote healthy meals and education activities for students, bringing together the two previous programmes into one, reflecting and important proposals of the European Committee of the Regions. At the same time, I must admit with regret that, for some aspects of the report, at best questionable, we, the Greens, have had to table seven amendments. I want to mention the most important of these: – on the ban on flavour enhancers or substances E 620, E 650. As we know, such nutritional additives as monosodium glutamate (E 621) promote addiction, high blood pressure and overweight, including in children. Why the honourable rapporteur wants to feed our children for European Union funds with unhealthy chemical additives, I do not know for sure; – on publicity rules. At the moment, all schools that participate in the programme are public, but the rapporteur proposes to create mandatory standards: to put posters at the door of schools, etc. Who needs it, I cannot understand; I also want to draw your attention to the fact that the programme is not particularly large. In many Member States, less than half of the schools participate. Therefore, let us think about whether we can afford the luxury of financing the supply of chocolate milk that is specific to one country, spending large and fixed amounts on the publicity of the programme. I therefore propose to support our amendments 50 to 56 and, in particular, to reject amendments 11, 32, 37, 45 and 49.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks in particular to the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, who has shown great capacity for synthesis, and above all because of the stubbornness with which he wanted to move forward, despite the doubts raised by the Commission at first, which we believe to be a little more reassuring today. This programme of support for the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools is the result of data that say that young people and children in Europe are consuming food badly, that obesity is increasing and that the consumption of so-called 'junk food' products is increasing in particular. Therefore, we absolutely must react by proposing more correct diets, and where should we do it? We must do this in schools which are the environment where, as they say, the adults of tomorrow are trained. I therefore welcome the financial support given to the education programme, which cannot ignore a minimum quota that this programme itself defines. We must ensure that this change is a permanent change, because healthy eating also means a reduction in health care costs. So it is a sustainability footprint at European level. If we go into the substance of the programme itself, I am very happy with the inclusion of products. We have put a lot of attention to fresh, processed but un processed products because, as some of us have already mentioned, children need to understand where the product comes from, not from the supermarket shelf. From this point of view, the element that creates so much debate is that of flavoured milk. It puzzles me personally, because this is not a natural product, it is a product rich in sugars, it is a product that derives from large companies and not from small producers linked to the territory that this programme aims to help and support. I therefore welcome this imprint, this approach, and I also welcome the Green amendment against the inclusion and use of flavor enhancers, which is another aspect that diverts the training of our children.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: Mr President, education in good eating habits is essential, but it is jeopardised by the junk food of the big fast food chains that are too busy at lunchtime by teenagers - a public that will have to be taken into account in the future.  It is absolutely essential that each school participating in the program provides local products from its immediate surrounding area and thus promotes short circuits. The difficulties faced by our producers would be less if a genuine food sovereignty policy were defended. This would avoid the unfair competition in terms of prices and jobs that our French fruit and vegetable producers systematically suffer. Rather than imposing the logo of the European Union, to make propaganda, it is the advertising of local producers that should be developed.  Finally, since it is about children, we must insist on organic products, because there is no need to fight obesity if, on the other hand, the fruits and vegetables consumed contain pesticides, since the practices are different depending on the country. Despite its imperfections, we support the project.

name: Albert DESS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has The Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats welcomes the fact that two independent school programmes are being combined. Offering our children fruit, vegetables and milk is an important task. I would like to thank all those who have contributed. I would particularly like to thank Sofia Ribeiro, who has worked on this report on the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats. I very much regret, Mr Tarabella, that the product range is so limited. My group supports Elisabeth Köstinger's motion and I am sure she will say more about it. Moreover, scientific evidence shows that cocoa is a very valuable food. And that is why I do not understand that it is not being offered.  Europe, with its 28 Member States, is far too different to offer such a small range of products. In my Bavarian homeland, the school fruit and vegetable program has been offered with great success. More than 80% of primary schools were involved, 345 000 pupils receive fruit and vegetables free of charge, and in future we also want to offer dairy products. This also contributes to shaping the dietary behaviour of our adults. And I think the most important thing now, Commissioner Phil Hogan, is that the whole thing is implemented very unbureaucratically. It is not acceptable that at the end of the day a proof of use must be provided as to whether each child has eaten the apple. I certainly trust the European Court of Auditors to demand such a thing. We must be damn careful so that a good approach here is not ruined by bureaucracy. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats support these programmes and hope that they will be well implemented.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleague, Mr Tarabella, on the great work he has done in this important report.  I would like to ask you, since we have the opportunity to be with the Commissioner and to be present here , I regret that the Council is not here , the utmost support for this programme: it is very important to change consumption habits and promote much healthier consumption. I know you'll support him. I hope that the Council will change its mind in this regard. It is very important to focus, in my opinion, on fresh fruits and vegetables. We want to change lifestyle habits, so that they are healthy, in children from six to ten years old. That's why fresh produce is a priority. I would also like to say that I am also pleased that among the educational measures a product as essential has entered the Mediterranean diet as it is olive oil or honey. Finally, to say that I do not think the allocation criterion is appropriate according to historical criteria. Here we end up with the historical criteria and we will actually go to the number of children by country. That's my opinion.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: – The health of our youngest children is one of the priority issues that needs to be found in the EU budget. Programmes such as 'Milk and fruit in schools' are particularly important as the problem of obesity affects more and more children and teenagers in the European Union. The problem is that our youngest citizens prefer to eat fast-food instead of fruit or vegetables. So we must do our best to convince them that fruits and vegetables, as well as dairy products, are not only healthy but also tasty. Therefore, a programme such as 'Milk and fruit in schools' should be accompanied by information campaigns promoting healthy eating and local products, not the European Union. It should not be forgotten that these programmes are also intended to complement farmers' support, especially in view of the poor situation in the milk and fruit vegetable sectors caused by the imposition of the Russian embargo.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: – It is always to be welcomed if we want to make European regulation simpler and more effective. Sometimes, however, we may be better off asking ourselves whether we want certain regulations at all. European school milk and fruit is such an arrangement. A few years ago, the European Court of Auditors concluded that the added value of a European school milk and fruit scheme is nil. Europe wants to be big in big business and small in small. My appeal to the European Commission is therefore to ask itself where the added value of a school milk and fruit scheme lies. The national Member States can set up such schemes themselves. This does not require a costly and needlessly complicated Brussels bureaucracy. Sometimes we have to bite through the sour apple and dare to abolish rules. This is an out-of-control project that I understand very well in history but does not see the future. It has no clear objective or added value. I will therefore vote against this report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: – Mr President, I very much support this proposal to merge the school milk and fruit and vegetable schemes because it is in the interests of children, of local farmers and producers, and of local communities and economies. The long-running school milk scheme has been a success, but for the seventh year now children in my constituency in Wales have missed out on the school fruit scheme because the UK opted out. Learning healthy eating at school is essential. Obesity is a growing problem and schemes like this can help us tackle it. Children in Wales and the UK lose out so that the government can maximise the UK Treasury rebate. I want my constituents to have the same opportunities as the some 8 million children and 54 000 schools in other countries who receive free fruit and vegetables each year, benefiting their health and their education. I will continue to work for the adoption of this scheme in Wales.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, give a man a fish and you will feed him for a day. Teach a man to fish and you will feed him for life. EUR 250 million a year sounds a great deal of money, but divided between the 55 million under-14-year-olds at school in the EU it is worth EUR 4.5 per year per child, much of which will be absorbed by administrative costs. On a daily basis, this would give a child, for example, about a thimble-full of milk each school day and a sliver of an apple. In order for this to be meaningful, the Member States would have to co-finance by at least tenfold and, in that case, this whole subject should be within their control in the first place. The British pro-rata share of the milk side of this budget would be about GBP 10 million, which of course would cost the British taxpayer twice that.  I believe British taxpayers’ interests and British agriculture’s interest would be much better served if this cash stayed in the UK and was used to finance school trips to farms, which in turn could use this budget to provide facilities for visitors, including a classroom and a competent lecturer. Children should watch cows being milked and perhaps bottle-feed a calf. They should have the opportunity to pick some fruit and they should have the opportunity to ride safely on mobile vegetable-picking and packing rigs, observing people who really do understand what the word ‘work’ means. Now that would be an education!

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am also in favour of this type of initiative. I just wonder what bananas have to do with European fruits and why bananas are also included in the title. So, if we have said that this is for children, that there are 30 million children to reach, are bananas European? Are bananas zero kilometers away? It has been explained why bananas are important in children's diets, as President Tarabella said. Excuse me, there is a fruit called kiwi that has the same properties as banana, because the potassium of the kiwi is equal to that of the banana. Isn't it that maybe there is someone who cares about bananas for another fact, maybe for multinationals or for something special, maybe for the aesthetic aspect? I say the banana had nothing to do with this project, the banana if the adults ate it! The banana – you see, this is the banana – an adult eats it, the child does not have to eat it, the child eats it in Africa, he eats it in South America. In Europe we eat bananas, we give children the fruits and vegetables of the territory, not to do Tarabella or the multinationals a favour. (The speaker concluded his speech by eating a banana)

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Thank you, Mrs McA, good appetite!

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has With the decision that we have now adopted in the Committee on Agriculture – and the word 'chocolate milk' has already been used a number of times today – it will no longer be possible to spend fruit yoghurt and fruit milk in schools. I think this is a very big problem because, even under the proposals of the Socialists and Marc Tarabellas, we are only supporting drinking milk or buttermilk or kefir with the school milk programme. I would like to express my sincere thanks to Sofia Ribeiro, who has also tried very strongly to make changes here. I can only tell the example of my Member State: if the vote now before us is to be voted on in the way that we did in the Committee on Agriculture, we would lose 85% of our very successful school milk programme in Austria, because fruit yoghurt and fruit milk can no longer be spent in addition to cocoa. I would find this a real pity, because – and I would perhaps also like to address Mr Zullo, and Marc Tarabella has also repeatedly claimed this – it is not large corporations that produce these products. These are all family farms that, in addition to agriculture, also run their farm dairy and deliver directly to schools. These are very small companies which also source strawberry preparations, for example, from organic farms, which already produce them specifically for school milk programmes. I think it would be a great pity if we could no longer finance this in the future. I believe that we are going too far here; the Member States are well aware of this. And this school milk, this cocoa, this fruit yoghurt is also a barrier for the children not to resort to chocolate bars or sodas, which have much more sugar. I believe that we here in the European Parliament do not have to be more papal than the Pope, but can certainly trust parents, schools and, above all, the Member States to know what they are giving to children.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Tarabella and the shadow rapporteurs for compiling this really informative report because in this way we can see how the EU can be a bit more efficient, even more than some reluctant Member States and governments. I welcome very much the merger and the increase in volume where the school milk and vegetable schemes are concerned. In my amendments I have contributed by proposing to enhance national and local consultation in this regard, because I think that we must keep two beneficiaries in mind, namely the children on the one hand and the local suppliers on the other. At the same time, we should not benefit governments through this scheme. Hungary, for instance, collects 27 % of VAT on school supplies as on all other foodstuffs. So I would just like to the urge the Commission to examine whether or not we could run this school scheme as VAT exempt.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, I support school milk schemes. They are an excellent source of calcium for growing bodies and they are a valuable way to promote the milk and dairy industry. I also recommend encouraging children to regard fruit and vegetables as an invaluable part of a healthy diet.  However, worthy as those aims may be, I am not convinced that it should be the responsibility of the European Union, and in particular the common agricultural policy, to provide the money. Surely, the basis of EU expenditure has to be spending only where there is a common interest that cannot otherwise be achieved at Member State level. The Court of Auditors has shown that funding these schemes through the EU budget is expensive to administer and represents poor value for money. We should leave it to the Member States.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, on Monday I visited an Istrian elementary school and got acquainted with one sad fact, that many children come to school without breakfast, without a glass of milk, let alone that they have the opportunity to get some fruit. Therefore, I warn that the situation in many countries of the European Union, when we talk about children, about young people, is worrying.  That is why this is a great program and that is why I personally sincerely support it and I want to thank that many of our amendments have been accepted, of which I particularly emphasize the importance of croatia being included as a new member state of the European Union, and this will be significant for children in schools in Croatia, but I am also happy that the amendment to prefer local products is accepted , that local foods are preferred, and therefore the Third Amendment, where we are talking about olive oil, honey and other products that are similar to those products that are local products, is something that is generally acceptable and very valuable in this report.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while the European Commission has not made any progress on the issue of the Russian embargo, this European programme is intended to continue to finance the distribution of milk, vegetables and fruit. It has three major impacts: social impact, health impact and economic impact. Even if some of the provisions adopted are questionable, as my colleague Huitema has pointed out very well, the European Parliament's proposal is a significant improvement on that of the European Commission. But there is a paradox, we are making wishful thinking here. Indeed, if we are offered quality products in canteens, it is to better advance us on a disastrous treaty - the transatlantic treaty - which, by the principle of free trade, will bring us American junk food and call into question all our European social norms.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur on this report which reinforces the fruit and vegetable, banana and milk programmes in schools, as well as their pedagogical vocation. Indeed, a healthy diet is an important issue for European citizens as it plays a major role in the fight against certain diseases such as obesity. The European Union is therefore legitimate in this regard. Maintaining separate programmes, which ensure that the specificities of fruits and vegetables are taken into account, on the one hand, and milk and dairy products, on the other, is also important. Finally, Commissioner, it is essential to simplify and unify administrative procedures for more effective implementation of programmes in order to achieve our objectives. On the other hand, the compromise voted in the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) is problematic because the criteria for the allocation of the proposed budget envelopes between the Member States do not seem to us to be fair in view of the previous state implementation. Indeed, after a transitional period of six years, the rapporteur proposes to remove the historical criteria for the allocation of envelopes that Member States have benefited from. Their envelopes are therefore likely to be reduced at the end of this period, which amounts to penalising states, including France, which have historically invested in these programmes. In order to preserve the balance of distribution of the milk programme envelope between the Member States, the rapporteur proposed to increase the total budget by EUR 20 million. However, this budget increase, in a context where the overall budget for agriculture is shrinking, is unfortunately unlikely to succeed.  We will not support the amendments to this effect, although we are in favour of this report.

name: Susanne MELIOR
text: Mr President, Commissioner Hogan, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for his work I believe that what we are discussing with each other today is a good programme. And it is, after all, a European matter when it comes to the health of children in the European Union. We want to use more fruit and vegetables and dairy products in schools to help combat obesity – an ever-increasing disease for children – so that prevention can be achieved. And I believe that Mr Tarabella has been very courageous in pushing forward an important report here and that we have agreed good things with each other that can then also lead to success. There will be less red tape, there will be more money for milk – 20 million – and there should also be a common logo, so that we in the European Union also have the common feeling that we are doing something good for the health of our children in schools.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. The practice of implementing the School Milk Programme for more than 30 years and the six-year school fruit programme clearly confirm that these are tools that effectively influence the eating habits of children and young people in Europe. Therefore, the Commission's December 2014 initiative to combine the two programmes and implement them under a common legal and financial framework deserves parliament's strong support. This solution, which simplifies the procedures for accession and participation in both programmes, will encourage an increase in the number of beneficiaries, i.e. schools, and thus increase the number of young people benefiting from both programmes. The increase in funding for the School Milk Programme should be reconsider, at least to the same level of funding as the School Fruit Programme, i.e. to EUR 150 million. euro per year. The Polish delegation in the EKR Group will vote in favour of mr Tarabella's report. Thank you very much.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, for this good report. However, there are a number of places to check, and we are voting on these today. In the big picture, it is good that these programmes are being put together and unnecessary administration is being dismantled, but it would also be appropriate to change the name of the programme a little. Namely, when we are talking about the supply of fruit, vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments, and when we are also talking about local, regional production, we should soon have berries in place of that banana. We have berries, especially in northern Europe, and they are very good and healthy. The fact is that those countries, Finland and France and many who have well put this programme into practice should not be punished for well managing this programme. Therefore, this historical key, it should not be changed and this transitional proposal, which is what Tarabella has here. That is why there is a split vote on Amendment No 29, paragraph two. I hope that all of you who support this programme will then come along, then ensure that the countries that have used this programme well can continue to use this programme and that it will then benefit children and young people in Europe.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: – Mr President, Mr Tarabella should be congratulated on his work.  Ladies and gentlemen, the recent crisis, caused by the Russian embargo, shows the extent to which it is necessary to strengthen the promotional instruments available to us in the European Union in order to improve the consumption of our products both within and outside the Union, but in the internal market above all. That is why this initiative is necessary, because demand for certain products in the European Union, in some cases, is declining as a result of much of the changes in consumer uses.  Therefore, with a view to strengthening the healthy habits of all European citizens, but especially children, this programme to promote the consumption of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools allows to give an honorable outlet to a part of the productions that are affected, sometimes, by critical market situations, such as the one we now live with Russia.  I believe that the new Regulation merging the two existing regimes so far, fruit and vegetables and milk, gives coherence to the European Union's policy in this area and I hope that this merger will be a first step so that in the not too distant future the promotion of consumption of healthy products is not limited to specific sectors , but is opened to other products whose consumption also has a beneficial effect on health, such as olive oil or nuts.  If we intend to promote healthy habits, I don't see why we should limit ourselves to two very specific sectors and ignore the nutritional role of other foods as healthy as those.  I believe that it is good news that an increase in funds for these programmes has been supported and that national co-financing disappears, so that programmes are treated equally in all Member States and thus improve the European dimension of measures.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Mr. President, every year 30 million students in European schools have participated in the subsidised milk and fruit programme since 1977 and 2009, respectively. I support the proposal to merge programmes, increase funding to €230 million per school year and facilitate their usability at the state and local level.  I recognize the importance of educating children about proper nutrition, but this program is not just about that. For some students, he is unfortunately indispensable because their parents cannot pay for meals for their children. I also warn about the inequality of new members when it comes to the allocation of milk funds, because the use of funds so far is such that it cannot be the only criterion. Archival data obviously cannot be the only indicator for the allocation of future funds. Let's not let administrative reasons delay a valuable program. There is no saving on those who need us the most. I call on the Commission to complete the evaluation process of existing programmes as soon as possible, and, together with the Council, to continue the process of adopting a new and fairer programme. Congratulations to the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, and the support of the European Parliament should not be doubted.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, the aid scheme for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, as well as the support scheme for milk delivery to educational institutions are now merged into a single scheme. These programmes are an expression of European childcare and their healthy eating in schools across Europe.  I am pleased that my proposal to remove the disputed historical criteria that prevented Croatia, as a new Member State, from participating in the school milk delivery programme has also been accepted, thereby eliminating discrimination against Croatian children in relation to their European peers. According to an analysis by the Ministry of Science, Education and Sports and the Ministry of Social Policy and Youth in Croatia, parents of more than 10 000 children cannot pay for their meals in school. This programme will provide these children with a free and healthy meal at school and they will no longer have to starve. This programme opens up opportunities for local food producers to place their domestic products in schools, which is a "new market" for them. Therefore, I expect Member States to make this happen, both for the children and for the farmers, because domestic is healthy and homemade is best.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Universal Exposition under way in Milan is also dedicated to feeding our children. Yes, because "Feeding the Planet" – this is the theme of Expo – also means teaching our children proper nutrition. I would like to congratulate my colleague Marc Tarabella on his excellent work and on the great attention he has paid to the centrality of local productions in the food education of children. Eating is good and to eat well you must, first of all, know and appreciate the agri-food products of your territory. These products represent the cultural, economic and food wealth of the various European regions. Teaching to eat, as well as a cultural issue, is also and above all a matter of health, because more and more science tells us that we are what we eat. The data, unfortunately, tells us the opposite, that our kids are overweight. The school can and must also teach a healthy diet. The result will be a greater awareness of our territory and of the importance of our agriculture.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, I congratulate Marc Tarabella on his work on this report. I believe that the current structure of the two programmes leads to the efficiency of strengthening the educational dimension of young people to know their food and source, to increase the consumption of selected agricultural products and to form a healthy diet, thereby improving the perception of agriculture and its products. The mandatory educational measures proposed by the Commission to accompany the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools are welcome and, like the rapporteur, I believe that it is essential to promote a healthy and balanced diet from an early age, by reteaching young people to know their food and provenance, to familiarise themselves with their taste and texture and to get closer to local producers. That is why I support this report, and if I were to summarise the reasons, it would relate to health, education, support for fruit, vegetable and dairy producers, but also support for local producers and local markets.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that Parliament is once again showing an important sensitivity, greater than that expressed – let me tell you – by the Council. I believe that this is an important programme.  All the research, and the press reports them with great detail, tells us that the percentage of those who consume fruits and vegetables decreases and tells us that diseases such as obesity, obesity among children are on the increase. So welcome are these programmes which want to bring food education, which is a priority objective. Feeding properly means first of all preventing so many diseases, starting, as I said before, from obesity. Daily consumption of fruits and vegetables is important. We must educate our children about all this, healthy lifestyles to combine with healthy eating, we must educate them to conscious consumption.  Last but not least, we must teach them the importance of agriculture, of the farmer's work, of the products of their territory. At that time, as has already been mentioned, many of these programmes were also linked to the EXPO, which have shown that they are important. The sooner we start, the smaller the ones, the more important the results are.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. When you talk to children in schools and kindergartens and ask if they have ever had practical experience with Europe, you often get the word 'school fruit programme'. In my own country, Saxony-Anhalt, and in Germany, 95% of the participants are satisfied with this programme. It is very popular there. It is therefore good that we want to improve this programme. However, I believe that we have not yet reached our destination here. We need even less bureaucracy. Schools should distribute fruit and milk and not have to fill out forms for hours. Furthermore, in my view, the programme belongs to the second pillar of European agricultural policy, because there would be more regional scope for regional design. It therefore shows that this programme is good, but can be further improved. We are already taking a step towards this today – thanks in part to many effective discussions in the Committee on Agriculture and Development – but we must not shy away from further steps. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Peter JAHR
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Schulze, when you talk to the users in schools and kindergartens, they often complain about the bureaucratic burden. Sometimes it seems that the pile of paper is larger than the milk that is then drunk. Do you share this view?

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I have met with many representatives of schools over the last few weeks and months because I am new to this Parliament and, of course, I have looked around in my own country at what we have from Europe. The second thing I'm told after I've been told before hand, this is a great program and that brings something to the kids, is that They've been shown which forms all need to be filled out. And I have to tell you: this was one of the first times that I really wondered how all this was going to work, and I was really surprised that the people there in these schools and day-care centres that are taking part in the programme are still willing to do so, because sometimes the effort is extremely great. I believe that we should continue to work on this. However, many other Members here in Parliament have already said this today.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Mr President, I would first like to congratulate rapporteur Mark Tarabella on the report and the compromises that have been reached therein. I would like to call on the Member States to pay attention to the fact that in Europe the problem of obesity is becoming more acute. Finding answers to this problem does not just lie in increasing medical costs, it requires educational measures to explain to learners the benefits of a healthy lifestyle. It is extremely important that adolescent organisms consume quality products, because this is an investment in the health of future European citizens. I would like to pay particular attention to the use of organic products under the new common scheme for the marketing of agricultural products in educational establishments. These products have 40 % more dry matter content and have characteristics closest to the natural qualities of the products. I call on the Member States of the European Union to ensure that information on the quality of organically clean and local products reaches as wide a range of adolescents as possible.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would first and foremost like to thank the rapporteur, Marc Tarabella, for the quality and precision of his work in a context of legislative uncertainty that is difficult to accept. We are talking about health, Commissioner, and I think it is important for the Council to measure the issue of this issue, since it is European youth that is at stake.  The programme presented to us will enable us to encourage the consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables as well as dairy products among young Europeans and, therefore, to fight - as has been said - against obesity and to promote a healthy and balanced diet. This programme, far from being anecdotal, will also help to energize a whole local agriculture by focusing on local and seasonal products as well as products from organic farming. I would like to say, as does the rapporteur, that for nutritional reasons, this programme should not concern industrial products such as chocolate milk or processed products.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, the rapporteur and the Commissioner are to be congratulated on ensuring that these schemes are amalgamated. President Juncker said one of his main priorities was to reduce the administrative burden and bureaucratic rules. Commissioner Hogan has been in the vanguard in bringing that about and is to be complimented. These schemes are very worthwhile because they tackle the twin scourges of poverty and obesity – often inter-linked – and certainly in my own country about 2 000 schools and 200 000 pupils benefit from it. And of course if they get into good eating habits when they are young, there is a greater chance they will continue this into the future, and so will their parents and friends. I would also ask, even though some people have said this is a great scheme for the European Union, how many pupils, how many parents, how many teachers actually know and say that this scheme is a European scheme and it is coming from the European Union? I think that is something we should be emphasising, particularly at a time of growing euroscepticism.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: – Both of these programmes were created at different times and in their structure and in their functioning there are several substantial differences. However, although these are not new European Union programmes, they certainly have their justification in the current situation where there is a declining consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products, and children in schools are increasingly exposed to problems with obesity or unhealthy lifestyles. This situation is made more difficult, among other things, by modern trends in the consumption of highly processed foods, which are often high in added sugar, salt and fat and which are unfortunately popular with young age groups. There is therefore no doubt that the current programmes have meaning and justification, and I think it is important that we also increase the effectiveness of expenditure intended to promote the consumption of agricultural products in schools.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Commissioner, in Greece we say the saying "Burn you, John, rub you with honey". Thus, after the troika impoverished the Greek people with memoranda, after filling my country with armies of unemployed people and thousands of over-indebted households, the troika organized in previous years, through the Commission and the Greek government, the distribution of fruit and fruit and vegetables in schools with the programme under discussion. However, the malnutrition of children in Greece has reached alarming proportions. According to the research institute "Propolis", six out of ten Greek students, in 2013-2014, did not have access to sufficient food. Commissioner, the humanitarian crisis in Greece is intensifying. European aid for the supply of fruit and vegetable products, even dairy products, to schools is therefore half-measures. They are not sufficient to tackle child malnutrition in Greece. What needs to be done is for the troika to take the debt noose out of Greece and stop the credit suffocation of the Greek economy.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, obviously it is vitally important that young people eat fruit and vegetables and drink milk. It is good for their health. But the question has to be asked: how is this of the competence of the European Union? What next? I presume progress will mean that next you will decide what we eat for dinner, what time we go to bed, etc. The EU is ever so slightly inconsistent on this. Ireland has 130 000 children living in poverty. What the European Union is doing to Ireland is the equivalent of a burglar coming around to your house, stealing all your money, stealing all your food, stealing all your goods and then giving you a little bit back, bit by bit, to feed your children. Remember, while this school scheme is going on, last year Ireland was forced to borrow, in two tranches, half a billion euros and then destroy it. It would have fed an awful lot of children. This is complete and utter hypocrisy.

name: Milan ZVER
text: – I support a scheme to promote a healthy diet in children. In many countries, the practice has been well established and therefore well received. However, where national bureaucracy has over-regulated and complicated the implementation level, the project has failed. I remember that it was precisely because of the bureaucratic obstacles that schools in Slovenia gradually stood out from the milk scheme. I also support the new combined scheme. I don't doubt much about parliamentary support. I want the project to be as open, elastic, wide and as restrictive and complex as possible. A healthy diet for children is important. When I was education minister, I introduced a free hot meal for students. The project was well received, especially among students, and slightly worse among school leaders. Unfortunately, when the second government came, it shut down this project. This government was the left government.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Mr. President, I'd like to first congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Tarabella, on a job well done. Statistics in the European Union are devastating. One in three children is overweight or obese. Also, children consume too little calcium, adults consume too few fruits and vegetables, 30 - 50% of what is recommended.  Obesity occurs, and with it everything that comes bad, namely diseases, burdens to the individual, family and society as a whole. This scheme is excellent, on the one hand because very good eating habits have been adopted since early childhood, and on the other hand because it allows farmers to place their homemade products straight on school tables. Croatia has so far been very successful in this action and that is why I am particularly pleased that my fellow parliamentarians supported my amendment, which I gave together with rapporteur Tarabello, to exempt Croatia from historical criteria and to allow it to use this to the full extent.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I would also like to thank you for bringing this legislation forward. To appreciate the reduction of bureaucracy, the simplification of procedures that lead to the promotion of the consumption of milk, fruit, vegetables in schools, all this can undoubtedly be supported and thanked for this.
