However, there are also moments that I think are not so commendable to me and which, in my opinion, deserve changes, and that is actually a reduction in support, especially for dairy products, which is presenting the proposal today. I therefore support My colleague Köstinger's proposal to give this aid an extended range of dairy products. At the same time, I would like to express a certain sigh that once again there has been no real practical scope for the subsidiarity of European law, which should lie primarily at the level of the EU Member States. I think that we have some debt in this that we should deal with sometime in the future.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – Mr President, Estonia implemented the school milk programme years ago and we are very happy that now it will be combined with fruit and vegetables. The problem for us, as for others who have this historical tradition, is that now we will be punished and after the transition period support for the milk programme will drop. I am really sorry about that. I hope that maybe we can still retain this historical tradition.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: – Mr President, I would like to say a few words. I think it is a wonderful program and when we had too many ... When we had far too many agricultural products and we were stuck on it because of the sanctions against Russia, we would have called for fruit and vegetables to go to schools instead of it deverting – I think that would have been an approach. What we have here is the end of parental incapacitation. In recent decades, parents have simply been gradually disenfranchised. These forms of incapacitation have then led to certain children simply no longer being properly cared for.  Now we are calling for food to be provided in schools. This means that the parents who are actually responsible for this – and not a single government – will be further incapacitated. I think we are starting on a completely wrong side here in the European Parliament. If family policy is also possible here in the European Parliament, then we should start elsewhere and not in the food of children in schools.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I wish to thank Mr Tarabella and the shadow rapporteurs for their work. It is interesting to listen to some of the comments that we have heard today in relation to the schemes.  The Court of Auditors indicated some time ago that there was a problem in relation to proper accountability as regards the schemes operating separately. Therefore it was important to come forward with proposals where we could reflect those particular concerns, such as the proposal that is before us in this report which is to merge the two schemes together. Even though the schemes have been evaluated before, I think that the decision of the new Commission to look at all of the pieces of legislation and all of the reports before it will strengthen the scheme going forward.  I would draw the attention of Members to the draft evaluation report which was published on 12 May 2015 and where the evidence provided through that particular evaluation report clearly indicates the need for the European Union to become involved and stay involved in these particular schemes, because otherwise a lot of the Member States perhaps would not actually implement programmes that would have improved the consumption of agricultural products or engage in healthy living – not always a priority for some Member States. Through these education programmes, some food could be provided for less well-off children in schools and, of course, they could ensure that we have, as many speakers have mentioned, an inter-relationship between urban populations and rural populations in relation to fruit and vegetables and milk products.  I think that many people do not recognise that the schemes are actually optional and voluntary. Even though some speakers here indicated that they were against these schemes being part of the competence of the European Union, the Member States which they are from are actually implementing the schemes. For example, the Netherlands and Sweden have difficulties about having the EU involved in the schemes, but they continue to implement those schemes in their Member States. Therefore, in my view, it does bring added value to have an overarching EU framework in assisting Member States to implement these particular schemes. I want to conclude by thanking Mr Tarabella and the shadow rapporteurs for bringing forward these proposals. I take on board the concerns that have been expressed, as well, in relation to bringing the Council on board in relation to these proposals. The final evaluation report will be available in mid-June which is not too far away. Then we can engage with the Council to see how we can advance this particular report further.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, first of all, I would like to express my thanks to Paulo De Castro, my coordinator, who trusted me in the preparation of this report, to Hélène Cuisinier, from the secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, who has been very sharp on this work, as well as to Maggie Coulthard, from my political group, and alexandra Ionna Leone, my assistant. I will try to answer a few questions and objections from Members of Parliament. To begin with, I would like to welcome the Commission's initial proposal, which was in line with the restriction of products and in the direction of the public health objective. In response to Mr Rompuy, I would like to say that my group and I support Amendment 50 of the Green Group, which aims to eliminate taste enhancers. So I can reassure him on that point. We have talked a lot about local fruits and products, which are effectively supported and privileged, as well as those from organic production. But you also have to add seasonal fruits, because in a region like mine, for example, eating only local fruits in winter would be like eating exclusively apples and pears, which would soon be boring for children. Although they are not produced in my country and do not come from the region, oranges and citrus fruits, as well as kiwis , to which I will return later, are seasonal fruits and are useful for health in particular because of their vitamin C intake.  With regard to the amendment on chocolate milk, I want to make it clear that I am not an enemy of this product - my ten-year-old son drinks it, not every day, but he drinks it - but, having said that, 200 ml of chocolate milk equivalent to 20 grams of sugar, that is, half of the maximum intake tolerated and recommended for school-age children. , which is far too sweet.  Mr Flanagan and Mr Ashworth were talking about the responsibility of the European Union. It is clear that in 24 out of 28 countries too little fruit and vegetables are consumed, so if Europe can help Member States improve this aspect, why do you stubbornly refuse the European Union's help? I don't understand. Europe, without having a right to interfere, has the right to have good ideas, hoping that the Member States will apply them properly. There will be no war between bananas and kiwis, it would be useless. They are both useful fruits - banana for its natural sugar intake, kiwi for its vitamin C intake. I would remind you that there are European bananas in the outermost regions, which are also preferred and which, if not, will be replaced by fair-trade bananas, thus obviously trying to favour small producers. Finally, I will express a regret, Mr President. Food, fruits, vegetables, milk are important, but perhaps we could have talked about other drinks. Given the increase in soda consumption and the proliferation of these products, perhaps we should have promoted drinking water, which can be a useful accompaniment. I hope that it will be valued in educational measures. Like you, Commissioner, I hope that the Council, which is now rather conservative with regard to practices, will follow the common view of the Commission and Parliament, in order to move towards a healthier diet through this programme of distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. – By adopting its position on this proposal today, Parliament is showing that it really wants to move forward with this programme. The Commission previously announced its intention to test the programme for subsidiarity, proportionality and better regulation and is considering de facto abandoning it. We see it very differently. In recent years, the Member States and Parliament have developed a coherent scheme to promote fruit in schools. By the way, it is up to the Member States to decide whether they want to participate in the scheme, so as far as subsidiarity is concerned, there seems to be no foul in the air. Dietitians and policymakers are now fighting how to reverse the diabetes epidemic and promote a healthier diet. This programme must therefore continue, in particular. Fruit and vegetable consumption is alarmingly low in the EU. In two thirds of the Member States, the absolute minimum recommended by the World Health Organisation (of 400 g per person per day) is not even met. We therefore hope that the Council will quickly clarify where to go with this proposal and we are counting on the Commission to be prepared to continue working on this programme as an 'impartial mediator'.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Healthy eating is a key issue for the youngest populations in Europe, as the risk of obesity continues to rise especially for children. Programs to support the distribution of fruits and vegetables and milk in schools encourage the consumption of healthy products, with a focus on local and seasonal products, while taking into account regional eating habits. Of course, it is also necessary to educate the little ones so that these eating habits continue outside of school. The new text also simplifies and unify administrative procedures for more effective implementation of programmes. I had already started this work as rapporteur for the joint organisation of the 2014-2020 CAP markets. However, it is not a question of melting them into a single programme because we must preserve the specificities of fruits and vegetables, on the one hand, and milk and dairy products on the other. For these reasons I will support the motion for a resolution.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. – I would like to point out that school milk and fruit schemes operate in different forms in the 28 Member States of the European Union and have different successes. The latter depends only slightly on the nature of EU legislation, as well as on the conditions under which educational institutions in a Member State operate and the funding of education in the Member States, as well as on eating habits. Therefore, the objective of pooling programmes and requiring uniform implementing rules in the Original Proposal of the European Commission cannot be implemented. We cannot put the same coat on all EU Member States. It is therefore necessary to consider the amendments to the current programmes. The proposal on the table cannot be adopted because it would lead to changes that would benefit only part of the Member States, while preventing others from running programmes efficiently and tailored to the country. As a result, highly successful Hungarian programmes would receive less EU funding in the future than in the current situation. For the above reasons, I will vote against the adoption of this proposal. I welcome and support the Commission's move to suspend amendments to school milk and fruit schemes. The current system needs to be maintained with minor corrections. These corrections should not result in a reduction in member states' competences and flexibility.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – With different, albeit similar, stories and frameworks, milk and fruit schemes in schools are fully justified by the need to encourage the consumption of these products at school ages and facilitate access to them without economic restrictions. Since the trends of decline in the consumption of these products have not yet been reversed, the relevance of the two school schemes under way remains. Both schemes could be improved, for example in the area of promoting the use of local and traditional products. That is the meaning of several of the amendments we have tabled. Not accepting these amendments is a missed opportunity to give these two programmes another reach. On the other hand, it is regrettable that the insistence on the allocation of funds to institutional propaganda to the EU, sometimes even to the detriment of further strengthening of appropriations for the first purposes of these schemes, is regrettable. Of course, it is not necessary here to say the damage that comes from the current Common Agricultural Policy and its successive reforms for populations, healthy consumption habits and local production. The meritorious nature of these programmes is not at issue, but in this framework and in the face of insistence on their propagandistic aspect, legitimate doubts arise as to their real objectives and scope.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. – As far as the Party for Animals is concerned, the school milk and school fruit programme can be reduced to one programme, namely a school fruit and school vegetable programme. The school milk programme can be discontinued. Milk is not as healthy as we might think. Recent scientific research from Sweden confirms this. For example, drinking milk increases the risk of bone fractures. We also heard several Parliamentarians talk today about lactose intolerance, which is becoming more common in young people. Advocating "a decline in milk consumption among adolescents", as some here literally do, is an attack on public health. But it is also an attack on nature, on the climate and on the animals, which are trapped in ever more massive stables. We shouldn't exploit animals and milk them. We can use the budget for school milk better for more school fruit and vegetables. In doing so, we limit the adverse impact of intensive livestock farming on our planet and give children a healthier food choice. Nor do we think it is appropriate for European logos to be pasted on everything. This form of propaganda is scandalous symbolic politics on the backs of children. I also believe that all European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: Written. "Healthy and varied nutrition is essential for a well-being person. It is especially important for a growing child. Unfortunately, healthy food is often more expensive than one-sided and unhealthy food. The EU currently has two separate school programmes to support a healthy diet in schools and kindergartens. The milk products programme has been in operation since 1977 and the fruit programme since 2007. As a Finn, it is easy to be proud of free school meals. At the same time, attention is drawn to the fact that not all European children and young people have a similar opportunity. When we vote on this, it is a question of combining these two existing programmes and making them more efficient. The same money should be enough even further. I am very much in favour of this. Healthy nutrition belongs to everyone.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. – We make full use of the current system in Slovakia and we are properly pumping almost all the funds for both programmes. Because the Competent Commissioner has decided to audit both programmes, the best solution would be to wait for the results of the audit and use them to decide on the way forward. I consider it positive to extend the range of products that can be distributed in schools from the EU budget, such as not only milk, but also yoghurts, cheeses, cottage cheese, and can be used directly from the region. I am pleased that the budget for milk and milk products will be extended by EUR 20 million. It is now up to the EU Council of Ministers to consider the need for audit results to complete the approval process.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: in writing. –  I welcome the Commission’s new aid scheme. The original idea of ensuring access for children to natural products must be enhanced. The number of educational establishments and students benefiting from the scheme should be increased. This can be achieved if the Member States increase their commitment in the implementation of the scheme. There are over 22 million children in the European Union with excessive weight and almost 5 million with obesity problems. In Bulgaria alone the share of pupils with obesity problems has increased from less than 10 % in 1998 to 21% among boys and 15% among girls in 2011. The existing ‘School Milk’ and ‘School Fruit’ schemes have been a step in the right direction. In my country children aged 7-10 consume on average only 40% of the recommended daily intake of fruit and vegetables. 89% of parents of children that have been benefiting from the scheme explicitly state their desire for it to be continued.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Every year, some 30 million European schoolchildren benefit from the two EU-funded programmes, the school-ready milk programme and the school fruit consumption programme. These programs are designed to encourage children to eat healthy products and adopt good eating habits in response to rising childhood obesity rates. In January 2014, the Commission published a legislative proposal to merge these two programmes into a common legal and financial framework in order to increase their effectiveness and reduce the administrative burden on national and local actors. In December 2014, the new Commission presented its work programme for 2015, which stated that the legislative proposal on the merger of the "fruit" and "milk" programmes was suspended until an evaluation was carried out under the CAP simplification exercise. Notwithstanding the Commission's recommendation, I invite you to vote today on this report so that work to amend the legislative proposal can continue. The adoption of this mandate is therefore a strong signal that Parliament wants work to continue. I welcome that in advance.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. – Almost a third of European children are overweight or suffer from obesity. That is why I would first of all like to emphasise the important educational role that the Fruit and Vegetables programme has in schools, and I hope for the best possible implementation in the Member States. The creation of a common legal framework for the two programmes is welcome, especially given the situation in the dairy and fruit sectors, which are heavily affected by the Russian embargo. I would also like to welcome the Commission's proposal on flexibility. It is essential that Member States are able to transfer funds between programmes to respond to the challenges facing indigenous sectors. However, I would like to draw attention to the importance of using short supply chains in the distribution of milk and fruit in schools. It is crucial that students are connected with farmers and agricultural production. Equally important is the distribution of products as natural as possible, without added sweeteners, and the fruit to be fresh and, if possible, grown locally and as naturally as possible, without pesticides and chemical fertilizers. I hope that a swift agreement will be reached between the institutions on this regulation and that the Member States will implement it successfully.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. – We need to improve the functioning of this programme and that is what this is all about now. It is about contributing to consolidate healthy eating habits, promoting the consumption of essential nutrients by children. Equally important, the programme helps to stabilise the flow of milk, fruit and vegetables, sectors already greatly affected by the decrease in domestic consumption and the effects of the Russian embargo. The programme for the free distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools is therefore of the utmost importance, not least because the consumption of these products has been decreasing in the European Union. This aspect has a double consequence. On the one hand, the impact on the health of the population and, on the other hand, the impact on agricultural markets. I call for the negotiation to take place in the spirit of the position we will be voting on today, so that the capital gains of this programme can be properly used in all regions of Europe, particularly in the Azores.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. – A healthy diet of children and adolescents is urgently needed during the growth and development phase, as the energy and nutritional value of meals are important for energy, day-to-day work, body growth and development and psychosocial development. Worryingly, the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables has declined in Europe in 2005-2010. The decline in fruit consumption is 9.4 per cent and vegetables 10.3 per cent. Among the many factors that determine a healthy diet, sufficient consumption of fruit and vegetables plays a particular role. According to WHO research, insufficient consumption of fruit and vegetables was ranked as a high number of attributable risk factors for premature mortality in the EU. The diet, which includes different types of fruit and vegetables on a daily basis, is very important for children in order to increase the nutritional value of meals and to maintain the recommended body weight. The European Association for the Study of Obesity estimates that between 12,000,000 and 16,000,000 children are overweight in Europe. The number of obese children is between 3 and 4.5 million. All these reasons clearly show that it is essential to introduce healthy eating habits through educational institutions at a young age, since an orderly school diet is one of the most effective ways of correcting unhealthy (family) diets and also affects the reduction of social disparities.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. – With today's decision, the European Parliament gives a clear signal to the Council that it supports the adoption of the school scheme regulation as soon as possible in order to reduce the administrative burden of their implementation and make them more effective.  The adoption of single rules for both schemes and the abolition of the co-financing requirement will lead to a fairer distribution of funds between Member States and increase interest in the School Milk scheme. We're pushing for a $20 million increase. the annual budget for milk in schools as an additional measure to support the dairy sector, local and small dairy producers most affected by the dropping of milk quotas. I welcome the expansion of the range of products in school with honey, yogurt and cheese, which are traditional for our country and have a proven positive effect on children's health. In addition to contributing to a healthy and balanced diet, the inclusion of these products in the daily menu of adolescents will increase their knowledge of the origin of food and stimulate local and organic producers by providing a market for their production. I therefore support the involvement of producer organisations in school schemes as a means of stimulating short supply chains and children's access to better quality and seasonal fruit and vegetables.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. – Programmes aimed at distributing fruit and milk, which aim to increase the consumption of these products in children and motivate them to a healthy lifestyle, have been operating in Slovak schools for several years. It is difficult to say to what extent they are fulfilling their purpose, as the last national evaluation of the school fruit programme was carried out in 2011 and the evaluation of the school milk programme is not available. I am all the more sorry that the European Parliament has not obeyed the Commission's call not to work on the new proposal until the current European evaluation of the schemes has been completed. I think it's a bad thing. If Parliament had waited for the findings, it could have prepared a better proposal. In the final negotiations between the Commission, the Council and Parliament, it will be necessary to fight for a form of proposal that will help to remedy these shortcomings. In terms of the number of schools and children involved, the school fruit programme has been more successful in our country so far. However, even with his administration, there were problems. Due to the lack of financial and staffing capacity, the fruit was handed out in school canteens, which are not visited by all children. At the same time, Slovakia is one of the few countries where parents must also contribute to the programme, which may discourage schools in poorer regions from being involved. The main problem with the implementation of the milk programme, in turn, is the lack of technical equipment.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is voting time. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes.)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That concludes the vote. (The sitting was suspended at 6.40 p.m. and resumed at 7 p.m.)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the Commission statement on the European Union's development aid to Eritrea in the light of documented human rights violations (2015/2683(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity to discuss EU development aid to Eritrea in the light of documented human rights abuses. Respect for human rights is a basic principle of EU foreign policy and therefore features regularly in our dialogue with partners in the entire world, including Eritrea. In this dialogue, and also publically, we raise our concerns that Eritrea continues to violate its obligations and does not respect fundamental human rights. We urge concrete gestures such as the liberation of the prisoners – notably Mr Dawit Isaak, an EU-Eritrean citizen – who have been detained incommunicado since 2001. The European Union also raises those concerns in international forums, notably at meetings of the UN Human Rights Council, where we appeal to Eritrea to cooperate with the UN Special Rapporteur and the UN Commission of Inquiry for Eritrea and to give them access to Eritrea. That said, it is our belief that continued engagement with Eritrea is the best option for a number of reasons. Firstly, engagement creates the possibility to stress the need for concrete changes and progress across the board, and to insist on the importance of adhering to international standards on human rights. Isolation rarely helps in these circumstances. Secondly, engagement allows us to continue supporting the population and improving living conditions. Lastly, engagement contributes to peace and stability in the country and the wider region. Some minor progress has recently been achieved: for example, in December 2014 the Government of Eritrea announced that the previously indefinite duration of national service would be limited to 18 months for new recruits. This is an important decision, since the open-ended duration of national service was a major push factor in migration. The decision now needs to be implemented. We must do what we can to alleviate the huge stress upon Eritrea’s population. They are facing a problematic food security situation and a lack of economic prospects and opportunities. The sharpest evidence of their despair is the outflow of people, especially young people, many of whom venture on a dangerous journey, trying to enter the EU by illegal means, and are easy prey for traffickers. That is why European Union development projects currently being implemented under the 10th European Development Fund (EDF), in the amount of EUR 53.7 million and covering the period from 2008 to now, relate mainly to agriculture and food security. The second sector is governance, with the focus on capacity-building and access to justice at grassroots level, in particular through community courts. Our aid is provided through projects and not through budget support. Strict monitoring procedures ensure that EU aid directly benefits the people, creates jobs and reduces poverty. There is no support to the central government in Eritrea. As regards the programming of the aid under the 11th European Development Fund, discussions are ongoing. It is proposed that EU development aid will support social and economic development, including through increasing access to renewable energy, in order to achieve tangible results for the population such as the creation of more jobs and the improvement of people’s livelihoods in Eritrea. In addition, support for governance-related activities that would promote sustainable economic growth is also provided for. Apart from the EU cooperation financed from the European Development Fund, the European Union has also allocated thematic funds in order to support, and build the capacity of, formal and informal civil society organisations active in the areas of social, cultural and economic rights. Although the context currently allows for only limited visibility, this engagement with non-state actors does encourage plurality and will strengthen citizens’ participation, including in the medium and long term. Let me say, too, a few words about migration. Eritrea is a key country of origin. By improving the livelihoods of the people of Eritrea, development aid is addressing and will continue to address the root causes of migration. Eritrea is an active partner in the Khartoum Process, under which human rights issues related to migrants and refugees will be addressed, as agreed in the Ministerial Declaration signed in Rome on 28 November 2014. Our development aid should also be seen in a regional context. Through regional projects the European Union is linking Eritrea better to the region. Recent developments in Yemen are of particular concern and may have serious implications for the stability of the region and of Eritrea, which is located just across the Red Sea from Yemen. The EU support for the population enables people to be less vulnerable to radicalisation, and EU aid should thus also be seen as contributing to peace and stability in the region. I would be happy to hear your views on EU engagement with Eritrea.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Eritrea is indeed one of the poorest countries in the world. According to the human development index, it is 177th out of 187 countries. Two-thirds of the population is below the poverty line. Although this country is relatively small in african terms, it has somewhere around 6 million inhabitants, about 30% of all applications for political asylum in the European Union are currently coming from Eritrea.  The reason is a systematic violation of human rights, a dictatorship in Eritrea that has been going on too long. Many call Eritrea the largest prison in the world or African North Korea. So where are our priorities, priorities and our development policies? In the 10th European Development Fund, priorities, as you said, were mainly related to food safety, to rural development.  No one doubts that these are important topics and that if our help goes towards the citizens, towards the people of Eritrea, not towards a dictatorial government, then it is justified. However, good governance, the issue of building inclusive institutions and respect for human rights must be embedded in the 11th European Development Fund. Simply, if we want to coordinately lead development foreign and security policy and of course immigration policy, it must also become a priority of our development assistance.  We have no illusions, development aid cannot be and must not be a substitute for foreign and security policy, but together they must work to achieve the goal, and this goal is to make Eritrea for its inhabitants a freer country where human rights will be respected.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Eritrea is indeed a forgotten country on an already forgotten continent; always remains out of the spotlight of our information, of our discussions.  We speak very little about Eritrea, Commissioner, and we have done very little for Eritrea, a country with a high degree of repression – one of the highest in the world – with a bloodthirsty dictator who has been concentrating all the power of the state for more than 20 years and indeed an open prison. That's Eritrea.  But if we talk about Eritrea today is not so much because we are concerned about human rights in Eritrea, but because we have received the warning, the warning that there are many Eritrean citizens who are leaving their country, who are emigrating or seeking asylum or refuge. That's what makes us talk about Eritrea today, that's the truth.  With a fairly small population of six million, in the past year alone, 300,000 Eritreans left their country. Many of these who leave their country are children, they are very young children, they are children of 15, 16, 17 years old. Most of them live in refugee camps and, as you know, there is a very serious problem of human trafficking and organized torture on the Sinai Peninsula. The Commission has announced a possible aid package: three times what has been earmarked so far. It's good news; but the question, Commissioner, is whether we are really going to allocate this aid to the Eritreans or whether we will be able to maintain the status quo of the dictator of Eritrea without helping the citizens. How are we going to know that this money is not going to end up benefiting, as has happened so far, the dictator?  On the other hand, we are not talking about asylum and family reunification, which is something that many citizens do need, those who have been victims of the exodus from Eritrea. Why don't we talk about it anymore and open up our space so that these people can come to have a moderately dignified life?  What I wouldn't want is for it to look like, Commissioner, we're like those rich people who pull check-ups for others to fix the problems.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the I believe that I can sign everything that has been said here, especially what Mrs Valenciano has just said. Again, we mostly deal with the symptoms, in this case in Eritrea. We are, of course, dealing with a corrupt, inhumane and dictatorial regime. I would argue that we should take a closer look at what sanctions we can impose on this country. In particular, I am convinced that we must engage where it really affects these people who are so oppressing this country. That is why we should do everything we can to target the circle of those who have been restricted by travel, the circle of those whose assets we are trying to freeze in the various countries, and the circle of those who send their relatives to elite European and American schools.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner Mimica, Eritrea is one of the signatory countries to the Cotonou Agreement, where the parties are committed to promoting and protecting all fundamental freedoms and human rights.  It has been a country without democratic elections since 1993. Just over a year ago, President Afewerki said without complexes: "If anyone in this country thinks there may be democracy or a multi-party system, let them go to another world to think of such things."  We are talking about a government that permanently uses the state of emergency and which recruits men, women and children to its army in a forced and indefinite manner; arbitrarily arrests and tortures; that restricts freedom of expression, conscience and movement and suppresses religious freedom. A government that provides logistical and financial support to terrorist groups. Do we need more reason to evaluate what we do with Eritrea?  But Eritrea is also Alganesh Fessaha, president of the Italian NGO Gandhi, the doctor who travels through Sudan, Ethiopia and Sinai to work at the origin, from where more than 5,000 Eritreans flee every month to Europe, escaping the Afewerki regime.  Alganesh Fessaha has managed to rescue hundreds of migrants kidnapped in Sinai. Nearly half of the six million Eritreans are under the age of 15, and thousands are the skinny boys with terrible stories behind them in Lampedusa, who eat the "zighini", the dish that reminds them of their land, prepared by the nuns thanks to Alganesh's recipe.  Alganesh Fessaha says that kidnappers call their families in Eritrea so they can hear their screams as they martyr them: they melt plastic into their skin, beat them to death or burn their hair with kerosene," he adds. They demand a ransom that claims it can amount to $45,000: "If you don't pay, we'll sell one of your corneas or a kidney," the traffickers tell their relatives.  So far, Alganesh Fessaha has managed, yes, to free hundreds of them; but hope for establishing a way in which Eritrea not only enters the inclusive governance that Ban Ki-moon has told us about this afternoon, in which Europe may be that locomotive that takes it out of that repression and that lack of respect for human rights, is in our hands.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I would first like to thank all the political groups, who have agreed that this debate should finally be on our agenda. The Khartoum process, launched by the Italian Presidency for its former colonies, aims to revive dialogue and cooperation with Eritrea, Africa's worst dictatorship. Under the eleventh European Development Fund (EDF), a figure of 312 million aid was first published, and then the information disappeared from the Commission's website. The tenth EDF, on the other hand, provided only 122 million, in the end reduced to 52 million due to lack of implementation. What has happened since then, other than the fact that Eritreans are the second most represented nationality among those crossing the Mediterranean to Italy?  According to documents from the SSAE (Social Assistance Service for Emigrants), three migration projects would be funded in Eritrea.  The first would be to strengthen the Eritrean government's capacity to combat human trafficking. Commissioner, this government has just declared that the perpetrators and organisers of this trafficking are human rights activists and Western journalists. Two years ago, it was the CIA. Who are you going to work with, if not with this corrupt government and its affiliates? There is therefore a risk of funding a new wave of repression in a country where the number of journalists imprisoned is no longer counted, half of whom are reported to have died in detention. The second project would build the country's judicial capacity. That's right, we have room. The Constitution has never been implemented and there is not even a penal code. Again, who are you going to work with?  The third project would focus on awareness campaigns. What are you going to fund and, most importantly, with what money? (The President cuts off the speaker's microphone)

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. I believe that we have this debate on Eritrea here today, mainly because Commissioner Mimica spoke to the press in Addis Ababa in March. In doing so, he talked about development cooperation for Eritrea, mentioned an amount that led to surprise, and made the link with the huge number of refugees from the country. I think it would help if the Commissioner clarified the development cooperation plans. In the past, of course, we had the European Development Fund for Eritrea. A large part of this has not been spent because it is impossible to spend money, for example, on large-scale infrastructure works in a country where workers are not working voluntarily, but are, for example, conscripts who actually act as slaves. The money allocated at the time was therefore not spent. I can well imagine that you are now trying again to make funds available for this. But I wonder if you think we'll have spent the money after five years. Finally, if we start to argue our development cooperation goals with the fight against migration, we will never succeed. An economy that is improving will also have more migrants. Why are we doing development cooperation with Eritrea? To break the regime there and give people a better life.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, only nine days ago my colleague, Nathan Gill, stood up in plenary in Strasbourg and said that the developing world needs trade not aid, and this week we have been given a case study that proves precisely that point.  Eritrea, as a state, has a terrible record on freedom of the press and human rights abuses. In fact in 2011 the country refused to grant entry to an independent UN reporter out of fear of what they might find, and only this week the European Union has called on Eritrea’s President to free reporters, bloggers and prisoners alike.  But the benign reality is that the EU suffers from its own hypocrisy and delusion on what development aid might achieve. The EU on one hand condemns dictators, and then gives countries aid. It then wants to tackle migration into Europe, but implements harmful policies. It throws money around without any accountability. And all too often, sanctions are applied that harm the actual innocent and do not deal with the guilty.  Only this week, the African Economic Output Report stated that Eritrea’s GDP has gone up to 2.1%, and that is almost double where it was in 2013. This country is rich and could easily mine gold, iron, copper and nickel – and those are resources that most countries would dream of having available to them. What Eritrea now needs is to be coerced to diversify its economy away from a completely mining-based economy. The people need jobs, they need job security, and most of all, they need an opportunity to escape poverty.  Foreign aid just does not tackle that. We have got to be very careful where we apply this foreign aid and what we ask for it from this country. I do not believe that we are actually taking the right steps towards that goal.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are finally talking about criteria to be met in return for European Union aid. But the whole policy of European cooperation towards Africa – let us be clear about this – is a failure. Eritrea is a striking case. This disbursement of a further three hundred million to Eritrea is not acceptable, when we know that these resources will not serve to improve the living conditions of that people, but more likely to feed some opaque NGOs and, above all, some corrupt sectors of that country's public administration. We call for a thorough check to be carried out, as is the case with all European funds, for which a thorough check is carried out by the monitoring bodies, and this should also be the case for humanitarian aid projects. We must begin to liquidate in the face of a review of the achievement of the objectives and the transparency of the procedures. We must make it clear that we are in danger of paying twice through mass immigration, because it has been said repeatedly that a large proportion of the aid applicants are Eritreans and the injustices that are being committed in these countries have been mentioned.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr When we in This House today debate development aid to Eritrea and highlight the human rights violations committed by the regime, I would like to remind you of a figure: 5 000. This Tuesday, 2 June, 5 000 days have passed since the EU citizen, Dawit Isaak, was arrested and imprisoned in Eritrea. Since 2001, this Swedish-Eritrean journalist has been imprisoned in the most despicable circumstances without trial, without contact with the outside world. Mr President, this is one of the most serious human rights violations with a Swedish connection to date, and it is high time to increase the pressure on the Eritrean dictatorship. Britain and Canada have taken steps to prevent Eritrea's western embassies from enforcing the regime's forced taxation of exiled citizens. Joint action by the EU Member States in this regard could lead to a significant disruption in the flow of money to the dictatorship in Asmara. It would also respond to a direct call from the UN Security Council. Let us therefore work within the EU to stop the illegal tax collection of the Eritrean regime. Let us work together for increased and effective sanctions against the representatives of the dictatorship and let us link the development aid that we are discussing today to clearer demands for compliance with human rights. 5 000 long days have passed since Dawit Isaak was imprisoned. Eritrean prisons are filled with other innocent, other prisoners of conscience. The EU must now respond to this with firm demands and tougher measures against the Regime in Asmara.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since the beginning of 2015, more than 10 000 Eritrean refugees have reached italy's coasts alone. Tens of thousands of people flee Eritrea every year, relying on the hands of unscrupulous traffickers, and die in their thousands on an endless journey. It is difficult to talk about this country and talk about this subject without seeing the faces of the people who, in their thousands, arrive on our shores and unfortunately lifeless.  For more than twenty years, the country's government has been governed by the same power group and there is therefore also an urgent need for alternation with democratic elections. Faced with such a high bloodshed, paid by the Eritrean people right on the borders of our Union, we must support the country's development process. That is why, Mr President, the humanitarian aid that has been given to Eritrea, within the framework of the approach that we have repeatedly defined even within this House, that of being able to intervene in the causes, must break this silence. We must bring the Government of Asmara to the table of dialogue and pacification, returning to the table without taboos, without hiding anything, supporting the country in the process of democratisation and keeping our values and objectives firm. I think it is also very important to be able to accompany the verification of this aid. We have to make sure that they really reach the people and that they benefit the population. First of all, we must ensure that humanitarian organisations are present and working in the country, so that they improve the living conditions of the Eritrean people. Finally, Mr President, we cannot ignore the consequences that the long-growing tension between Eritrea and Ethiopia has had on peace in the region, until we reach us through a sea that has changed into a graveyard. Taking responsibility for protecting and promoting peace sometimes involves the courage to embark on the path of dialogue whenever possible. We must break this silence.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Europe has obligations to Eritrea, a country in a depreable social state under a brutal dictatorship. It has commitments all the stronger because it is a country that has experienced experience – bad experience – colonial. Europeans are more obliged in this situation than otherwise. The free world has at times faced the need to overcome and respond to two phenomena – human rights violations and to help a society in a depply situation. And that is what we should be doing – a firm 'no' to dictatorship, direct assistance to society. This assistance should be monitored as closely as possible. I agree with My Colleague Sargentini, who has called for an assessment of the progress of the aid so far. We should not spend money in a wasteful way. An assessment of what has happened in the previous year should take place. Perseverance and regularity will make us achieve our goals

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to Wikileaks, the ways in which the Eu ropean Union wants to stop migrants fleeing are now clear. I read a passage: 'the use of force must be allowed, especially during embarkation or when operating on land'. At the same time, dictatorships are being economically supported, hoping to stop the exodus, primarily from Eritrea. Last year there were reports of improved human rights in Asmara, relations refuted by the opposition.  Commissioner, please put yourself in the refugee's skin. Reading reports and documents, the fugitive will make the connection. It will be said that Europe either traps them in Libyan camps, or hands them over to the traffickers he claims to fight, or returns them to Isaiah Afewerki. I do not know how you feel, but I do know how the refugees feel, condemned to slam into the walls that Europe has moved south... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Bodil VALERO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Both the Commissioner and my Swedish colleague here have spoken about Dawit Isaak, a Swedish journalist who has been imprisoned in Eritrea since 2001.  5,000 days – that's almost 14 years. 13 years and 246 days today, to be exact. According to Amnesty, he is the only EU citizen currently imprisoned for his views. But neither pressure from the Swedish government nor silent diplomacy has helped to secure Dawit's release. In 2009, President Afwerki stated that he would not hold a trial or release him, and that Sweden was completely irrelevant to him at that time. Then there is the issue of aid. As far as Sweden is to be seen, we do not have any budget support for Eritrea, and now you said that the EU has no budget support either. What does the Commission intend to do to actually ensure that we have an EU citizen released from prison in Eritrea?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Mr President, one of the countries in Africa with which the European Union is trying to strengthen ties is Eritrea. But the government of that country systematically violates human rights. The case of Eritrea is a typical example of the culture of the European Union's foreign policy philosophy. In the name of purposes but also vague, unspecified and controversial interests, we tend to want to upgrade our relations with countries whose governments are not democratic and provocatively violate the principles of democracy. The usual excuse is that these countries have great strategic value for the European Union. Even worse, however, is that we want to integrate some of these countries – Turkey, Skopje, Albania, Kosovo – into the European Union when they do not meet the criteria of the Copenhagen Treaty. All we manage to do with this tactic is to degrade the prestige of the European Union and become political hostages to these states. If we want to upgrade the prestige of the European Union, we must be guardians of the values and principles of the European Union.... (the President interrupts the speaker)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, European development aid must have the objective of reaching the ones most in need, and considering the situation in Eritrea the EU delegation must closely monitor the use of this funding.  It is clear that increasing political dialogue with the government about human rights on the basis of Article 8 of the Cotonou Agreement is needed as well as an increase in direct support to the civil society and human rights defenders. It seems that the UN Commission of Inquiry on Human Rights in Eritrea has had no cooperation from the Eritrean regime and that this commission has not been granted access to the country.  These facts raise concerns about the decision to triple the aid given to Eritrea. There seems to be no evidence of any real change in terms of human rights in Eritrea. The European Commission should halt its implementation of the aid package until the UN Commission of Inquiry on Eritrea has been given access to the country in order to assess the situation.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: – This morning, the Belgian Secretary of State for Asylum reported on Flemish radio that the number of asylum applications from people from Ethiopia and Eritrea has doubled this month compared to May 2014. The terrible human rights situation is the most important factor for their flight. Far too often they die on the way to the Mediterranean. Belgium has a high recognition rate for Eritreans, but it remains the happy few who escape. We need a viable solution for those who remain behind in everyone's interests. This country ranks 181st on the UN Development Index out of a total of 187 countries. I hear, Commissioner, that the dialogue mechanism is being used to improve the situation, but frankly I shudder, I am horrified by this regime. Support for people: yes. Support for this regime: no. I urge people not to deviate from these principles. Development and human rights must go hand in hand.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, I think the Commissioner quite rightly said that isolation seldom helps, but then of course the question is how to engage with a regime that is, by all criteria, one of the most repressive in the world. Add the fact that we are dealing with a country that could easily be listed in the top three most isolated countries, next to North Korea and perhaps Turkmenistan. I think Eritrea would be very high on this list. Perhaps looking for some innovative solutions through development cooperation might be a way forward. I shall just give you an example. An international federation of deaf-disabled people have a project in North Korea to help deaf people there, so there must be some ways of getting entry points in order gradually to convince the government that it would profit from opening up. Lastly, and perhaps this is a question to you, Commissioner, we have the Intergovernmental Authority on Development for the Horn of Africa countries. Is regional cooperation ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Olaf STUGER
text: – The Dutch people are craving tax increases. Every month, these people struggle to make ends meet. Can you imagine how these people feel when they hear that the European Commission is going to transfer EUR 312 million to those in power in Eritrea? Eritrea, one of the most corrupt countries in the world and the country that scores lowest on the press freedom index, is even lower than North Korea. Mr President, how on earth can I explain this to the people of the Netherlands?

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, torture, arbitrary detentions, including that of the Swedish Eritrean citizen David Isaac, since 2001, severe restrictions on freedom of expression, association and religious freedom are routine in Eritrea. There have been no elections since independence in '93. The Constitution has never been enforced and political parties are not allowed. Forced labor and mandatory military service indefinitely also force thousands of Eritrean scanders to flee the country, seeking refuge in Europe, because refugee camps in neighbouring countries often only constitute detention in ininclimate and degrading conditions. To retain Eritreans in their country, the European Commission wants to triple development aid. It is a policy that will fail roundly, because it is impossible to develop if one ignores the fierce repression in which the Eritrean people live, imprisoned by the tyranny of President Isaiah. It is embarrassing the lack of strategic vision of the Commission and the Council, who are willing to negotiate with a dictatorship which absolutely despises the democratic principles, which we supposedly defend, in so way of freeing ourselves from refugees in the Mediterranean. This is a blind plan that will fail and the least is to demand... (The President interrupts the speaker.)

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we should not be surprised, Eritrea is the emblematic example of the objective contradictions in which the European Union's development and cooperation policies are exercised. Why contradiction? Because, on the one hand, we are providing more resources for the country's livelihood, in an attempt to stem the exodus of refugees and to help solve the social problems present, and, on the other hand, we are doing all this in a country where human rights are largely violated. It is difficult to get out of this contradiction, because not providing resources means making the situation of the most needy groups more difficult, but providing it in this situation also means having no guarantee that this money will reach people in difficulty. So what is to be done? We must introduce new constraints into the Commission's proposal, and that must be written down. Firstly, development aid must be accompanied by monitoring of the EU delegation in Eritrea, and together we must call for the immediate opening of the human rights chapter. Only in this context is the decision taken by the European Commission acceptable.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, we need to talk about Eritrea and we need to talk about all of those countries that face corruption and where people are imprisoned, as we have heard from our Swedish colleagues, but we cannot walk away from them. We are caught, if you like, between a rock and a hard place. Ms Hautala had a proposal about how we might intervene in these cases without money being siphoned off in corrupt ways. This morning in this House, we heard from a church leader in Nigeria about how they are dealing with the impact of Boko Haram and how they need aid to help people who have no shelter, no food and no water.  Commissioner, you rightly said that we have to solve these problems, because if we do not we will continue to have migratory flows beyond our capacity to cope. It is in our interests that we tackle these problems on the ground. Even where our policies fail we have to keep trying, and improving the lives of those who are affected so badly. Good luck with the work.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the tensions in Eritrea also affect Europe very closely, which has been forced to deal with the migration crisis in recent weeks. After Syria, we are talking about the second country of origin of migrants, who try to cross the Mediterranean Sea. Most Eritreans have no hope for their future, and detention is a very common experience, which affects a large number of individuals – women, men, boys and even children. This is a very difficult issue which is also denounced by a United Nations investigation, which highlights the many human rights violations committed in Eritrea. According to the UN report, the government has also used tensions with neighbouring countries as a pretext for ignoring respect for human rights and for subjecting every aspect of people's daily lives to military control. The European Union must restart a dialogue with Asmara in order to try to resolve the root issue of migratory flows, but at the same time it must make economic aid conditional on a significant increase in fundamental freedoms in the country.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Eritrea is a champion in Africa in the imprisonment of journalists. It is now a large open prison that oppresses human rights. At the same time, during the Arab Spring, Eritrea limited Internet access. The country has been under a state of emergency for 20 years and its leadership has "written" the Koton agreement "in its old shoes". Malnutrition, poverty and violence against women dominate there, and its citizens leave aron and come as refugees to Greece and the rest of southern Europe. Eritrea must therefore proceed with deep democratic reforms and the building of the rule of law. The European Union's development aid must go to the impoverished people of Eritrea and not to the oligarchs of the regime who must realize that the European Union will stop development aid to Eritrea if they do not immediately cease to violate human rights.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Mr. President, someone compared it very well and said that Eritrea is the North Korea of Africa. The dictatorial regime, disrespect for human rights, everything we know very well that is happening in this African country, rightly asks us to have a very balanced policy.  I think that this is exactly what our Commissioner Mimica showed and said in his opening speech, this balance that goes for not helping the regime and not giving money to the budget of that regime, but helping concrete projects that will allow for such a quality of life in this space and perhaps still allow some people to stay in that country , not to come to the Mediterranean Sea and then the question is where they will end up.  So, I want to express my support for this conception and the Commission's strategy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Mr. President, the situation in Eritrea is ringing alarm bells. She managed to get even North Korea off the top of the list of countries with the highest censorship and media nonfreeness. A country where there is no independent journalism has also become africa's largest and strictest jailer of journalists.  But Eritrea is not only dangerous for journalists. Believers who do not belong to the four religions recognised by the Eritrean Government are also persecuted. People living below the edge of poverty are fearful of unlimited military recruitment and forced labor, constant psychological and physical bullying.  This fear drives 4,000 Eritreans every month to leave their country, and for these reasons the entire football team fled the country in 2013. We cannot talk about development while violating fundamental human rights. Eritreans would rather die trying to escape their own country than stay living in inhuman conditions. Since January, 14,000 Eritrean refugees have arrived in Italy in boats. Therefore, the issue of Eritrea has also become a problem for the European Union and I call on the European Union to start addressing it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I have been calling for some time for the reassessment of development aid, especially to countries that are corrupt, dictatorial or autocratic, and I think Eritrea is a case in point. This is a country that has had the same president since 1991. It has no constitution. It has no independent judiciary. It has no elections. And there is no freedom of the press. In fact, it is ranked last in the Reporters Without Borders index. What is the point in giving development aid to them? You are only propping up the regime that is there. I think that rather than doing that, we should actually be trying to help the refugees in the short term so that at least they can have some quality of life, and then stipulate to countries like Eritrea that development aid is available provided that at least basic human rights are respected.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Eritrea is, of course, a real dilemma for us as a European Union, because on the one hand it is obvious that human rights violations, restrictions on freedom of the press and other democratic rights naturally lead us to really question whether development aid cooperation with such a country makes sense. On the other hand, however, I believe that there is also agreement – as the debate has shown somewhat – that we naturally have a great interest in providing development aid perspectives to the people who have to live there in difficult conditions, so that they have a perspective of staying in their country and not being lured to the Mediterranean by smuggling gangs; we would otherwise have the problem in Europe afterwards. That is why, Commissioner, we must find a balanced response. Surely we cannot just say that we are increasing the development aid budget. On the other hand, as Mr Adaktusson has made clear proposals, we must ensure that the regime that keeps the people there in these circumstances is also clearly told by us that we are taking measures elsewhere to improve the situation.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I agree with Parliament’s concerns about, and condemnations of, the dictatorship and human rights abuses in Eritrea. We should bear in mind the very difficult context we are working in where we face two options: either we suspend all aid programmes; or we engage in better focusing our aid to reach those in most need. We are of the opinion that it is much better to continue to engage with Eritrea through our different instruments. We will of course continue to follow closely the human rights situation in Eritrea. I took good note of your calls and proposals to be taken on board when programming the national indicative programme for Eritrea under the 11th European Development Fund in order to better assess the needs of the people and not the government, and to better address the root causes of migration. We also take due note of proposals on how to better use regional cooperation possibilities and on combining international or European sanctions vis-à-vis the regime in Eritrea. We should never forget that our primary objective is to improve the livelihood of the population and thereby contribute to the stabilisation of Eritrea.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. – The EU has reduced the aid offered to Eritrea from EUR 226 million in 2005 to just EUR 14 million in 2013. Political instability in Eritrea was one of the reasons for the EU's decision to suspend its aid payments in 2011. The EU stands with those who fight for democracy and respect for human rights. As a major international donor, the EU has a duty to address the social and economic exclusion of migrants in their countries of origin in an attempt to stop the current crisis. The number of migrants is increasing; only in the first two months of 2015 the number of migrants arriving in the EU through Italy increased by 43% compared to the same period in 2014.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. – Under one of the most repressive regimes in the world, Eritrean society has been oppressed, tortured and muted for decades. Last year alone 300,000 Eritreans, most of them very young, left the country. Much of them live in refugees in Sudan or Ethiopia, but thousands decide to cross the desert, exposing themselves to the abuse, torture and extortion of traffickers, to try to reach our shores. The country has been out of information and politics for too long. If we discuss this issue today, it is precisely because reality has knocked on our doorstep. Eritreans are the second in number of asylum applications in the EU. In response, the Commission has announced an aid package of EUR 312 million for Eritrea (three times what has been granted in recent years), apparently conditional on the regime 'containing' this flow of refugees. We Socialists are in favour of increasing aid to the population, but it is imperative to ensure that it reaches the ground and has an impact on their real needs. Our external action must be consistent with our values and this requires a minimum commitment to human rights by the Eritrean regime.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I consider universal human rights and democracy to be fundamental values of the Union and fundamental principles and objectives of the Union's external action. I am glad that today, as in the past, we are discussing an urgent case of human rights violations in Eritrea, where serious violations continue to take place. I am concerned that torture, arbitrary imprisonment, strict restrictions on freedom of expression, association and freedom of religion are the reasons why thousands of Eritreans flee the country every year. I believe that only development aid and the development of human rights and democratic principles in this country can stop the oppression that is being perpetrated against the Eritrean people. We certainly agree that we are currently facing the great challenges of the current refugee wave flowing into Europe, with Eritreans making up the second largest group of refugees on boats in the Mediterranean, according to the UN. I myself wonder why Eritreans would flee their homeland when their own regime talks about their own country as a paradise on earth. However, the reality is that refugees are talking about it, that Eritrea is hell on earth, and the main cause of fleeing the country is the repression of all rights and freedoms by the local government.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda are the statements by the Council and the Commission on cyber-attacks against the media – a new level of exposure to network security (2015/2709(RSP)).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to start my intervention today by referring to the address we have heard this afternoon by His Excellency the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Ban Ki-Moon. Surprisingly or not, the UN Secretary-General drew our attention to the growing concerns related to radicalisation, which is very relevant to the discussion we are about to have. It is also remarkable that our debate today takes place almost at the same moment as the UN Security Council is holding an open debate on the protection of journalists in conflict situations. Strong, professional and independent mass media are indispensable for effective democracy, economic growth and development across the globe. As early as 1946, at its very first session, the United Nations General Assembly adopted a resolution affirming that freedom of information is the cornerstone of all freedoms. The European Union, as a union based on democratic values, fully subscribes to this principle – freedom of expression is amongst the fundamental values protected by Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. Nonetheless, it is important to recall that the freedom of expression depends upon the safety of journalists and media professionals. Freedom of expression, both offline and online, and strengthening the independence of the media are long-standing priorities of Latvia. We promote them as a part of our Presidency of the Council of the European Union, and in international organisations. Unfortunately, cyber-attacks, including targeting the media, have become part of modern hybrid warfare and terrorist attacks. Therefore, we need to mobilise all our instruments and combine all our efforts to minimise the risks of such attacks. Today, I will pay particular attention to three specific aspects. First of all, cybersecurity, secondly, combating propaganda and radicalisation, and thirdly, a broader response to hybrid threats. First, in recent years, cybersecurity has become a matter of the highest political priority for the European Union. Given the very prominent role that the media, especially electronic media, play in the daily life of modern society, increasingly often they fall victim to cyber-attacks. Hence, any attack against the media should be seen not only as an attack against a fundamental freedom; depending on the scale and damage caused by such an attack, it may be seen as an attack against critical infrastructure. The Council has already come up with a number of initiatives with the aim of ensuring that the internet is open and secure. More initiatives are in the pipeline. In June 2013 the Council adopted Conclusions on the Cybersecurity Strategy of the European Union where it recognised the need to put in place safeguards and take measures to protect the cyber-domain, in both the civilian and military fields, aiming at developing an EU response to cybersecurity incidents and challenges. The same year, together with the European Parliament, we adopted the Directive on attacks against information systems. This was a very important piece of legislation to respond to the increasing concern about terrorist or politically motivated cyber-attacks against information systems, which form part of the critical infrastructure of Member States or of the Union. This Directive also identifies the trend towards dangerous and recurrent large-scale attacks against such systems or particular functions in the public or private sector. Today we are working on another very important piece of legislation – the proposal for a Directive on network and information security. This Directive will enhance cybersecurity preparedness, capabilities at national level and cooperation between Member States and across the EU. It will also stimulate a culture of risk management in the public and private sector. We are confident that the constructive work on the draft Directive will allow a swift conclusion of the negotiations and a timely adoption. Allow me also to mention briefly the importance of the review of the Internal Security Strategy. The Commission communication of last month on the European Agenda on Security prioritised combating terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime as interlinked priority areas with a strong cross-border dimension. The Council is currently working on defining its immediate priorities on this subject. We look forward to working in close cooperation with the Commission and the European Parliament on concrete measures to be taken with the aim of further shaping this policy area. Secondly, we should not forget that in modern-day hybrid warfare, the media can be both targets and weapons, victims and aggressors. For this reason, the discussion of cyber-attacks against the media goes hand-in-hand with another revived phenomenon – aggressive propaganda specifically targeting fundamental European values. We have been realistic in recognising that legislative work alone will not produce sufficient results. Effective and creative practical preventive and counter-measures that go beyond the necessary legislative minimum are equally important. Today the EU is faced with the reality that the media broadcasting for the European public are no longer there solely to inform, educate and entertain. Some states or organisations increasingly use the media for the achievement of military and political goals, turning against the fundamental common European values, attempting to manipulate public opinion. Today the media are being exploited to spread aggressive anti-European propaganda and to incite hatred. The Council remains fully aware of and concerned by this dangerous phenomenon that poses a threat to European security and public order. Discussions are ongoing as to what effective response mechanisms may be created. The Council recognises the urgent need for further action addressing radicalisation at the EU, national and local levels. Hence, Europol has been tasked to set up an EU Internet Referral Unit to target content promoting terrorism or violent extremism. Thirdly, the existence of complex external threats to the security environment in Europe should not be underestimated. We should therefore strive for better synergies and closer links between internal and external security, aiming at ensuring effectiveness in internal coordination and cooperation in areas such as cyber-defence and strategic communication. Being guided by this logic, on 18 May this year we decided to join our efforts to work on a set of proposals to help counter hybrid threats and foster the resilience of the EU and its Member States. The proposals will address the need for closer intra-EU and international cooperation with the aim of developing greater situational awareness and early-warning mechanisms for countering the hybrid warfare threats in areas such as cyber-defence, strategic communications, border security, energy security, and others. We expect to deliver the results by the end of 2015. I would like to conclude by underlining that today we live in a digital era, where virtual reality is no less real than the real world. For this reason, cyber-attacks should and must be seen to be as dangerous as attacks on real structures. The media increasingly often fall victim to such cyber-attacks, given that they rely on information technology and given the prominent role they play in modern society. Therefore, if the 20th century was marked as an era when the fundamental principles of freedom of expression were written in stone, thus giving the media the platform for development, the 21st  century is marked by the need to effectively respond to the emerging and growing new threats against media freedoms. We must spare no effort to protect our fundamental values in the digital environment. I thank you for your attention, and I look forward to listening to your views.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the cyber-attack carried out on TV5Monde in April was an attack on the values that we hold dear in the European Union: freedom of speech, a free media and our ability to access information. This attack, as you know, was short-lived and did not cause serious harm, but it was very visible and serves as a reminder of the potential for cybercriminals to impact our lives. We need to defend ourselves better against this sort of attack, no matter who is responsible and what their motivation is. The benefits we enjoy from technology need to be protected against criminals and terrorists who want to undermine our values, spread their message or simply steal money. Greater cybersecurity is something we can all contribute to – the European Union, Member States, companies and individuals. From the European Union’s perspective, we are engaged in a wide range of activities to improve cybersecurity. Only a few weeks ago, the Commission published the European Agenda on Security. This document sets out three key transnational threats to be addressed in the security domain: terrorism, organised crime and cybercrime. The attack on TV5 was a cybercrime which tried to glorify terrorism and promote the nihilist message of ISIS, or Da’esh. It is therefore at the heart of what we will prioritise in the coming years. On cybercrime, the Agenda proposes reinforcing the capacity of law enforcement authorities, in particular through the European Cybercrime Centre of Europol. It also proposes to address the obstacles to criminal investigations on cybercrime such as access to evidence. Implementing existing legislation on attacks against information systems will be another priority. To combat terrorism, the Agenda proposes to enhance the role of Europol further, by establishing a European Counter-Terrorism Centre. This will be a secure centre for information exchange among national law enforcement authorities. It will build on the successes of the European Cybercrime Centre. Terrorists are exploiting the Internet to spread their propaganda, radicalise and recruit, communicate, and plan and direct terrorist activity. In response to this worrying trend, the Commission will launch an EU-level forum with the Internet industry. The forum will look at how we can enhance our collective efforts in addressing these issues – both in terms of reducing accessibility to terrorist material and in countering the terrorist narrative online. Europol will also establish an Internet Referral Unit on 1 July to help Member States identify terrorist material online and then refer it to the industry with a view to its swift removal.
