Cooperation with the private sector is of critical importance, with public-private partnerships to structure a common effort to fight online crime. In the first half of 2016 the Commission will propose establishing a public-private partnership on cybersecurity in the area of technologies and solutions for online network security. I would like to highlight the fact that the European Union has already done a lot to address cybersecurity. I have already mentioned the European Cybercrime Centre, which was established within Europol in 2013. It acts as a focal point in the European Union’s fight against cybercrime. In 2013 the European Union adopted a cybersecurity strategy. It aims to strengthen cyber resilience, reduce cybercrime and advance international cyberspace policy. Finally, the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA) also contributes to the European Union’s response to cyber-security issues. It works towards a high level of network and information security. Both terrorism and cybercrime are dynamic areas that require us to adjust our responses to stay ahead of the perpetrators. I have made clear that these are priority issues for the Commission. I will be working to ensure that there is an effective contribution at European level to protect our societies and economies from these challenges.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has Today's debate on the attacks on the French TV5 channel makes us all think. We have now heard a great deal from the Commission and the Council on cybercrime and cyberattacks, and I think I can say, Minister, that I am somewhat surprised at the positive words you have said about the council's contribution, which– admittedly in a difficult situation in which you are in the Presidency of the Council – has been making the efforts that have been going on here for years at European level. , unfortunately, has not taken a significant step forward in the last nine months of our trialogue negotiations. These incidents, which we are discussing today – be it TV5, or even a few days later the cyberattack against the Belgian newspaper Le Soir – show that if we in the European Union were finally to succeed in increasing the resilience of the critical infrastructure, we would no longer see such incidents to the extent that we see today. Unfortunately, in the European Union, in the continent of 500 million citizens, we still have a large number of companies, of infrastructures, which are more or less unprepared to react to such incidents. This cannot be a portable condition in the long run. I believe that I can once again urge you, including on behalf of the whole House, to make it clearer in the trialogue negotiations that we need to move faster with this legislative instrument. It is simply not possible to explain in public why we have been negotiating for months and, in the end, we have had to complain about other incidents that we could have avoided if the legislation had now come quickly. That is why it is very clear today that, of course, in the end, the European Union will only be as strong as the weakest of its parts in the area of cyber defence, whether it is cybercrime or cyberper attacks, and that is why there is a need for a European regulation, which we urgently want under the Latvian Presidency.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has This regrettable cyber attack has once again made it clear to us what threats to freedom of information are possible. No one knows when and where similar attacks will happen next. The self-proclaimed Islamist cybercaliphate, which proudly claims to have carried out the attack, has previously hacked the US military and the Twitter account of US news magazine Newsweek. Cyberattacks are increasingly being used as a means of warfare – in a wide variety of places and by a wide variety of actors. But the cyber-caliphs are primarily concerned with something very fundamental, namely to hit Western culture at its most important point, freedom of expression. This was deliberately used in the hope of forcing us to relinquish a piece of freedom of expression. When the media change their work because they are afraid of being victims of terrorist acts, it threatens our democratic society. Another self-evident thing to be said is that we should be aware that the Internet is not the cause of terror; rather, it is being instrumentalized. We could have the safest Internet in the world – there will still be attacks. But there are many ways to create the greatest possible level of security. There have been significant activities since 2013, and Parliament has seen itself as a pioneer of such measures. Unfortunately, there is often a lack of coherence, with too many actors pulling different strands. Cybersecurity should not be blocked by national egoisms. We must therefore make every effort to ensure that the important issue of cybersecurity does not get stuck in the opaque labyrinth of the EU institutions. That is why we finally need a legal basis.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Indeed, cyberspace is a bad thing for Islamic terrorists, but I will also recall the attacks by Russian-led hackers. This was the case in Latvia, it was in Estonia, so it was also in my country – Poland. It is therefore a plane of activity, either by some countries with imperial ambitions or by terrorists. The European Union must act decisively on this issue. We must act quickly. I agree with these remarks that this is too slow. We must feel that these attacks can be more and more and that entire systems not only in the sense of the media, but state systems can be paralyzed as a result of such attacks. Thank you very much.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the ALDE Group fully supports free and open media, and that is why we must do more to protect them from cyber-attacks. Cyber-attacks on the media come in two forms: one on the information shared with the public, and the other on the actual sources of journalism information. Both endanger our trust in a free media. On the public side, in only a few years what was a game for hackers, vandalising media websites and Twitter accounts has been transformed into tools of misinformation and panic-mongering. False information placed on Twitter has already led to panics on the stock market. Cyber-attacks on the media have been used in warfare to cut off information to citizens: such attacks go all the way back to the war in Georgia. And now hacked broadcasts are being used as propaganda for terrorist organisations. On the other side, journalists’ email accounts and networks are being hacked. The identities of whistle-blowers and anonymous sources are becoming known. These cyber-attacks come not only from criminal organisations but also from the misuse of government resources. Without better protection, this will have a chilling effect on investigative journalism. As cases like ‘LuxLeaks’ have shown, we need strong investigative journalism in order to keep our businesses and governments straight. As our citizens move online for all their information and the rate of information exchange keeps increasing, we must find ways to help our media organisations adapt to the new threats facing them. Freedom of the press today must mean more than the right to print what you believe: it must also mean that your readers’ trust will not be abused by hackers or criminals.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, we should agree that we are not just talking about 'cyber-somethings', but call things by their name: the threat to computer and IT security from attacks on critical infrastructures such as the media, the Belgian newspaper Le Soir, the French broadcaster TV5, there have been hacking attacks on the Bundestag, on numerous companies, data theft, espionage – whatever you want – attacks that criminals and the secret services of all continents are equally enthusiastic about. Hacker attacks happen all the time and are directed against anything that is somehow interesting. They are cheap, they are simple and are suitable for pushing others into the shoes of others. Still others draw attention to gaps in the software and to grievances from which we very often profit as politicians – as so-called whiteheads, with whom we are dealing here, who move in the throng of countless blackheads who do their mischief. I think I have to say that we do not want to criminalise these people. I say to you: we need a whole new level of protection for IT security – everywhere. To this day, the Council and the Commission are pushing for standardisation bodies, binding minimum standards, reporting requirements, partly because the state and secret services are increasingly extending their octopus arms to data. We don't need to reinvent anything. We have a directive. We have had the Moraes report for a year, and we are calling for greater independence for the EU institutions and, by the way, for the European IT industry.  It really has to stop intelligence agencies lowering security standards, having their own backdoors in software, and demonizing encryption by security agencies. We demand the use of free and open source software everywhere and more money for research and innovation, not a reduction in Horizon 2020. We require encryption technologies. So I ask you to do, do, do, do, do! Don't talk today and talk about the next attack tomorrow, but actually start something!

name: Julia REDA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the recent attacks against the IT system of TV5 are not the first of their kind. They are part of an ongoing threat to the free press, but there is still a lack of an open analysis of how we can make our media more resilient. As part of this analysis, European governments need to ask themselves whether their own actions are part of the problem. Europe is still exporting surveillance software that has been used to suppress journalists in Bahrain and Morocco. European governments are participating in the sale of unknown security holes in software instead of reporting them publicly and making sure that they are fixed. That leaves software vulnerabilities that are also used in domestic media. Legislation by Member States against so-called hacker tools criminalises the study of these tools, which is a vital part of proper IT security training. After the TV5 attack, the Commission was quick to highlight the ongoing negotiations on the Directive on Network and Information Security as a response, including its possible extension. I would like to ask how we can come to an agreement on this directive and whether it needs to be extended in relation to some of the topics I have just mentioned. What we need is a clear commitment to a reliable and trustworthy IT infrastructure policy, one that does not trade in short-term gains for secret services at the cost of the security of everybody else. If you want to protect the free press, then fight the introduction of government-mandated backdoors that can also be used by criminals, promote the use of open source software for all security-sensitive applications, present us with a legislative proposal for whistleblower protection and provide access to easy-to-use encryption technology for everybody, including journalists. Then, perhaps, one day even the European Parliament will manage to allow its Members to encrypt their emails. I, for one, have not given up hope on that.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking about cyberattacks and Internet security. It is a fact that much of our daily lives, as well as our social and economic activity, are based on the Internet. The ability of some to take ownership, remove and distort data is motivated in the vast majority of cases by financial incentives but, to a large extent, also by political and personal. This is a terrifying reality. Attacks on the media are, I think, the least dangerous compared to other possible scenarios. But we must not be consumed with accusations about which country supports such attacks. The truth is that all major powers, whether east or west, use all the means at their disposal, including cyberattacks. It is at least hypocritical to claim that only Russia or China are responsible and not to recognise the fact that the United States of America and some countries of the European Union have exactly the same strategy. I don't think there's any hope that all countries will agree to stop this practice, so I guess we have to learn to live and defend ourselves through it................. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Axel VOSS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is a good thing that you are addressing this issue with conceptual ideas today. We have espionage, sabotage, data theft, which affects every second company today, according to a study by Bitkom. This is an alarming result, and Der Spiegel also writes this week that in the US, a hacker in an ordinary passenger plane has connected his notebook to the box that controls the entertainment program, thereby pushing the engines. In other words, the security authorities are sounding the alarm and fearing further such dramatic attacks, and the attack on TV5 is basically going in the same direction. All these examples are now dramatic, unsettling, frightening and present us with new challenges. The digitization of infrastructure, economic value chains, and the world of life not only opens up opportunities, but also poses risks. The cyberattacks are ubiquitous, encompassing all areas of life and can have similar effects as attacks with weapons and lead to corresponding collateral damage. But here crime, belligerent terrorist attacks reach dimensions that expect completely new answers. How do we really want to ensure our security in Europe? We are not good enough in terms of security policy here. We should not underestimate this power of cyberattacks: we need a new defense that secures our foundations. Cybersecurity requires concerted action by business, politics, and society at all levels. I am convinced that we need more measures than just the NIS directive. It is important that we act quickly. We are lagging behind technology and the hackers. We need something like security by design or security by default.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, cyber-attacks are certainly one of the greatest security challenges facing the international community in the twenty-first century and are a powerful geopolitical weapon at the service of new possible forms of war, far removed from those to which we have unfortunately been accustomed, but no less dangerous. They are increasingly threatening our fundamental rights and our way of life.  Unfortunately, there is a huge gap between a security system, based essentially on national strategies and borders, and the globality of the network and its threats, which are becoming less and less random and increasingly the work of professionals behind whom criminal organisations and even governments are hiding. We must therefore move from declarations of principle by European leaders to concrete commitments in the definition of coherent and effective legislation. A striking example of the gap between words and deeds is the ongoing trialogues relating to the directive on the security of computer networks. The Commission's proposal, significantly strengthened by the European Parliament at first reading, is certainly a first step towards the creation of a common European strategy, providing for significant forms of operational cooperation and prevention and rapid response mechanisms, thus ensuring a resilient European network. Unfortunately, the adoption of this directive, despite the Efforts of the European Parliament in seeking a compromise, is currently threatened by the attitude of the majority of Member States, which are obviously still too jealous of their competences in the field of security and so short-sighted that they do not focus on the new global nature of cyber threats. Only with common European strategies, effectively coordinated at international level, will we be able to combat this new form of war in order to guarantee an open and secure digital space and to take full advantage of the opportunities offered by the Internet and technologies, without compromising freedoms and without affecting our habits.

name: Dawid Bohdan JACKIEWICZ
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In its Resolution of November 2012 on cybersecurity, the European Parliament called on the Commission and the Council to explicitly recognise digital freedoms as fundamental rights and as necessary conditions for the exercise of universal human rights. Parliament also stressed that Member States should aim to never threaten the rights and freedoms of their citizens when developing responses to cyber threats and attacks.  Unfortunately, cyberattacks are increasingly becoming a tool of political struggle. Access to the media means access to information, and information is today one of the most important, if not the main, good that determines the achievement of objectives not only in the social but also economic and political spheres. More than two and a half years have passed since this resolution. I would like to ask what progress the Council and the Commission are telling us today in the fight against cyber-attacks? Is the European Union able to create a programme of sanctions for cyberespionage, as the United States has done, for example? Ladies and gentlemen, without concrete solutions, we are not in a position to deal with this problem. The resolution alone is not enough. In calling for more action in this area, I ask and at the same time stress that Parliament must uphold citizens' rights. Thank you very much.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Madam President, information is power in a digital age, and we are at a stage where we are not really being proactive and we are not moving forward. The NIS Directive (Network and Information Security Directive) is stalling. We had problems with the Italians, now we have problems with the Latvians. Let us get on our bikes and do something and get this directive done. We need it and we need to get on the offensive. We cannot just be defending Europe, we need to have an offensive division too that can strike back at our attackers. They are out there. They are attacking. They are doing damage. They are killing the freedom of information. They are killing us! Let us really focus and do it, and all unite together and get this NIS Directive done. We do not have the luxury to wait anymore. We need to get things done in Europe, and cybersecurity is very important. I would say that it is the same as terrorism. We have had some attacks. We will have some cyber-attacks, and that is terrorism. Let us all unite and let us bring Europe forward to the light.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, my absolute condemnation of cyberterrorism and my solidarity with the French and Belgian media attacked by supporters of the so-called Islamic State.  Unfortunately, these attacks are nothing new. In my country, several media outlets were attacked for weeks by neo-Nazi terrorists. I know that the police are investigating this case and even that anonymous hackers are helping in the pursuit of these cyberterrorists.  But what I'm flake about is this unheard-of relevance: I don't know who wants to pick up some of this state of alarm. I hope you don't go in the direction of attacking our freedoms. For what reason? Because we are still awaiting some detention, criminal responsibilities or guarantees of non-repetition for espionage to millions of European citizens and even to our governments. Espionage carried out in the heat of exception laws, such as the Patriot Act of the United States, and with the complicity of Member States of the European Union.  The spying programs of the US National Security Agency or the UK Communications Headquarters threaten us all because these agencies are out of the law, outside the rule of law, out of democracy and I'm more afraid than cyberterrorists. You know why? Because in the name of our protection they end up with the same freedoms that cyber-terrorists seek to destroy.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Unfortunately, the Commission's report was one big gibberish. The only specifics That I heard were very worrying – namely, that some restrictions must be lifted. I understand that this is about further expanding the police state so that it can violate the privacy of homes, the privacy of apartments and businesses.  Americans, Chinese, Russians know how to conduct politics in cyberspace. The question is, can we? If we can, we have to do it. If we can not, it is not worth talking about, because it resembles the advice of an impotent, how to prevent unwanted pregnancy. Thank you for your attention.

name: József NAGY
text: – The Internet is one of the most important strategic tools of modern society and has been under increasing threat over the last ten years. Not only is the public administration and the economy at risk, but people's privacy is also closely linked to the security of data transmission. Relationship security and the loss of credibility of content can also lead to social destabilisation, and it is only a matter of time. Why are we afraid that citizens will not understand our decisive action? Think of the Internet or Mobile Banking. A loss of confidence could crippling the economy overnight. You may be at risk from contact on social networks, but also with your purchased music stored on cloud services or even your family photos. This is quite understandable to the public.  Today, without a network connection, the subway does not move, trains and even planes do not take off. In connection with today's air traffic black-out in Belgium, everyone thought it was some kind of cyberattack. Moreover, colleagues have noticed today that it is becoming increasingly difficult to access the Internet throughout parliament. The cyberattack on French TV5 only highlighted the vulnerability of the Internet world. Last year, the attacks cost €340 billion and increased by 25% in one year. According to the report of the Global Economic Forum, the lack of adequate defence systems is one of the biggest problems for the global economy.  Manipulation of fake content and information is also a challenge. We need to strike a balance between freedom of speech and privacy and the pursuit of cybercrime. And more importantly, and from what we perceive little, cybercriminals must be spectacularly punished.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, the increase in cyber-attacks against media outlets demonstrates how the tentacles of terrorism and other serious crime go far beyond what we have traditionally understood by armed attack and terrorist act. They also show how imperative and urgent it is to bridge the gap between internal security and external security. This depends on the security of our citizens, critical infrastructure, the ability of governments and public and private services to operate without any problems. This depends on all kinds of computernetworks on which today the functioning of society is based. Targeting the free press with cyber attacks, come from those who come, as seen in the case of French TV5, is an attempt to gag. These attacks are therefore not only against journalists and news organizations. They are attacks against our societies, against democracy, against freedom. Cyberterrorism is increasingly sophisticated, cheaper and easier to execute. We are not prepared in the European Union! We need to recognise this, and that here, as in other areas of European security, Member States recognise that it is imperative to work together, with and under the guidance of the European Union and the High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy. They need to design a consistent, coherent and systematic strategy to prevent and disarm the cyber threat which is, by its nature, offensive and borderless. That is why the answers that are demanded and in which we have to invest, resolutely, are in the technological, political, legal and defence terms. The European Agenda on Security, presented weeks ago, must provide the framework for coherence and effectiveness of related instruments and strategies: from the outset the European Cybersecurity Strategy, the Information Network Security Directive, the Cyber Defence Framework Policy. But without recognizing that we have a shared interest, we will be increasingly at the mercy of terrorists and cybercriminals.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: – Madam President, we do not have only physical nature in the 21st century, we also have a digital or virtual nature. Therefore, every pillar of our life, security and freedoms has a cyber nature as well. If this happens in our lives as individuals, it also happens for companies or for the public authorities. Cyberattack is strategic, and in the case of the media it is key to our democracy because they are, of course, a critical structure, and this applies both in terms of common crimes and crimes of an ideological nature, especially in the case of identity or religious fanatics. It is especially crucial in the face of terrorist strategies, as we talked about today.  Cyberattack, in any case, is global and the geostrategic board forces us to do the prevention and pursuit work well.  But it is imperative to keep proportionality on individual freedoms in the fight against these crimes and attacks. If there's a challenge in the 21st century, it's this one. Nor can we willingly exceed the limits that the public authorities must and can set and which they must set with surgical precision. You, all of us, are going to involve and involve intelligence experts, engineers, governments, but are we going to involve philosophers, sociologists, historians or jurists so intensely?  The expanded strategic debate is as key as the same reaction or action in the short term: without it, we will be unbalanced an absolutely crucial situation.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: Madam President, as my colleagues have already said, the French-language media outlet TV5 Monde was the victim of a very large-scale cyber attack almost two months ago. Terrorists have taken control of the TV station and its social networks. Although this attack did not cause any human casualties, its seriousness is not to be underestimated as it has undermined the fundamental principles and values of our democracy. It demonstrated the ability of terrorists to act on the Internet and their disconcerting ability to spread their speeches relentlessly in the media and social networks.  Cybercrime is an ever-evolving phenomenon that is very difficult to understand at national level alone, which is why it is essential at European level to strengthen the fight against the use of the internet by criminals and terrorists, on the ground of prevention and detection as well as prosecutions. This requires better exchange of information and pooling the capacity of police services, which requires more trust and responsibility between Member States. It also means in-depth cooperation between judicial authorities, which requires better transnational access to evidence and information, as well as the guarantee of legal protection for whistleblowers who help prevent and detect threats on the web. If cybersecurity is a defensive response to cybercrime, we need to develop a more proactive approach. By their cyberattack, terrorists are undermining our right to information and our freedom of expression and flooding the web with their hate ideology. Let's stop them from taking action by strengthening our online security! (The President cuts off the speaker's microphone)

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: – Madam President, we have been witnessing a serious and worrying trend lately. The speed at which new applications appear on our mobile devices is inversely proportional to the speed at which the European Union is legislation on many important topics. Once again, a key dossier such as the Network and Information Security Directive has been delayed in discussions in the Council, although the European Parliament adopted its first opinion on it in its previous mandate. In Brussels, and not only do everyone know that the digital economy is a priority for both the European Commission and Parliament. The benefits of the digital single market, however, are rendered meaningless in the context of an uncertain internet space. There is a theme that comes before the economy and growth. This is the theme of our security, an issue on which we must work together more than ever and be concrete and decisive. The new network security legislation will increase the level of protection on the internet, enhancing cooperation between different Member States of the European Union. We cannot allow ourselves to become the target of attacks, whether online or offline. Our security is a global problem that does not affect citizens, businesses and institutions of only one country. Security in Europe depends on all of us and it is only possible if we deliberately join forces in this area. For this reason, the speed at which we make decisions and operate is of great importance. It is even more important to think preventively, to prevent future cases of cyberespionage, cyber attack and possible cyber warfare.  This is the only way we can protect our citizens, our businesses and societies as a whole.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Of course, I share these views on negative judgment, behaviour itself, attacks and so on. All that remains is the question. Two and a half years ago, as Mr Jackiewicz said, we adopted the relevant declarations in this regard. What is the state of their implementation? I am aware that crime in various forms has always been and always accompanied humanity. Methods have changed, technologies have changed. We are at such a moment that we want to protect human rights. Only one of the human rights is the right to feel protected, and we must therefore make it clear what the state of implementation of this resolution is, what measures we will take to make the calculation clear to potential next offenders – the risk is very high. Discoverability? Almost certain that it will seem. Three – that the consequences will finally be suffered. And these are the key issues. Thank you.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I have listened carefully to the whole debate here, and I must say that together, as a representative of my political faction, My colleague Schwab, who spoke for our faction, I am not satisfied with the way the Commission and the European Council approach this issue, it seems to me that these are many words, many sentences, but few acts.  Cyberattacks are here, they're on the rise, they're causing enormous economic damage. Now they are touching the media too, they are threatening freedom of speech, and we are not just going to make do with platitudes, plans and, say, the thesis. There must be concrete actions and concrete steps.  I dealt with this security when I was a member of the Czech Government, and I have to say that, for example, the Czech Republic is very prepared for cyber attacks in this matter. In recent days, we are launching a special laboratory in Brno, which has just been provided by both the state on one side and the local university, and we will simulate individual cyber attacks here and we want to be ready for them. I believe that the main thing is to strengthen the resilience of critical infrastructure, prevention is, in my view, the main thing. Of course, it is possible to talk about what the Commissioner was talking about, i.e. strengthening repression in the form of increasing money, strengthening Europol's powers, but it should not slip to the police state, i.e. the police state. Let us strengthen Europol, but it cannot be at the expense of the rights of our citizens.  Like I said, I think repression can play a role, but it's not key. Prevention is key, and here we really have a lot of catching up to do, we are not ready for this as Europe, and it is now up to the Commission and, of course, the Council to be very active in this matter, to start talking to each other, to work together, so that each country has a clear body that monitors cybersecurity. Of course, legislation that is still on the table must also be finalise.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the digital society and the Internet are the backbone of our society – the opposite cannot be said today – and they are above all instruments for guaranteeing freedom and also prosperity. The recent attacks on TV5Monde, as well as other media, carried out by the so-called Islamic State fully demonstrate how clearly our computer systems are vulnerable. Madam President, it is unacceptable that the cybersecurity directive – as well as so many other directives, unfortunately – should still be blocked in the Council, due to the fact that the Member States cannot agree. Terrorist threats, however serious they may be, cannot be an excuse to restrict the freedom of our citizens and to restrict the fundamental rights of our citizens and the media.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Commissioner, first of all, I would like to say on behalf of our PPE faction that I completely condemn the cyber attacks on the media that have happened in recent months. Whether it was an attack on French TV5 or the Belgian newspaper Le Soir. Cybercrime is a threat to every country, every business and every citizen, because its consequences are unpredictable. It is increasingly becoming clear that the EU is not adequately protected against such attacks and is not prepared to defend itself against them. These attacks could come anytime, anywhere. It is not possible that we are not able to ensure a high level of security of our most important networks, such as transport, energy or health care, where there is a plethora of private and state-owned enterprise data. The main thing we currently lack is connectivity and close cooperation at EU Member State level.  Yes, Commissioner, in 2013 we set up a cyberattack centre at Europol in The Hague. I personally had the opportunity to visit him. But we have to say that we have not given him sufficient financial cover, i.e. he does not have enough funds, and we should change this situation as soon as possible. I would therefore like to call on the Member States, in particular, to help, to cooperate on a common infrastructure, and to the European Commission to try to prepare networks and authorities against attacks from the outside.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, thank you for the minute granted, however much it may not affect the full range of issues. I would allow myself to focus on only one aspect, and that is the issue of fundamental rights and freedoms.  We admire the development of digital infrastructure in America, the US is to some extent an example to us, but I think it is also an example in that not very happy way, i.e. in their monitoring process and, to some extent, breaking into fundamental rights and freedoms. We should say that this is not a path for the EU and for our citizens. I would very much like to see any solutions promoted by the EU not so much susceptible to breaking into fundamental rights and freedoms. I think that this is a limit that we really cannot go for, and I would very much like it to be made clear here, as has been said by my colleagues.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a large part of our lives are now on the Internet, both private and professional. The protection of the data network on the network must be adapted to the importance of all this, to the importance of the information involved. The possibility or threat of a Big Brother watching us, or rather spying on us, could compromise all the opportunities that the network contains as a great resource. Cybercrime affects us with the same violence as traditional crime and also puts our lives in danger at times. Attacks on the media are doubly serious because they undermine freedom of expression, but above all the right to information and therefore to knowledge. Increasingly, cyberattacks are aimed at our security, sometimes they manage to paralyse state apparatuses, they are the new frontier of terrorism. Our IT systems are vulnerable, but the Cyberterrorism Directive is still blocked. The European Union must protect us.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Commissioner, the cyber attack on the French channel 'TV5 Monde' shows that attacks on the media are dangerously peaking and must be combated. Because this attack is an attack on freedom of the press; it is an attack on democracy itself. It was a jihadist attack, this time on cyberspace. For this reason, the European Union's cyber security strategy must be made more effective and effective. This requires close cooperation between the Member States and the Commission. But we should not fall into the trap of jihadists aiming to restrict the freedom of movement of ideas. For this reason, the Internet must be and remain open and free. And so, in the name of cybersecurity, freedom in cyberspace and the fundamental rights of citizens and users should not be restricted.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, in one previous speech I called on the Commission to declare internet freedom, for the digital society to be declared in some way europe's fifth freedom. However, every freedom, including that freedom, should have its own protection.  So, and this fifth internet freedom that I advocate at the level of the European Union and I am even advocating this freedom and the creation of our new age, the digital age is something that is ahead of us, that is our life, but it also seeks proper protection, because we can talk today about a kind of cyber terrorism. Every terrorism should in some way have that lever of defending against such a single terrorism, and especially when we talk about this situation about press freedom, about what is in some way pivotal in our freedoms in Europe and in the values of our European Union. So the answer to the war must be very clear.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). – There is no doubt that cyber attacks pose a very great threat to both independence and freedom of the press. For this reason, they must both be condemned and dealt with appropriately. But this modern threat, whose success is based on the achievements of technology, not only threatens the press, it threatens other structures much larger in value. And I am referring to the state itself. Try to imagine what problems would have arisen if the attack on the TV station TV5 had manifested itself with the same success against the security, defence and operation structures of the state and private enterprises. We must therefore analyse and address this risk. We must be careful though, because our approach to guaranteeing cyber security must not go against individual freedoms, human rights and independence.... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, the attack on French TV Channel TV5Monde on Wednesday, 8 April highlighted Europe’s vulnerability to high—tech cyber criminality. I believe that these attacks signal a new level of threat to western media as well as civil and military networks, and we cannot find the EU unprepared. We must focus on securing key EU networks – transportation, energy, financial or healthcare networks. We must achieve cyber resilience as well as a common high level of security. I support options such as requirements for EU countries to provide national NIS strategies and for the constitution of agencies to facilitate cross-border cooperation at EU level. I hope that soon I will hear from the Commission and from the Council about how they intend to implement cyber-security strategy.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, attacks on the media are not entirely new events. They are often politically motivated, target highly visible victims in order to maximise the reputation of the perpetrators and are part of a generally vast and extremely complex geopolitical context. Recent studies of cyber threats have shown that the media is one of the sectors most attacked. The recent attack on TV5Monde by hackers linked to ISIS, as well as representing a serious attack on the foundations of our democracy, is very alarming and should not be underestimated simply because it did not result in casualties. This unprecedented attack has raised the risk in cybersecurity to new levels of severity. The new scope and breadth that attacks can reach as a direct consequence of the growing dependence of technology-related sectors and connectivity should make us reflect. It is therefore essential that, over and above the NIS Directive, the European Union's cybersecurity strategy and the European Security Agenda, digital single market should also be conceived and implemented with a 'Security by design' approach... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – Recently, we have seen many cases where cyber-erors obsessed with the desire to sow doom are hacking into multinational firms, stealing personal information about employees, stealing corporate secrets and, worst of all, even threatening them. Personally, I consider this to be a crime, and I therefore support all the measures and actions of stakeholders at both European Union and Member State level that are directed against these cyberattacks. Cyberattacks against the media are a new threat, which is why we need to act very quickly, reassfully, and also because they are on an upward trend. Cyberattacks must also worry us because they are increasing, and not only in frequency and scale, but also in their sophistication and intensity of action. I am very glad that Latvia, as the country president, has also made this a priority for its Presidency, and I believe that other states will also follow in these priorities.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to express my thanks for the invitation to come here tonight to share our points of view on a very sensitive issue. As I said at the beginning – and allow me to repeat it – terrorists’ use of the Internet constitutes for us in the Commission a very important issue and it is very high among our priorities. As you know, it has been highlighted in the European Agenda on Security. I do not have anything to add tonight. I am looking forward to meeting with you again to discuss the same issue as soon as we have implemented the actions foreseen in our agenda. As you know, we have already started working very hard on that.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for this very important and very lively debate. As I have already mentioned in my opening remarks, cyber-attacks, including those targeting media, are an increasingly worrying trend. The growing sophistication of cyber-attacks and cyber threats around the world, and their use as an element of hybrid warfare and terrorist attacks, oblige us to stand on high alert and continue working to improve our capabilities to tackle this threat. We should continue to invest our efforts in guaranteeing the implementation of the existing tools and the full use of the EU initiatives dedicated to the fight against cyber threats. We should also continue and intensify work to provide for new and more comprehensive responses to the constantly evolving challenges posed by this threat. The Council remains fully committed to work constructively towards the adoption and effective implementation of concrete measures in that respect. Mr Schwab and some other honourable Members have reminded us of the importance of reaching an agreement on the Directive on Network and Information Security. Today the Presidency and the European Parliament received key input from the Commission on its recommendations for the most challenging issues in the directive, regarding its scope and several aspects of implementation, that will be instrumental in making the last remaining strides towards a compromise between the Council and Parliament. With this directive the EU is going into unchartered territory in attempting to make our new digital lives more safe and secure. This is, admittedly, not an easy process, as developing legislation on a highly technical issue that touches at the same time on national security is no easy task. The Latvian Presidency continues and will continue to work to make significant progress on this issue by the end of June. We are confident that the good spirit of cooperation which prevails will allow us to reach a timely conclusion of the negotiations on the Directive on Network and Information Security in order to provide the EU and its Member States with an instrument to improve its preparedness and capabilities for action in case of cyber-attacks. At the same time, regulation of such innovative sectors must be achieved in a prudent and balanced manner in order to avoid placing an unnecessary burden on an industry that is creating growth and jobs. We shall also continue our efforts towards introducing effective and creative practical, preventive and control measures that will go beyond the necessary legislative minimum. Strategic communication, countering propaganda, and international cooperation are on our list of priorities. At the same time, despite this late hour, I would like to recall the root cause of such attacks targeting independent and professional media. Dramatic changes in the media landscape, in particular the introduction of new technologies, have resulted in an unprecedented flow of information. Despite draconian measures, neither totalitarian regimes nor terrorists are able to firmly close the tap and fully prevent the information flow. Journalists’ independent voices and reports give the international community a unique insight into realities on the ground, including in conflict zones. It is thanks to journalists’ courage that the world is aware of what happened in Chernobyl, Chechnya, Libya, Rwanda and Srebrenica and what is happening in North Korea, Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria and Ukraine. The media serve as a catalyst for a rapid and effective global response, and thus they are vital to the survival of a democratic society. It is for this reason that all of our activities aimed at improving security, resilience and capabilities should go hand-in-hand with activities aimed at safeguarding and reinforcing the ability of the media to provide independent and reliable information.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – Living in the digital era entails not only information sharing at increased speed but also more favourable conditions for cyber—hackers to find various security shortcomings. Therefore, taking into account the increasing incidence of cyber-attacks against Western media agencies in recent years – including attacks carried out by ISIS and by the Syrian regime, and a number of undisclosed attacks – efforts to step up cybersecurity are needed. Cyber-attacks pose an imminent threat and can take many forms: interrupted news flows, the distortion of media information for terrorist purposes, the leaking of sensitive personal data such as the identities of whistle-blowers, etcetera. Such attacks are extremely dangerous, especially at times when critical coverage of events is required. They are an aspect of information warfare, with the aim of distorting facts and fuelling an unwanted response to the originally intended media communication; and, in turn, they endanger the security of states and their citizens. I believe that a new cybersecurity directive is extremely timely. We need to make sure that, at least, a minimum level of security is guaranteed in sectors of critical importance, such as media, health, banks and transport, and to ensure that these sectors step up their security cooperation with the European agencies.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. – Recently, there have been several cyberattacks on the media, such as the French TV5 Monde and the Belgian daily Le Soir. At one point, around 150 000 different malware spreads through the Internet, infecting more than 1 million users every day, despite cyber threats becoming increasingly dangerous and threatening order and the rule of law in the Member States of the European Union, and for the period between 2007 and 2013 the European Commission allocated EUR 350 million to cyber research. However, for the 2013-2020 follow-up period, it added only EUR 50 million to this amount, which several experts consider insufficient, even as other major powers are massively increasing these funds.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, cyber-attacks on the media pose a new threat to cybersecurity because they are aimed at generating terror and thus threaten one of the fundamental institutions of democracy. These attacks reveal the brutal truth that no one is safe today. They prove that terrorism and cybercrime can have disastrous consequences that have a direct impact on citizens. In an instant, the Internet distributes about 150,000 viruses that infect the hardware and software of more than 1 million users every day. Recent attacks on French TV5 Monde and Belgian daily Le Soir only confirm concerns about the ease with which the attacks are carried out. We live today in a digital age where virtual reality is no less real than in the real world. For this reason, cyber-attacks must be seen as as dangerous as real-world attacks. The European Commission and the Member States should adopt rapid solutions to improve cybersecurity at European level. This means better cooperation between national and European institutions, in correlation between real efforts to jointly combat such threats. Concrete solutions are needed and a clear presentation of the current security situation in cyberspace.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. – Cyber jihadists have recently attacked the French channel TV5 Monde. Eleven channels in 200 countries have failed, the broadcasting centre was under the control of the hackers, and personal details of members of French soldiers fighting ISIS have been made public. This major attack on a leading medium and the threat to military families represents a new dimension of cyber warfare, the effects of which should not be underestimated. These cyberattacks on the media are primarily aimed at restricting freedom of expression and media in order to destabilise our culture and our European value system. It is therefore necessary to give TOP priority to IT security, to increase investment at the enterprise level, to initiate awareness-raising measures and to classify IT systems as as similarly worthy of protection as critical infrastructure. In addition to media such as TV5 Monde, Le Soir, The Huffington Post, New York Times, etc., power grids, banks, health data, etc. could soon be hacked on a large scale. The negative spectrum here ranges from political agitation to economic espionage to cyber-jihadism. Europe, the Member States, must confront this development with all determination and professionalism. Clear guidelines for cybersecurity are an important first step here.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. – Cybersecurity is becoming an increasingly pressing issue in Europe. Attacks take place daily, touching all countries of the European Union, not limited to geographical borders. The Internet is an open platform and tool for various terrorist compounds and radical groups to achieve their destructive goals. In the Baltic states, the issue of online propaganda and cyber attacks against public opinion platforms, public bodies and the media is very relevant from Russia. The increase in the number of hackings demonstrates that anti-EU forces and special services from unfriendly countries have mastered ways to exploit the digital space as one of the strongest tools of threats and terrorism. Cyber terrorism must be seen as a threat to the security of the EU as a whole and appropriate action must be taken as soon as possible.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – Cyber-attacks against the media pose a new threat to cybersecurity, which aims to generate terror and threaten one of the fundamental institutions of democracy. These attacks demonstrate, once again, that no one is safe from danger and proves that terrorism and cybercrime today can generate devastating effects that directly affect citizens. The European Commission and the Member States must adopt rapid solutions aimed at improving cybersecurity at European level. This requires, in my opinion, better cooperation between national and European institutions, with a real correlation of efforts to combat such dangers together. I am pleased that my country, Romania, is in the outpost of the fight against cyber-attacks, through its highly qualified specialists and institutions, and I take the opportunity to once again suggest to the European institutions the creation of a body responsible for European cybersecurity based in Romania.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – first of all, I would like to express my solidarity with the French journalists of TV 5 monde. The cyber attack on the French TV channel on 8 April brought to light our weakness for high-tech cybercrime, as well as the growing potential threats to the European media. Just as the terrorist attack on a "charlie hebdo" in January this year, the islamic State's cyberattack on a large international media is actually an attack on the foundations of our democratic societies. This is a targeted attack on freedom of speech, democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental human rights. All the values that underpin the European project. Immediate and coordinated action by Member States is needed to ensure effective protection against Islamic State cyber terrorism. The new European Agenda on Security is a step in this direction. That, however, is not enough.  We need to ensure the full implementation of existing legislation at national level. I believe that the establishment of adequate policies to ensure cybersecurity must also be a priority in the European strategy against terrorism.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. – Computer attacks take place almost every hour. Attacks often target media websites and pose a danger to media freedom and the free flow of information. Even the powerful BBC failed to resist such attacks, and in Croatia we also witnessed similar activities.  It would be interesting to find out who was comfortable with the dnevno.hr just before the presidential elections in Croatia to be silenced even before the pre-election silence. Since a hacker attack costs more than a thousand dollars a day, it's not entirely about someone's private game. It's about someone who has the money to run it, and to keep it that way for days, and obviously weeks, months.  And right during the presidential campaign. These events are an indication that the EU Security Strategy as well as the Network and Information Security Directive should be improved in their implementation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Persistent advance threats and targeted attacks have shown that traditional security defences can be infiltrated without the danger being detected for months, valuable data can be stolen and destructive actions can be carried out. In addition, the companies you rely on the most are among the most likely targets: financial institutions, health organizations, major private labels and others. PC World reported an 81% increase in advanced and targeted hacking attacks in 2011. In addition, according to several research reports, 855 security incidents were identified and 174 million records were compromised. Regarding the costs of cybercrime in the United States, with an average of 1.8 successful attacks per business each week, the average cost of cybercrime is $8.9 million per company. Protection methods must keep pace with the environment of cyberattacks. With the emergence of targeted attacks and persistent advanced threats, it is clear that a new approach to security is needed. Traditional techniques are simply no longer appropriate to protect data from cyberattacks.

name: Elissavet VOZEMBERG-VRIONIDI
text: PPE), in writing. – The recent terrorist cyber attack on European media, such as the French channel "TV5 Monde", marks a new kind of threat to Europe and its democratic values. The EU and the Member States face significant security challenges. The Union must therefore be further fortified, both legally and institutionally, in the fight against terrorism, organised crime and cyber-attacks. The new European Agenda on Security, which sets out the Union's strategy for dealing with threats in this area, should give particular weight to better preventing and suppressing such crimes aimed at manipulating and gagging the Western media. Success depends not only on effective cooperation between EU institutions and bodies, as well as Member States, with national authorities, but particular emphasis must be placed on the training and specialised training of crime-fighting authorities in Europe, in order to make it more effective to identify 'online' perpetrators, who admittedly use highly advanced technological means of encryption. We believe in the Commission's new initiatives in this area and in the consultation of all political forces in order to guarantee the safety of European citizens.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "It is naïve to think that in the near future we will be able to bring about a rapid improvement in security and security on the internet. By observing and respecting the current efforts in this area, we must acknowledge that cyber attacks will continue, perhaps intensify. In my opinion, the desire to create a single centre to counter such threats is a way nowhere. Without far-reaching action by all stakeholders, no project to combat cyber attacks will succeed. It should also be noted that too often we disregard the individual security of users and their data. We have a big gap in educating how to use the internet safely in such a way as to protect your data and to make your use of the network fully user-friendly. We should not just focus on ad hoc firefighting, but should address the problem from the lowest level, teach and spread good practices in the use of the network. Finally, I would like to mention that the internet is also a gigantic business, and it is also the owners of large internet companies who also have a huge responsibility to protect, especially the youngest users, from online abuse.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the issue with request for oral response (O-000048/2015) to the Commission on the Elimination of the Practice of Early and Forced Marriage of Girls, by Iratxe Garcia Pérez and Anna Maria Corazza Bildt, on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality (B8-0552/2015) (2015/2654 (RSP)).

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: author. – Madam President, around the world, including in Europe, 28 girls every minute are forced to marry. They are exposed to abuse and violence and are denied their rights to health and education. They are robbed of their childhood. The UN Special Representative on Sexual Violence in Conflict, Zainab Hawa Bangura, has denounced horrible sexual abuses and organised rapes committed by Daesh/ISIS. Young girls are sold naked at the market and promised as brides at a price after recruitment. We also see an increased number of children being given in marriage in refugee camps, as desperate parents try to find a way out of poverty. I want to mention the heart-breaking story of Heda, a young girl from Chechnya forced to marry a man three times her age, despite her clear opposition. The life of the journalist who reported this is now under threat. Just last week an international conference on child marriage was organised by the NGO Girls Not Brides. It emerged that there are camps in countries like Zambia and Mozambique to initiate girls in sex and prepare them for marriage, sometimes before they turn nine. These are just a few chilling stories, but there are thousands more and none of us can remain unmoved by them. Child marriage is not only a violation of children’s rights but also a form of violence against women. Unfortunately, only 11 Member States have ratified the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention on combating violence against women that recognises child marriage as a criminal offence. I therefore call on all the Member States to ratify the convention and on the Commission actively to encourage more Member States to enforce it. We cannot close our eyes to this horrific practice. It is time to act in order to end it. We are talking about children. I am proud that the EPP Group took the initiative in this public debate in plenary and I warmly thank the Committee on Women’s Rights and its chair for this report. Let us join forces across political groups and at all levels to put an end to child marriage. The consequences are devastating: girls’ health is at stake, with serious risk of complications in pregnancy and childbirth, and even HIV infections; and girls are exposed to sexual abuse, domestic violence and even honour killing. It is also a question of empowerment. Girls forced to marry are forced out of school, and education offers the best chance for girls to develop skills and have a role in society. Keeping girls out of school is a way to condemn them to poverty and discrimination. I welcome the fact that the European External Action Service and the Member States have made child marriage a priority in the EU Action Plan for Human Rights and Democracy and the EU Development Cooperation Gender Action Plan. However, progress has been slow and uneven. I therefore call on the Vice-President of the Commission/ High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to implement this commitment in all the dialogues and programmes with third countries and regional organisations. The upcoming International Conference on Financing for Development, in Addis Ababa in July 2015, will be a test for our leaders. Child marriage should be included as a priority in the post-2015 development agenda. We need to work with law enforcement authorities, the judicial system and the police, and also to provide training and technical assistance to promote the adoption and enforcement of legislation prohibiting early and forced marriages, including a minimum age for marriage. However, this is not enough. The EU also has an important role in supporting information and awareness campaigns, and our challenge is to combat stereotypes. Violence against children and women should never be justified by culture, tradition or religion, and it is time to break the vicious circle of poverty, submission and violence. We need to work together with religious communities, schools and the media to change attitudes. We need to help families and community leaders to keep girls in school and protect them from violence. Let me thank the many international organisations, including UNICEF, and the many NGOs and civil society bodies who are doing a great job. This is about girls’ dignity, and our message to the 50 million girls a year should be: ‘You are not alone.’ The European Parliament will remain committed to work with all concerned to keep at the top of the EU agenda a zero tolerance policy against child marriage.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, early or forced marriages constitute a violation of girls and women’s human rights and are a brutal form of discrimination rooted in gender inequalities. Protecting children against harmful practices, including child, early and forced marriage, is a priority for the European Union. This has been reiterated in various policy documents, including the latest Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy. And rest assured: the successor to the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment in Development will foster women and girls’ physical and psychological integrity, with a specific focus on the fight against harmful traditional practices. We all know that addressing child marriage is a very complex issue. It requires a comprehensive strategy that covers the adoption of protective legislation, the enhancement of access to quality education, the promotion of gender equality, and a change in mentalities and social norms. It also requires adequate funding and well-targeted projects. We are committed to ensuring both. At the Girl Summit in London in July 2014 the European Union committed to allocating more than EUR 100 million for the next seven years to gender equality and children’s wellbeing under the Programme on Global Public Goods and Challenges. Additional projects are also envisaged under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights and under the Pan-African Programme in order to support the African Committee of Experts on the Rights and Welfare of Children, which is the only region-focused children’s rights instrument in the world. In order to translate our policy into actions on the ground, the European Union has developed a series of projects and actions in the framework of our cooperation with regional organisations. Also, through political dialogue the European Union regularly engages with countries where early and forced marriages take place. Eighty-four EU delegations worldwide have prioritised children’s rights in their human rights country strategies. Human Rights are at the heart of our partnership with the African continent under the Joint Africa-EU Strategy. At the 4th Africa-EU Summit in 2014, it was agreed to work together to ensure the full respect of human rights, international law, gender equality, and to fight all forms of discrimination, racism and xenophobia. The European Union participated at the Casablanca donor meeting on Ending Child, Early and Forced Marriage last week, following the ‘Girls Not Brides’ conference for a global partnership to end child marriage. All EU framework agreements with third countries – such as association and cooperation agreements concluded since 1995 – include a human rights clause. Through it, the parties to the agreement declare their shared commitment to the promotion and protection of human rights. It also gives the EU a clear legal basis on which to raise human rights issues with the respective countries. And we regularly do so. Moreover, some EU framework agreements include articles on human rights cooperation and on cooperation related to gender equality. On this basis, specific cooperation initiatives can be agreed to fight against child marriage. The European Union welcomed the entry into force in August 2014 of the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence. So far 37 countries, of which 23 are EU Member States, have signed the Convention and 18 countries, of which 11 are EU Member States, have ratified it. National ratification processes are progressing well. Five Member States ratified in 2014 alone. The Commission services are also examining the legal, policy and practical implications of a possible EU accession to the Convention. As part of its initiatives to tackle violence against women, the Commission funds national awareness-raising campaigns by Member States, grassroots projects by civil society organisations and European networks in this area. These campaigns, projects and networks play an important role in raising awareness of the Convention and in promoting its ratification and proper implementation. To conclude, I would like to praise the work done by the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality and the Subcommittee on Human Rights. Both use every opportunity to raise awareness and challenge practices contrary to our human rights principles. Your work is absolutely essential to the upholding of human rights principles within our partner countries and I am thankful for it.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: for the PPE Group. – Early child marriage is in stark contrast to christian and, fortunately, the European vision of human dignity. At the same time, they also contradict international law, as expressed in the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I therefore welcome and support any initiative that increases children's chances of their childhood not being terminated prematurely and often forcibly by forced marriage. However, it is not possible to protest in one breath against forced marriage of children, while at the same time highlighting their right to family planning. It seems absurd to me if, in one sentence, female colleagues highlight childhood, and in the next sentence they talk about children, girls, as adult women. If we want to do something to put an end to the practice of child marriage in the world, we must, above all, demand compliance with the Charter of The Rights of the Child from the partner countries of the European Union where this phenomenon exists. I therefore share the third question and believe that the Commission is monitoring the situation of children at risk in third countries. I am of the opinion that, in dialogue with them, it is necessary to insist consistently on the end of the practice of child marriage, even at the cost of cutting official development aid. But pushing through elements of gender ideology under the pretext of protecting the innocence of childhood, I find this inappropriate and ultimately ineffective. And I think that is also why most countries have not yet ratified the Istanbul Protocol. And worst of all, instead of helping the children at risk, we're just going to hurt them. Boys and girls, too.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner, this afternoon the Secretary-General of the United Nations, Mr Ban Ki-moon, said, in part of his speech, that one of the most important values of the European Union project is to be united in diversity to defend human rights, and this is what we are doing right now. From different ideological positions on many issues, today we share concerns about an issue that tears us all apart when we see girls, both within the European Union and outside the European Union, being forced into marriage. There is a 2014 report that such forced marriages are also taking place within the European Union.  I therefore urge the Commission itself to incorporate actions in this area and, of course, in foreign policy and in cooperation policy.  It is essential that the gender perspective is incorporated. It is true that on paper, most actions incorporate the gender perspective, but then the data tell us how only 28% of the projects that have been financed in terms of cooperation incorporate this gender perspective.  We're talking about fundamental rights. We are talking about combating gender-based violence and we are talking about the rights of children.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Around fourteen million girls are married every year before the age of eighteen. The case of an eight-year-old girl from Yemen who died from internal bleeding after a wedding night with her five-times older husband is very eloquent and painful. This is not a private matter for families – it is a public matter that we must treat as a crime. Early forced marriage is a brutal restriction of childhood and a violation of the rights of the child. Therefore, this practice should be regulated by law and criminal penalties. It must not be turned a blind eye and must be opposed, but not by urging the European Union to adopt and ratify the Istanbul Convention, the ideological nature of which will not only not solve this problem, but will even open the door to social dismantling and undermining the institutions of the family. We must combat the practice of premature marriage in discussions with partner countries on cooperation between the European Union and these countries. We must also ensure that such cases do not happen in the Member States of the European Union despite the formal ban. Information campaigns are needed to raise awareness of the disastrous effects of these practices. We must not tolerate violence that affects human dignity, the right to freedom, education that poses a threat to health ...  (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank Mrs Corazza for the initiative to bring this oral question to the House and for having reached the consensus of the political groups to talk about something that we often remove from our conversations.  We're used to reporting, chasing paedolystia. We were convinced by Dr. Mukwege when, in his speech, upon receiving the Sakharov Prize, he explained to us how rape is a weapon of war that destroys communities. Early marriage, forced marriage is a weapon of mass destruction because it destroys girls, eliminating their ability to be educated: that is the main weapon.  Forced marriage is not only an attack on human rights, but it is a violation of children's rights and is violence against women. The consequences of early marriage are devastating for girls, because it is not only health problems, sexual abuse, domestic violence, but above all the destruction of their future because it destroys their ability to empower therself, to develop through education.  I would also like here to stress the role of the Commission and the European Union as a whole in getting the European Union to sign the Istanbul Convention, in which forced marriage is recognised and specified as something to be pursued and which must be removed from our society.  I would also like to stress that we are not only talking about rights and violations of rights, but we are talking about democratic standards, our obligation as a reference in the world of democracy. And I also refer again to what Mr Ban Ki-moon said this afternoon: it is important that inclusive governance, inclusive democracy and our role as a locomotive in the world in the defence of human rights have a special sensitivity and a very clear determination to eliminate forced marriage in all those countries with which we have agreements.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too believe that this is the issue we are discussing today, an issue that really concerns an issue that speaks to us not only about violence against children, such as girls forced into marriage, but once again about male violence against women, about fathers deciding to choose for their daughters. I, unlike my colleague from the ECR, believe that working towards the full implementation of the Istanbul Convention would be crucial, too, in the key to the issue we are discussing today. I believe that we must work, we must work on trade agreements in order to call on third countries to take action against this scourge, but we must also work to create greater awareness and education of girls within the Union, where these cases occur. It is therefore also a question of allocating resources to unite through education.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, Mrs García Pérez has already said this: there are still cases of forced marriage in the European Union. According to the european Agency for Fundamental Rights' study last October, it still exists in some groups such as roma. A survey of eleven countries where more Roma live found that 2% of girls between the age of 10 and 15 had been subjected to forced marriage and 16% of adolescents between the age of 16 and 17.  The internal situation is therefore worrying: how will the European Commission ensure that this practice is eradicated in Europe?  And with regard to foreign policy, our weapons to put pressure on those countries where this terrible practice occurs to combat it are political and trade support. But the facts show that we have not even fulfilled our commitments to put the gender approach to 75% of the projects financed.  Are we going once and for all to apply the demands of gender equality in our political and trade relations? Are we going to firmly demand countries where women are considered second- or third-rate citizens to respect basic human rights? Why don't we apply a feminist foreign policy with conviction and firmness? With these words: "feminist foreign policy". That's how clear it is.  I assure you that women who were forced to marry girls, which I have met in countries like India, carry infinite sadness for the rest of their lives, a sadness that should be enough for the European Union to react with emergency and force.

name: Daniela AIUTO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we learn almost daily from the news of cases of women, including minors, forced to marry men much older than themselves. These events find fertile ground in ignorance, poverty, illiteracy and cultural, ideological and religious beliefs that do not respect women's fundamental rights. Cultural and religious motives are often the fig leaf behind which hide the real will to commit sexual abuse of minors. I am thinking of the recent case of Kheda, a child bride forced to marry the Chechen police chief more than thirty years her own. This violence does not only occur in third countries, culturally and politically far from the European Union, with which, however, the European Union itself does not hesitate to maintain economic and trade relations, but also within our own borders. Forced marriages, as well as episodes of female genital mutilation and other violence against women, originate in a different culture from that of the European Union, but they also happen on a daily basis in our cities, which are much closer than we think. It is no coincidence that many such incidents are aimed at obtaining citizenship and must therefore be monitored and combated.
