Therefore, just as attention and control are required within the walls of our house, we must also ensure that there is condemnation of such violence by third countries, not only from a formal point of view but also with effective verification of what is really happening. Commissioner, we must put an end to this hypocrisy. In this situation as in other situations, the European Union cannot pursue economic policies and trade agreements with third countries without ensuring that third countries respect the most fundamental human rights, including the right of a woman to freely choose her partner and the right for girls and girls to be able to live their childhood and adolescence with serenity.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: – Millions of girls worldwide are forcibly married, most of them in Muslim countries. In Turkey, the country that recently received another EUR 1 billion from the European Union, this practice is the order of the day. In a third of marriages, there is an underage girl. Some are only eight or nine years old. Because of open borders, we are also seeing the phenomenon of forced marriage more and more often in the European Union. Here too, the rights of girls are being violated. Of course, there is no point in signing all kinds of treaties and setting up initiatives if we continue to ignore the structural problem, namely Islam and importing them. The idea of the Committee on Women's Rights to financially support the families of these girls is therefore simply a ridicuul. In this way, the European Union only pays for the dowry if these girls are married to an uncle or a cousin. Of course, the problem does not go away by throwing a bag of money at it. The European Union should not give money but close its borders. Because we do not want to have these practices here, and we should not tolerate them here.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. When a 40-year-old man marries a 12-year-old girl, this is mostly justified by tradition, sometimes by religion, and this situation is deeply objectionable to me, because in our criminal codes sex with a child is treated as paedophilia, and in such a situation we are dealing with sexual violence, psychological violence, economic violence and violations of human rights – women's rights to dignity, freedom, self-instable anceslight. It is therefore a phenomenon which, for obvious reasons, we must limit and combat with all our strength. It applies not only to Asian countries, but also, unfortunately, to Europe. The basic tool to combat this phenomenon is, in my opinion, education, because it gives a pass to further working life, gives you the opportunity to be economically independent – and awareness of your rights and money are essential tools for preventing and protecting against violence. Another very important tool, of course, is the Istanbul Convention, which prohibits forced marriages – and I am proud that Poland recently joined the group of European Union countries that have ratified this Convention. I am also very pleased with the European Commission's earlier declarations that the European Union, as a party, will ratify this Convention, because it is very necessary for Europe to be more aware of the rights enshrined in the Convention. It is also worth recalling that at a recent UN session on human rights, one hundred and sixty-seven countries of the world agreed that this convention is the gold standard of anti-violence policy and that the provisions of this Convention should be widely used as an essential tool for combating violence, including sexual violence. Thank you very much.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: – Mr President, earlier this year Malawi, to its very great credit, banned forced child marriage. This was a tremendous victory in a country which has one of the highest rates of forced child marriage in the world. One of the leading campaigners for this tremendous change was an 18-year-old woman called Memory Banda, who started her advocacy on the issue when her own sister was married at the age of 11 to a man in his early thirties. The sister is now 16 and she has three children. Memory herself has said, ‘Marriage is often the end for girls like me, but, if our leaders will invest in us and give us the chance to be educated, we will become women who create a better society for everyone.’ However, passing laws is not the end of the story, for even when child marriage is illegal it is still common. In India it is illegal for girls under 18 to be married, yet UNICEF estimates that around 47% of girls in India were married before they turned 18. Simply changing the law is not enough: information, awareness and education campaigns are crucially important to stamp out this terrible practice. We are all agreed on this, and the EU has a real role to play here – to go out and do absolutely everything we possibly can to end this barbaric and cruel practice.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: – The topic of forced marriages is viewed by many in Slovakia as a topic that does not concern our country. It is a question of the past, or that it is a problem that occurs only in developing countries, where parents force their children, daughters, to marry much older grooms. Yes, we are getting really horrifying stories from these countries that several of my previous speakers have told us about. However, forced marriages are not a question of the past, they are a reality of the present and their victims come not only from those distant countries, but also from Slovakia. These are modern-day slaves, young, underage girls from marginalised communities who travel abroad to see a good job. However, seeing a better tomorrow becomes a nightmare the moment they are forced to marry an unknown man. Their personal freedom is limited and returning home is impossible. If we want to help these girls, but especially if we want to prevent more girls from losing their childhoods and hope of a free, happy and full life, we need to invest more in quality education, as well as ensure that helplines, asylum homes or social services centres can function sustainably.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: – Mr President, I would like to encourage the Commissioner to maintain the support of European actions in the third countries where this practice is socially assumed, but I would like at the same time to encourage him to consider the effect that prevention and attention we can have on these countries on the risky population living with us.  The Catalan police have put in place a protocol to be able to make this problem visible here and offer victims attention, advice and connection with social services. And, before long, only one of the provinces of Catalonia detected and resolved six cases.  Experts advise focusing efforts on formulas to effectively and effectively nullify these unions, establish a minimum age for getting married, and identify and prevent risk groups. And I think this experience is very interesting.  That is why I would like to know, Commissioner, whether you have reliable data on the impact of this problem, which is often linked many times also to cases of genital mutilation in Europe, and whether you find it interesting to be able to incorporate into third countries awareness campaigns and programmes the testimony of people who were born there and learned here that forced marriages are not normal , but one of the starkest expressions of inequality and violence against women and girls that can also be successfully fought.  I would like you to answer this because, beyond statements, what we need are practical examples and concrete results that we can measure over time.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Mr President, 39,000 girls are married in the world every day, according to Unicef data. 700 million women, according to Unicef itself, have been forceded by force in the world: 250 million of them under the age of 15.  But I would also like to recall the origin of most of these marriages which, according to all studies to this day, is in poverty, that is, in this perverse system that exploits human beings, countries and their resources. A system in which we are seeing slavery practiced again: 36 million people in the world live in slavery, according to the Walk Free Foundation.  I would also like to ask the European Union to sign the Istanbul Convention and declare 2016 as the European Year against Gender-Based Violence. Our conviction is very clear: without equality there is no development, there is no justice and there is no democracy.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, it is shocking that the main cause of death for girls between the ages of 15 and 19 is pregnancy and childbirth. This, too, shows how important it is that we put these early child marriage at the very heart of the fight for girls' and women's rights. And now that the Commission is preparing this next Gender action programme, I hope that this issue will be strongly raised there. Mr President, I have seen in practice that it is certainly not always enough to change the laws. It may sometimes be the case that there is an absolutely brilliant constitution in the state which provides that, under the age of 18, there can be no transition to marriage, but then there may be exceptions that a judge in Morocco, for example, can very widely exercise discretion, in which case very young girls can then be forced to marry this way. Or, for example, in Tanzania, where there is also a fine progressive constitution, then such a traditional right prevails. That is why it is important to talk to the traditional leaders of these communities. It is also important that girls are empowered to believe that they need to get into school and then ensure their own lives.

name: Louise BOURS
text: – Madam President, the issue of forced marriage does not just affect children living on the African and Asian continents. It is happening across Europe, and the silence surrounding it has many parallels with the exploitation and trafficking of young girls across many towns in northern England. UK law imposes a maximum sentence of seven years on the perpetrators of this crime, and it is simply not a strong enough deterrent. Girls are afraid to speak out, others dismiss it as a cultural practice, and our social services in England, the police and the politicians dare not speak up for fear of being labelled racist. With open borders, human traffickers have free rein to exploit children. In 2013, over 600 children were trafficked into Britain for exploitation and forced marriage. This modern—day form of slavery is on the rise, and the EU has given the perpetrators a helping hand: by not allowing Member States to control their own borders and check criminal backgrounds, the EU is enabling this crime to escalate. The UK can at least check an individual’s passport. Mainland Europe is prevented from even doing that. Criminal trafficking gangs operate with impunity due to EU free movement rules, so whilst Members are very good at voicing their outrage at these crimes, they are fundamentally unable to implement anything practical to actually stop them.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, traditions, especially those of indigenous and minority groups, are essential as they often embody the continuous existence of a community. However, as we saw a couple of years ago, certain countries tried to push through a process to legitimise the concept of ‘traditional values of humankind’ as the basis for human rights law at the Human Rights Council, led by the Russian Federation. There is an inherent danger to making ‘traditional values’ the standard for human rights. Not only do these values evolve constantly, they are also difficult and dangerous to define. It is within this context that culture cannot be used to undermine the universality of the human rights principles, which are applicable to the practice of early and forced marriage of girls. Firstly, the EU ensures that gender equality is on the agenda in every dialogue with third countries, especially for development cooperation. However, it should keep on mainstreaming gender equality in all policy areas and programmes, especially inside the Union. Too many girls in Europe are still deprived of their right to education, because they are forced into marriage. Secondly, there is an urgent need for reliable data on forced marriages inside the European Union. Lastly, Parliament has urged the Commission in the past to promote the national ratification of the Istanbul Convention and even launched the procedure for the EU’s accession to it. I urge Commissioner Jourová to pursue this as a priority so that the battle against forced and early marriages can take place in a harmonised way across the entire European Union.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Child and forced labour is a cruel crime. Child marriage abruptly ends childhood, school and, above all, ease. Child and forced labour. Forced marriage usually means the first rape on the wedding day. In any case, it is a violent and involuntary entry into a completely unequal marriage. This marriage can never be in partnership. Such a marriage can never be voluntary, and above all it can never be good. Girls and women who are married against their will are often subjected to a lifetime of sexual and domestic violence. We know there are three groups of perpetrators. These three groups of perpetrators exist not only in the Third World countries, but also here in Europe. There are men and women who order these marriages. And there are men who are grooms themselves. These individuals are persecuted and punished. There are people who suspect forced marriage but do not act. They belong enlightened and they belong to responsibility. And there is society, there are the politicians who know exactly what is happening, who know that the victims exist and who knowingly do not protect them. These are awakened. I address you today, to the Commission. We need reliable data in Europe. We need prosecution in all Member States. We need aid systems. We need a legal age of protection for the first option of marriage. We need an understanding of the victims and, above all, we need the ratification of the Istanbul Convention. We need you today!

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: – Mr. President, according to UNICEF data, every year 15 million girls, some as young as 5 years old, enter into marriages without their consent, mainly for a much older man. Such premature and often at the same time forced marriages are mostly concluded in developing countries. Even one in three girls under 18 in developing countries enters into such a premature marriage.  In countries such as Niger, Chad and Mali, this figure is even scarier, with more than 70% of girls entering into premature marriages. This practice, in addition to posing unacceptable violations of the human rights of women and girls and a serious threat to their health, education and socioeconomic status, has truly devastating effects on development and economics. Forced marriages are serious brakes on our efforts to eradicate poverty. That is why we must put an end to this harmful practice through increased development policy efforts in cooperation with third countries. This year we have a unique opportunity to put women and girls at the centre of global development efforts, which Parliament has called for with a resolution on the Positions of the European Union within the negotiations of a new development framework after 2015, when we sent a clear message that women and girls must be at the centre of development efforts, as this way we can stop the cycle of poverty before it starts. Therefore, I would like to welcome the efforts also explained by Commissioner Mimica and, of course, call on the Commission to continue in line with the human rights-based approach, and in dialogue with the recipient countries of development aid, to insist on the development and implementation of legal frameworks to help eradicate this harmful practice.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: – Forced marriage is one of the cases of extreme and criminal violence, which particularly forces children and young women to lose their innocence. I am not exclusively referring to physical violence and sexual abuse, but also to the early death of dreams and wills. I mean girls who stopped playing to satisfy so-called cultural whims. They are young women who should be in schools and universities and who are literally sold by their families in the name of gods, customs and traditions. I am also referring to men, many of them much older, who willingly accept to rape young girls.  If it is true that the religious, cultural and social issue weighs, no less true will these marriages have a price: the gift, or rather a payment. "Forced marriage is little more than slavery," said a young woman forced to marry, and we have many girls and young people who are slaves in Europe.   These women are the daughters of shame. Shame on who knows where and how these marriages take place. Shame on those who are unable to enforce the law. Shame on those who do not protect them from the madness of a so-called custom and an honor that is but a tradition that kills.  We know that about 10% of foreigners who have come to Syria in search of a caliphate are Western women and girls, some of them European, who will also be forced to marry or raped or murdered or sold. One of these young women has been sold 22 times, 22 times!  What have we done for this young lady? For all the young girls and girls brutally raped by their cool husbands? For all the girls who, instead of a doll, have a baby in their arms? What is the role of education in this area? What have we done to ensure that no girl or young woman in old Europe is promised as a commodity and sold into slavery?

name: Marek JUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In this interesting discussion, we have heard particularly at the beginning about Yemen, about Africa, about the Istanbul Convention. Only, unfortunately, only a few of my colleagues, mainly, thank them for this, have said that when we talk about this form of violence against, we actually say women, but not women, because to girls, to girls, we are talking about a phenomenon that is going on in Europe today. A few years ago, data was published suggesting that in certain environments in Germany, up to one in ten women may fall victim to such a fate. Just a question in which? If we are talking about the Istanbul Convention, then perhaps let us ask in which, because this, I ask you, is not in those countries that have recently voted in favour of defending the natural family system. Not in Slovakia, not in Croatia, not in Lithuania. This is only a problem in the vast majority, ninety percent, of the Muslim immigrant community in Europe. And I'm not really surprised that we're talking about this problem around us, since we don't want to call reality by name. But at the same time, I want to say that we Poles and we in Central Europe want to have the choice of not making your mistakes and not going on the path of this policy that we want to impose today, and which we are actually discussing these dark aspects today. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I wanted to ask you if you do not think, Mr President, that this is a violation of the principle of gender equality, that we are talking about forced marriages of women, and that we are not talking about forced marriages of men, which also happens?

name: Marek JUREK
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. Thank you very much, Mr President, for your attention. We necessarily care about the weaker side as a rule, but you are right. Yes, in many countries, such as Germany, this is a problem that also concerns marital coercion against young men. And I say it again – let's really think about the environments in which these dramas occur and what really lies behind this mask of multiculturalism.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, I first appreciate your excellent Czech, which is constantly improving from one plenary session to another. But on an issue that is very important, which is very difficult to understand.  First of all, I would like to say that our task is to protect the rights of children, forced marriages do not only concern girls, but also concern boys. Children are the group that is most vulnerable. Children in Europe must have the right to make free choices, it is not possible to dictate who to marry. That is why a number of initiatives are being launched in Europe. Recently, an initiative was emerged in the UK that if a child wants to avoid being taken to, say, India or another country, they will take a spoonful in their underwear. The staff of the service that checks the child as he passes through the scanner can see this spoon and can actually tell that the child is being taken away for forced marriage. Hundreds of children across Europe have already been rescued. And I am very glad that, for example, in Germany or the UK there are organisations that systematically address this problem. Yes, we can criticise forced marriage in a number of world countries here, but Europe should focus above all on the problems that are within it. Precisely because tens of thousands of children are forced to marry someone they do not want in EU countries every year, and we must prevent this not only by adopting a resolution, but by effectively combating this phenomenon, which is as old as humanity itself.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: – Mr President, according to statistics from the United Nations Population Fund, 14.2 million young women under the age of eighteen are or will be married every year between 2011 and 2020 in developing countries, mainly sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia, which represents 39 000 forced marriages every day. The percentage is impressive, and the statistics do not stop there: one in four teenage girls is married without her will between fourteen and eighteen years old; a young woman in nine is forcibly married between the ages of ten and fourteen; one in two girls gives birth to a baby while still a teenager in developing countries. We must not forget, at the same time, that in 2009 more than half of the world's population, i.e. 50.6%, lived on less than EUR 0.70 per day, which encourages forced marriages for young women who are still seen as a source of income for their families. In fact, girls and teenage girls are items in these countries that parents have as they please and that are sold to future spouses. If we consider that about 36% of children over the age of six have never gone to school, and where there are schools, the classes have an average of 129 pupils, we understand that in these countries marriage is often a solution or perhaps the only possible solution to survive for young women without education... (The President interrupted the speaker's speech.) (The speaker agreed to answer a question from the removal of the blue card in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Regulation).

name: Urmas PAET
text: blue card issue. – Many thanks for recalling my late history, but on this serious issue, I have such a question that, unquestionably, forced marriage of girls is a serious violation of human rights. According to the World Health Organisation, there are already more suicides among teenage girls in the world today than women die in childbirth, for example, which is that this has gone up exponentially and one reason is the same forced marriages.  Every year, the European Union makes very different agreements with countries where forced marriages are a problem, and provides relatively generous development aid. What is your view, for example, of the situation in the area of human rights, for example, in the development of development aid, but especially on the very subject – in the area of forced marriages with girls – in the country to which development aid is granted, and how much should these things be made dependent on each other?

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: Answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – The European Union certainly has cooperation agreements with these countries in many cases, but I believe that we must bear in mind the emphasis on education that would allow young women to survive and look for a job, which would be an alternative, this situation of course having other alternatives, which were exposed by the speakers before me.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: " Mr. President, the untimely marrying of girls with coercion is a terrible practice that I condemn in the strongest terms. I believe that we must vigorously fight this kind of violence against girls who are neither physically nor mentally ready to marry and take on the demanding role of wife and mother. It is really important that in our relations with third countries we insist on respect for the human rights of children and the fight against this kind of violence against girls. However, I think it is even more important to eradicate this appalling practice within the European Union, otherwise Europe loses its credibility when influencing third countries.  Quality integration of minority groups that mostly practice forced wounds marry girls, for Member States, but also for members of minorities, should not only be an option, but also an obligation. This practice has no place in European societies, it should be clearly condemned, and perpetrators of such violence against girls should be drastically punished.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: – According to Unicef, more than 700 million women are married worldwide before the age of 18 and 250 million were married before the age of 15. These are unimaginable figures that show that we still have a lot of hard work to do in the area of combating discrimination against women and achieving gender equality. I am very pleased that the Istanbul Convention, which sets out obligations to prevent violence against women, has also been signed by Slovenia, which then ratified it at the end of last year. The legal framework for combating discrimination against women is thus set, but we need more decisive steps in the fight against gender equality. In this light, I believe that an information campaign on raising awareness among our citizens about this type of violence should be stepped up, as the figures show that in some countries there is a very high percentage of girls in their teenage years who have been victims of violence and have never sought help.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, all boys and girls have the right to live their childhood and adolescence peacefully, and this in all countries of the world. However, as we know, the practice of child marriage and especially the marriage imposed on girls is still widespread in some regions, including South Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. These are, however, countries with the highest rates of maternal mortality and infant mortality, as well as malnutrition, illiteracy and early school leaving.  Therefore, while understanding the different socio-cultural conditions in these countries, the practice of child brides is no longer tolerable, which, moreover, constitutes a violation of the legal constraints laid down in Articles 12 and 19 of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and Adolescents.  I therefore hope that the Commission will be able to play a leading role in the adoption of legal measures and concrete measures to raise awareness among the communities concerned, so that this unacceptable practice can be put to an end.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the practice of pre-forced marriage of girls, particularly in Asia and Africa, has raised concerns in the international community but also in the European Union itself. This practice violates the human rights of girls and women and leads to an increase in health risks. The consequences of early and forced marriage are enormous for women but also for societies themselves. Maintaining the cycle of poverty, forced marriage reduces a society's chances of creating sustainable development and social cohesion. Of the Member States of the European Union, 23 have signed and only 11 have ratified the Council of Europe Convention on the Prevention and Combating of Both Violence against Women and Domestic Violence, a convention which regards forced marriage as a violation of human rights. A report published in 2014 showed that forced marriage is a problem in some Member States, such as Germany. Parliament has taken a position on combating violence against women. It will now be necessary for the Commission to initiate the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention of the Council of Europe .

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, we are witnessing frightening practices when we talk about girls, when we talk about violence against young women, and we must really do everything we can to end this practice. What I want to emphasize is that these are psychological and physical traumas for these girls or young women. In any case, unfortunately, I must note that in addition to Africa where this is too common a practice, unfortunately both on our continent and in the Member States, and especially in some countries that are our candidates or want to join the European Union, in the Balkans, we still have such a very bad practice or practice that parents already decide in advance while the children decide that they have to marry individuals , i.e. boys and girls. In this context, I call on the European Commission to support the members of the European Union to sign the Istanbul Convention.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: –Mr. President, one in three girls are marrying before the age of 18, among them one in nine before the age of 15. 15 million a year worldwide, more than 41,000 a day, one little girl every second. To be more specific. From my first word to the end of my one-minute speech, a forced marriage will be made by 30 girls.  Why? Because tradition so dictates, because they were born in the wrong sex, because they are too much of a cost to families, because the compulsion to marry depends on their safety. Children have a right to be children. Girls must be able to choose for themselves who to marry and with whom to start a family. We must provide them with a childhood, safe and carefree. After all, we and the future of humanity depend on it. To save children's childhood, to provide every child with education, that is what we must strive for and take concrete actions. It's not just a question of adhering to international conventions and declarations, it's also a matter of humanity.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, I truly hope that the Commission is going to carry out a concrete plan of action with a view to ending child marriage. Many girls who become pregnant early have to cope with dangerous risks to their health and to that of their children. The majority of these girls are forced to leave school before finishing primary school, and many suffer from violence and sexual abuse. It is important to establish information and awareness-raising campaigns in communities in which this gender-based human rights violation is practised. These girls often see their role in the world only as baby-makers. We must change that, start discussions on these issues and help the girls make the right choices. I would also like to transmit a message to the Commission and to the Commissioner present here: as mentioned before, we face this situation in Europe as well, not only in developing countries. Look at some Muslim communities in Europe and the Roma communities as well. We should also address these issues in the European Union.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, I will admit that I am genuinely surprised or shocked by the information I have received from my colleagues through the debate. I did not know that the problem was so serious even within the EU. I apologize for my ignorance. The next time I face something so shocked, I would rather avoid it by actually directing its development support, especially to countries where such fundamental issues of violation of fundamental human rights and freedoms will not arise. I am surprised that it is possible that, in other cases, as we have seen, in other cases of human rights violations, the EU may direct its development aid where there is a violation of the fundamental values in which we believe. I don't have a timer running, but I think a minute's passed.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the last ten years, as many as a hundred million girls have been forced to marry before their eighteenth year of age, and it is expected that by 2050 there will be as many as 1 200 000 000 victims of forced marriages, a truly impressive number. Early and forced marriages are a practice that mortifies the rights of women and girls and threatens their health. This practice is a kind of mortgage on the lives of girls, who will never be free to make independent decisions and to grow up with their peers, nor to free themselves from the condition of the object of domination of others. I therefore consider this position of the European Parliament, which recognises the importance of putting an end to early marriages, to be absolutely important if gender equality is really to be guaranteed. The Commission, for its part, must develop awareness-raising campaigns, but above all it must assert the European Union's cultural diplomacy in exchanges and agreements with third countries where early marriages are more widespread, in order to put an end to this unacceptable and shameful practice.

name: Soraya POST
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Marriages in which one or both parties are children should never be recognised as legal. Child marriage is, by definition, forced marriage. Unfortunately, they occur – we are talking about Africa, we are talking about third countries – even within our borders. Unfortunately, what is most amazing is that we know about it, but do not ensure that there is protection for all these girls and children who are subjected to forced marriages. The Istanbul Convention is committed to active action against men's violence against women. Child marriage is a form of structural violence against women that maintains inequalities between men and women in society. The Commission is also an important step in the fight against child marriage as it draws up clear and concrete guidelines on how states can start acting now to stop child marriage and other forms of men's violence against women. The Istanbul Convention is a convention that all Member States should ratify. calls on the Commission to launch a process for the EU to accede to the Convention and to develop financial support for ngos working against certain groups on these very issues in order to raise awareness;

name: Soraya POST
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, throughout this debate I have seen a joint commitment to the elimination of child marriage, early marriage and forced marriage. To ensure this, we need to develop overall strategies that impact on issues interrelated to harmful practices, such as birth registration to provide girls with a legal identity, improved access to health services, and issues such as adolescent pregnancy which jeopardise girls’ rights. In particular, I would stress the need to focus on education. Educated girls become empowered women who can challenge social norms. We need awareness-raising, leading to public declarations of the abandonment of harmful practices, and to broad-based social mobilisation and legal and policy measures. We need knowledge so that we can better understand the dynamics of social norms. With regard to data on forced marriages and genital mutilation in EU Member States, the European Institute on Gender Equality is expected to publish a report on 9 June 2015. Allow me to thank the honourable Members and the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality for being active and dedicated on gender issues, especially this year as we celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Beijing Platform for Action and the 15th anniversary of UN Security Council Resolution 1325 on Women, Peace and Security.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. – Many girls are forced to marry, which not only constitutes a violation of the rights of the child and human rights, but is also a form of violence against women. These marriages violate girls' right to physical integrity, autonomous decision-making, a life free from violence and marital rape, but above all violate their right to be girls. Delaying marriages and deliveries, in addition to the unquestionable benefits for girls' psychological health, also protects them from the risks of HIV infection, childbirth death and medical conditions such as obstetric fistula. The EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation requires that the gender dimension be a primary objective in at least 75% of all new EU-funded projects. However, only 28% of projects take into account the gender dimension. The EU Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy states that the prevention of child marriage is a priority for the EESS and Member States.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. – I am appalled that this practice is continuing in the 21st century. Young girls should never be forced into marriage, and indeed no one should. This practice causes severe psychological scars for those who are often too vulnerable to end such marriages. We all need to do everything we can to end this appalling situation. Marriage is a deep bond between two people who love one another: the entire institution of marriage is cheapened by so-called ‘forced marriages’.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Millions of children continue to experience forced marriages, which are a violation of children's rights and violence against women. These marriages are contrary to the rights of girls in accordance with the Beijing Declaration of the United Nations. The European Union cannot spare any effort to eradicate this phenomenon which violates the fundamental rights of millions of human beings. All levers must be used, in international law (via the Istanbul Convention in particular) but also through development cooperation and EU trade, cooperation and association agreements to end forced early marriages.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. In 2014, the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) counted more than 250 million women who were forcibly married as children worldwide. Worse, nearly 130 million women have undergone genital mutilation (total or partial removal of their external genitalia), mainly in Africa and the Middle East. In fact, it is estimated that nearly 10 million girls and adolescents are forced into forced marriages a year.  It is high time that the United Nations raised the age of marriages and criminalized forced marriages in spite of local customs and traditions. This dishonourable practice for women is akin to a form of modern slavery that is intolerable to endorse. The marriage of a child short-circuits her education, limits her possibilities, jeopardizes her health and increases her risk of being a victim of violence. Girls are often married to older men and, while forced marriage also affects boys, it first exposes girls to early pregnancy and childbirth, the leading cause of death among 15-19 year olds, according to a United Nations report.  The European Union, which promotes gender equality, must the forth in its international agreements and support the cessation of forced marriages.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. – Many girls are forced to marry, which not only constitutes a violation of the rights of the child and human rights, but is also a form of violence against women. These marriages violate girls' right to physical integrity, autonomous decision-making, a life free from violence and marital rape, but above all violate their right to be girls. Delaying marriages and deliveries, in addition to the unquestionable benefits for girls' psychological health, also protects them from the risks of HIV infection, childbirth death and medical conditions such as obstetric fistula. The EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation requires that the gender dimension be a primary objective in at least 75% of all new EU-funded projects. However, only 28% of projects take into account the gender dimension. The EU Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy states that the prevention of child marriage is a priority for the EESS and Member States.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – We in the European Parliament have spoken and emphasised in our resolutions that it is necessary to adopt laws prohibiting forced marriages of children and to provide for a minimum age for girls to be 18 years old. All girls and boys must have the right to safe childhood, the right to education, children must be protected from any abuse, exploitation and feel safe full-fledged citizens. Such fundamental rights are established by the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Children, but millions of girls do not have children, are prematurely married and violate not only their rights as children, but often they experience violence and sexual exploitation. In addition, the health of young girls, both physically and psychologically, is often disturbed, and unfortunately there are cases where such forced marriages end in the death of young girls. So I would like to ask the Commission whether it intends to take concrete steps to stop forced marriages of young girls? What initiatives could the Commission take to educate and train communities, girls and families in those countries where forced marriages still exist? It is therefore very important to change the attitudes of families and parents to such marriages. Of course, this is the need to legislate to ban forced marriages of young girls and to punish the sexual exploitation of girls, to harm health, and for the use of any violence against them.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. Forced marriages of young girls are a real scourge that seriously undermines the dignity of women. That is why all progress towards reducing these practices must be welcomed and encouraged, especially in developing countries. However, this struggle, however legitimate, should not be used as a pretext for the implementation of policies of interference in the internal affairs of States, especially since this scourge has a strong problem with the Member States of the Union, starting with France. According to the NGO Plan France, nearly 70,000 girls have been forced into forced marriages in France. According to the NGO, most of these girls are immigrants from Turkey, the Maghreb and sub-Saharan Africa. That is why, before giving lessons to other nations, we must sweep before our door.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. – Many girls are forced to marry, which not only constitutes a violation of the rights of the child and human rights, but is also a form of violence against women. These marriages violate girls' right to physical integrity, autonomous decision-making, a life free from violence and marital rape, but above all violate their right to be girls. Delaying marriages and deliveries, in addition to the unquestionable benefits for girls' psychological health, also protects them from the risks of HIV infection, childbirth death and medical conditions such as obstetric fistula. The EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation requires that the gender dimension be a primary objective in at least 75% of all new EU-funded projects. However, only 28% of projects take into account the gender dimension. The EU Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy states that the prevention of child marriage is a priority for the EESS and Member States.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – We are asking the Commission what steps will be taken to tackle the phenomenon of forced early or child marriage. We are faced with tragic examples of forced marriage involving minors, and we must realise that these are happening within the EU, which is extremely worrisome. Only 11 Member States have ratified the Istanbul Convention, which criminalises forced marriage, rightly recognising it as a human-rights violation and a form of gender-based violence. Forced early or child marriages have terrible implications and long-term consequences for girls. Health risks, abuse and the cutting-short of education are all common factors limiting empowerment, fuelling poverty, destroying childhood and depriving girls and women of freedom. During the past five years, gender equality was to have been a priority in at least 75% of all EU-funded development projects. However, last year a review showed that this was the case with only 28% of EU proposals. Clearly the Commission is not pushing this priority hard enough.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. In our European and Christian civilization, marriage is the protective institution of women and an essential guarantee for children. If this institution, the foundation of our societies, is threatened from within by ideologies that the Union likes to promote, the fact remains that a new threat comes from outside our borders. The massive immigration to which Europe has been subjected for decades has led people who are foreign to our culture. The destruction of our models of assimilation and integration, caused by the resignation of the elites of the spheres of public education, culture and the defence of national cohesions have fostered communitarianism and practices that we cannot accept. The early and forced marriage of young girls is therefore the consequence of these two dynamics and the evil at the source should be treated by defending the cultural integrity and unity of the nation states of Europe. The dignity and equal treatment of women are not foreign struggles to the peoples of Europe, on the contrary, we are the best defenders of it. It is not a question of universal rights, but it is an identity common to the nations of Europe.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. – Many girls are forced to marry, which not only constitutes a violation of the rights of the child and human rights, but is also a form of violence against women. These marriages violate girls' right to physical integrity, autonomous decision-making, a life free from violence and marital rape, but above all violate their right to be girls. Delaying marriages and deliveries, in addition to the unquestionable benefits for girls' psychological health, also protects them from the risks of HIV infection, childbirth death and medical conditions such as obstetric fistula. The EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation requires that the gender dimension be a primary objective in at least 75% of all new EU-funded projects. However, only 28% of projects take into account the gender dimension. The EU Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy states that the prevention of child marriage is a priority for the EESS and Member States.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. – Today, according to UNICEF, there are more than 700 million women who were married as children – one in three of them before the age of 15. The consequences are devastating for girls who have health problems and who endure sexual abuse, domestic violence and honour killings. Girls forced to marry are also forced out of school, which condemns them to poverty and discrimination. Too many girls in the world are being robbed of their childhood. Childhood marriage is not only a violation of children’s rights; it also constitutes violence against women. The time has come to act. We call on Member States to ratify the Council of Europe’s Istanbul Convention on combating violence against women, which recognises child marriage as a criminal offence. I approve of the fact that the European External Action Service and the Member States have made child marriage a priority in the EU Action Plan on human rights and democracy and in the Gender Action Plan.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. – With great sadness, we find that today many girls are forced to marry, which is not only a violation of the rights of the child and human rights, but also a form of violence against women. These marriages violate girls' right to physical integrity, autonomous decision-making and a life free from marital violence and rape, but above all violate their right to be girls. Delaying marriages and deliveries, in addition to the unquestionable benefits for girls' psychological health, also protects them from the risks of HIV infection, childbirth death and medical conditions such as obstetric fistula. The EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation requires that the gender dimension be a primary objective in at least 75% of all new EU-funded projects. However, only 28% of projects take into account the gender dimension. The EU Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy states that the prevention of child marriage is a priority for the EESS and Member States.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. Women's rights are being violated all over the world. The most terrible violation, if we wanted to make a list, concerns the right to choose whether, when and with whom to marry, especially since the victims of this violence are not women, but girls.  Europe can do a lot. First of all, to effectively follow up its action plan on gender equality in development cooperation policy and to link all types of aid to the objective of abolishing discrimination and the social and family subordination of women. But forced early marriages are not just a phenomenon in developing countries. Unfortunately and dramatically, the same logic is often applied in our countries, in Europe. We too, therefore, must carry out projects in support of those little girls who find the courage to flee and to rebel. Otherwise we risk them finding only the desperation to surrender or much worse.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – One of the objectives of the post-2015 development agenda is to strengthen the rights and position of women and girls. The implementation of this priority requires increased efforts to eliminate harmful practices affecting women's rights, such as early forced marriages, which affect 14 million girls a year. Forced marriages are an extreme form of violence against women and a major obstacle to achieving equality between women and men. In its 2006 resolution on women's immigration: the role and place of immigrant women in the European Union, the European Parliament stressed that "violations of human rights, including the rights of girls, in the form of forced marriages or other violations, cannot be justified on any cultural or religious grounds and should under no circumstances be tolerated". Issues related to women's rights, including forced marriages, must be addressed in the context of bilateral association agreements and other agreements with third countries. Educational programmes and information activities focusing on forced and arranged marriages are also crucial. Finally, it is necessary for all states to accede to the Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence in order to establish a common policy of protection and international cooperation for the defence of women's rights.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This oral question addresses an important issue, namely that of forced and early marriage of girls. For example, nearly one in nine girls worldwide is forcibly married, and in developing countries one in two children is born to a teenage mother. The cultural and social pressure on girls in these countries is considerable. Forced marriage often appears as the only possible future for these young girls, who are therefore reduced to an object when they are not simply sold as a commodity. However, this problem should not overshadow the fact that in France, as in other European countries, these practices also exist. Young girls living in the European Union are thus subjected to family pressures and forced married in the parents' country of origin. It is also necessary to denounce all the mutilating practices, such as female circumcision, which must be combated in France as in the European Union. Parliament must also address these issues.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. All girls have the right to a childhood in which they can play, enjoy the right to education, be protected from physical or psychological harm, abuse and exploitation. The practice of early and forced marriages is not only a violation of children's rights, but is also a form of violence against women. It violates the right of girls to physical integrity and to take decisions themselves, for example on family planning.  The 2010 EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development Cooperation provides for gender to be the main objective or a significant target of at least 75% of all new EU-funded projects.  We therefore call on the Commission to urge the Member States to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention. We call for strict rules to be introduced in association and cooperation agreements with third countries with a view to putting an end to child marriages, while at the same time providing for monitoring mechanisms aimed at eliminating the phenomenon of early and forced marriages. New information and awareness campaigns on the subject will also be needed, in partnership with other international organisations and partner countries, raising awareness among parents and community leaders.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. – A hundred years ago, forced marriage by young people and parents of children was a common practice throughout Europe. This was mostly for economic reasons. Fortunately, our world has changed since then, and while the EU can be criticised for many things, the fact is that our citizens enjoy their freedoms in one of the most advanced democracies in the world. And here's our responsibility to the world. Just as I am also calling for the EU not to provide material support in general, for example, to countries that regularly and seriously violate human rights, I am also calling for us to do everything we can to stop the forced marriage of child girls in third countries. These girls shouldn't be in the wedding bed, they should be in the schools. I am convinced that their uplift and support is the biggest catalyst for social and democratic reforms in the countries concerned.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – Millions of girls are forced to marry too young or someone they have not chosen each year. Girls who should play, go to school and develop as children in order to live a full life in the future must instead endure violence and brutality. In most cases, they are not allowed to continue studying in school and their mortality rates are high. By 2014, there were 700 million children under the age of 18. A WHO report released late last year reveals that suicide among teenage girls has exceeded mortality in terms of mortality, which was considered to date to be the most common cause of death among teenage girls worldwide. The EU must combat this violation of the rights of children and violence against women, and call on other countries to do so. To this end, it is necessary, in cooperation with third countries and regional organisations, to raise people's awareness through various campaigns, to support laws and policies aimed at eliminating the practice of child marriages, and to address this issue in trade, cooperation and associative agreements with third countries.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. – Many girls are forced to marry, which not only constitutes a violation of the rights of the child and human rights, but is also a form of violence against women. These marriages violate girls' right to physical integrity, autonomous decision-making, a life free from violence and marital rape, but above all violate their right to be girls. Delaying marriages and deliveries, in addition to the unquestionable benefits for girls' psychological health, also protects them from the risks of HIV infection, childbirth death and medical conditions such as obstetric fistula. The EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Training in Development Cooperation requires that the gender dimension be a primary objective in at least 75% of all new EU-funded projects. However, only 28% of projects take into account the gender dimension. The EU Strategic Framework on Human Rights and Democracy states that the prevention of child marriage is a priority for the EESS and Member States.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. – Girls' childhood ends immediately with a non-voluntary marriage. In our understanding of childhood and adolescence, the right to physical and psychological self-determination at any age is one of the most important fundamental rights. But many girls are deprived of this right by being forcibly married as children. This means that these girls are subjected to sexual and other physical violence at home, not to mention that any right to a self-determined life is forcibly taken away. We must finally act. I call on the Commission to take the important steps. To this end, the Istanbul Convention must be fully ratified in order to send out an international signal. For this, however, we also need a legal age of protection at European level, from which no marriages can be concluded. I also call on the Commission to support initiatives against forced marriage in all relations with third countries. Above all, however, we must also ensure that girls and women are strengthened in Europe and in third countries. To do so, they must have unfettered access to education, training and the labour market everywhere in order to preserve the chance of an economically self-determined life.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – The United Nations definition of forced marriage is clear and opposes marriage without the consent of both parties as well as forcing families or societies to marry. The fact is that girls, women and girls are the most often victims of forced marriage who are often deprived of the right to education and growing up, and are often victims of domestic violence, including honour killings.  Violence against women is a violation of women's human rights and is a brutal form of discrimination based on gender inequality. The Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence, also known as the Istanbul Convention, applies a similar approach and is a very valuable legal and political framework for the effective fight against violence against women at national and European level.  Europe as a world leader in many areas must be a role model for other countries in protecting women's rights, so we must insist that all Member States of the European Union not only sign the Istanbul Convention, but also implement it, as of the 23 countries only nine of them have implemented this strategic document on combating violence against women in the Union.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – Where do we draw the line between tradition and law? Can we go beyond tradition and culture the rules that we consider valid and which we strengthen by laws, normative acts and constitutions? Marriages between minors are a well-known problem in Europe among traditionalist communities. Many cases are recorded among Roma communities and many cases lead to abuses and risks against minors that we cannot accept as such. Tradition is no longer an argument when the safety, health and integrity of minors are called into question. The European Commission must intervene, including through the framework described by the Istanbul Convention to stop violence against women, together with the Member States, to stop forced child marriages. We need clear commitments from all the European institutions against a phenomenon that stops the natural development of children in Europe, which takes away the fundamental right to a normal life, freedom and equality for many minors. All children are entitled to a happy and carefree childhood. All children have the right to education and protection, and the European Union has an obligation to make this regulatory framework accessible to all children, regardless of ethnicity or cultural affiliation.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Premature marriage of girls and forced marriages continue to be widespread worldwide. Despite international commitments, this problem significantly reduces human rights – especially women and children – and hinders development and poverty reduction. As part of the EU Strategy for Human Rights 2012-2014, the prevention of child marriage has been identified as one of the priorities of the Member States and the European External Action Service. This important commitment has been renewed in the EU Action Plan on Human Rights and Democracy 2015-2019, one of the objectives of which is to address child marriage and premature and forced marriages. I support the European Parliament's strong position on combating all forms of discrimination and violence against women, including forced marriages.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I wanted to mention one phenomenon that I noted in the Czech Republic concerning the discussion of the Commission's report, which assessed the effectiveness and effectiveness of the Framework Decision on combating terrorism.  In the context of the public debate in the Czech Republic, as well as the debate among Czech politicians, there was more or less no uniform level of view on whether or not Czech law contains sufficient sanctions against the phenomenon of so-called foreign fighters, i.e. whether Czech law allows the punishment of, in principle, the mere preparation of a crime. The debate was simply divided between criminal law experts and politicians.  I, listening to the debate, realized how serious the matter was. It is a punishment for those who leave Europe and then try to prepare for the fight in the service of the Islamic State. I think that the Commission should adapt this matter uniformly and prepare a directive. And that's more or less what I wanted to challenge her to do.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – [The Member spoke in Latgale.]

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I have repeatedly raised the issue of Germany's debts to Greece in the plenary session of the European Parliament. Firstly, the war reparations awarded by the Paris International Peace Conference in 1946, totalling EUR 108 billion, plus interest. Secondly, it is the compulsory owner-occupied loan, amounting to EUR 54 billion, plus interest. Thirdly, it is about the reparations of the relatives of the thousands of victims executed by the Nazi occupying troops. Fourthly, it is the return of the archaeological treasures looted by the Nazis. 70 years after the end of World War II, Germany refuses to sign a peace treaty with Greece. We therefore call on Germany to proceed with the repayment of its above debts to Greece, totalling EUR 162 billion, plus interest, and to launch the signing of a peace treaty with the Hellenic Republic, as it is inconceivable that two countries of the European Union have not concluded a peace treaty with each other since the end of World War II.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, the European Union and the Member States do not yet have an effective response to what is happening in our forests. Namely, the death of tame chestnut due to the action of pests and due to the action of the fungus means the destruction of biodiversity in our forests.  How important tame chestnut is for biodiversity, I need not mention further, but also how important it is for many rural regions of the European Union and how positively tame chestnut affects the local economy and all that it means for rural areas of the European Union, I would like to emphasize in particular.  That is why I call on the European Commission, member states, regional and local authorities to make further efforts to protect the tame chestnut that is disappearing today in 16 COUNTRIES of the European Union in such a way that the pest acts against it, and in the 24 member states of the European Union there is a fungus against sweet chestnut.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). – The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union begins with reference to the ever closer union of the European peoples. However, in the last years of the crisis, the dominant political forces, pushed by the capital markets, have abandoned this vision and are attempting to cultivate rivalries between peoples, with the ultimate aim of de-inging work for the benefit of capital at European level. Their planning is currently being implemented with particular intensity at the expense of the societies of the heavily indebted states, where over-indebtedness is used as a lever to push for the imposition of so-called structural reforms summarised in the deregulation of the economy. Thus, each individual worker is left without cover in the face of the power of capital, while, more generally, the mechanisms for protecting the socially weaker are deconstructed. The same will then be extended to the other countries on the pretext of competitiveness. The people must unite in their resistance to the reactionary attack of the postmodern authoritarianism of the capital markets.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – The dairy sector has been and still remains one of the cornerstones of the Lithuanian agricultural sector, but the analysis of the milk market situation over the last two decades shows that the cooperation in this lithuanian agricultural sector is not strong enough and does not withstand competition from raw milk imported from european Union countries. Even co-operative farmers are unable to accumulate sufficient bargaining power and negotiate a decent price for the milk they produce. One of the reasons is the oligopoly of milk collectors and traders, which are subject only to regulation, but such regulation is limited by the common organisation of the European Union milk market. In view of today's situation, it is simply necessary to enable states to regulate the raw milk market more or to take responsibility for regulatory measures at European Union level. The Lithuanian Government has proposed a law that significantly increases the regulation of the milk market, but does not allow regulatory opponents under European Union law to adopt it.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Mr President, Romania's entry into the Schengen area is not only a necessity, but also an act of justice. The recent waves of migrants demonstrate that there are countries of the European Union which, although they belong to the Schengen area, have serious problems securing their borders, with the European authorities obliged to take urgent measures in the spirit of human solidarity, of course, by the way, by setting quotas for migrants for each country. However, it is incomprehensible why Romania is denied access to the Schengen area, although its borders are very secure, meeting the technical conditions, being a security provider in south-eastern Europe. We have obligations and we fulfill them, but we do not understand why our rights are not respected. And Romanians need strong answers. When will the principle of mutual solidarity also be applied in matters of rights and not just obligations? I believe that Romania's entry into the Schengen area must be done immediately, otherwise those responsible will prove that double language is at home here in Europe, and we do not want that.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: – On 8 May, we commemorated the 70th anniversary of the end of the Second World War in Europe. The individual Member States honoured the victims with all due respect and piety, but I expected the representatives of the European Union, the European Parliament, the Commission, the Council to come up with a proposal on how we would use this anniversary to send a clear common signal, a message, to the people of Europe, but also to the whole world. We have squandered the right opportunity to say, by joint declaration, at a time when xenophobia, extremism, discrimination and intolerance are on the rise in Europe and there are too many war conflicts, that we do not respect and tolerate violence and we always and everywhere promote peaceful solutions. The European Union was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2012 and quite rightly so. That is why we had the anniversary of the end of the Second World War in Europe to take advantage of and reach out above all to the young generation, pointing out that wars have only dead heroes, but living orphans, widows, incomplete families and long-lasting wounds on the body and soul of survivors.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Mr President, in October 2013 the Indian police detained 25 anti-piracy security guards, among them Estonians and UK and Ukrainian citizens. In July 2014 the Madras High Court decided to drop the charges against the security guards, a decision which has been appealed by the Indian police. The men have not been allowed to leave India during the proceedings, despite the fact that they were acquitted. Some of them have serious health problems, and their economic situation is disastrous. The Supreme Court considered the case in April this year but once again has delayed a decision – until July, since the court is on summer vacation. It is a matter of extreme concern that the men have been held in India for such a long time, especially since the charges were dropped against them almost a year ago, and it is unacceptable that the Indian courts are stalling with a decision beyond reasonable limits. This issue must be addressed at all levels in EU meetings with India until it is resolved and the Estonian and UK citizens are back home.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – The conditions that the communication company Movistar-Telefónica wants to impose on its contracts led workers to strike indefinitely. In Galicia, it began on April 14 to stop the brutal precariouss that brings with it the new contract.  With the productivity system that Movistar imposes, it can happen that workers suffer wage decreases and even dismissals because, even working the hours set by collective agreement, they may not reach the minimum points required per day to each worker to meet this productivity. This system requires you to spend many extra hours without pay and puts safety at risk at work. We are talking about a company that, in the first quarter of 2015, tripled profits compared to the same period in 2014.  We must denounce that these situations sat in the labour reforms that the European Union is imposing in the States affected by the Troika, and also in the tolerance of the Spanish Government and the Galician Government to large companies.  Enough of precariousness. Let us put an end to these conditions of slavery and return to policies that guarantee the rights of workers.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: – So, it is worrying that, in the context of austerity measures, the Slovenian Public Fund for Human Resources Development and Scholarships has shrunk to such an extent that the funds have been reduced to such an extent, students will no longer be able to receive an Erasmus + scholarship supplement of €150 per month, and study exchange or practice abroad represents a significant financial stash, so many students can only afford it with financial assistance. The sad fact is that, because of the unfed material situation, many have been unable to exchange abroad before. It can be concluded that withdrawing the allowance will make the situation worse, and let us recall that the Eurostudent survey in 2013 showed that only 2 per cent of students went on the exchange, but many more wanted, 18 percent. The reasons, of course, are pure financial. However, a 2014 study on the effects of the EU Erasmus Student Exchange Programme shows that graduates with international experience have a much better position on the market. I therefore appeal to the competent Slovenian institutions to reconsider the consequences of the revised conditions and the replacement of the co-financing short.com.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Mr President, today in my one-minute speech I would like to inform you about the curious opinions of Czech President Miloš Zeman on Russian sanctions. During his visit to Moscow in May, Czech President Zeman said that he anticipated an end to the sanctions against Russia by the end of this year. It is not clear where the President got this idea from. As far as I am aware, the EU is not planning to do any such thing. It is possible that the President’s words are not founded on truth. However, the man has in the past quoted articles which were never written, so in this case it could be that he misheard something which was never said. This is, however, a serious matter. Can the High Representative or the Commission say whether the EU is really planning to lift its sanctions against Russia by the end of this year?

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: – Mr President, efficient execution of the EU’s refugee agenda requires the full backing of all Member States. One particular Member State’s government, however, is challenging its bases – those of European values, solidarity and humanity. As we heard from Hungarian Prime Minister Orbán himself at the previous sitting of this Parliament, his government insists on undermining current EU efforts by dealing with all migration and refugee issues within exclusive national competence, rejecting current and future immigrants, and using arguments for so doing that smack of nationalism and populism. The most disgusting aspect of his attack on the Commission’s proposals is the fact that Mr Orbán launched this provocation purely to serve his internal political goals – to cover up recent corruption scandals that his proxies are closely involved in. In response to such challenges from the Council, I urge Parliament to use its full political weight to back the Commission in this important effort.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: – Mr President, the European Union currently produces only 2% of the coal it consumes, so the rest of the third countries matter.  At the same time, however, the European Union promotes the silent death of entire mining basins in Asturias, of León, Palencia, Aragon and, to give them one example: at the end of 1993, there were more than 30,000 miners throughout the Spanish state, while in 2011 there were only 4,000 left, not counting the indirect posts of auxiliary industries and economic activity that were lost.  Our position is that the end of aid to the sector in 2018 has only taken into account economic and non-social and labour criteria. The market is allowed to act, that is, when it says "buy cheaper coal" it refers to multinationals abusing cheaper and precarious labour in other countries, and leaving entire counties dependent on that industry without a future, precisely there, where Europe's highest unemployment rates are. Jobs, population settlement and security of supply must ultimately be guaranteed for the future of thousands of people, and to do so, we demand the continuation of the aid of the Miner funds — in Spain they are not supporting this energy policy. We ask that we continue with these funds from criteria of social and environmental sustainability that allow renewable energy to be joined with the mining sector.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, the subject of my speech is refugees. I want to emphasise my position and express my opposition to mandatory quotas for the deployment of asylum seekers. I am convinced that the Czech Republic and other countries are and will be in solidarity, but voluntarily, not by being outvoted.  However, the event of the day reminded us of one particular refugee. His name is Hartmut Tautz. In August 1986, when he was 18 years old, this citizen of what was then East Germany was torn apart by military dogs on the Czechoslovak-Austrian border while trying to escape to the free world and died. Today, an installation commemorating this horrific event involving his mother and sister was unveiled on the esplanada in front of Parliament. However, some members of the radical left are calling for its removal. The pretext is the visualization of blood, but it is hypocritical, since all totalitarian regimes are based on blood shedding. My colleagues and I are fighting and hope that the statue will last here until 2 June, when it is to be taken to the National Gallery in the Czech Republic. In today's debate on refugees, this work of art is a memento to me, standing before Parliament and reminding us of a time when Europe has changed, it is free, but the world around us is safe.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, professional football was born in my constituency 127 years ago, when Aston Villa and Stoke City and the mighty West Bromwich Albion got together with a handful of other football clubs to form the Football League. The beautiful game went on to become the world’s dominant sport, but now the beautiful game is being dragged through the mud, brought into disrepute by Sepp Blatter’s disgraceful chairmanship of FIFA, which has become a discredited organisation, riven as we now know with criminality and money-laundering at the very top. It defies belief and possibility that the autocratic ‘Don Blatterone’ never knew what was going on – in any other organisation he would have been gone decades ago. Ordinary football fans that I represent and that we all represent are outraged and feel tainted by what is going on. What is the matter with these people, when 60 migrant workers a day are said to die for every game of the Qatar World Cup? And what is the matter with us that we stand by and do nothing about it?

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, this afternoon we were able to hear from UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon talking about the importance of the rule of law and human rights in building a fairer society, a better world. But in the European Union itself the rule of this law is in doubt: companies such as Coca-Cola violate with impunity the court rulings against them, denying the right to full readmission of illegally laid-off workers. Unfortunately, this is not an isolated case: a few kilometers from this factory, dismissed workers from the Polytechnic University of Madrid and Telemadrid are living in a very similar situation, since the sentences recognizing their right to effective work, as well as the violation of fundamental rights, are breached in the face of the indifference of the Government and the media.  The European Parliament cannot remain silent in this situation, it must say loud and clear that when workers' rights are not respected, there is no democracy.
