From here, our support for those who organize and fight for justice and for judicial judgments to be served.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Mr President, injustice is a concomitant phenomenon in our lives and manifests itself in many forms. But the most horrific is experienced by poor and socially weak biological families across Europe who are being unfairly taken from children. When I studied cases that take place in Norway, for example, I was frankly very appalled. This injustice is all the worse because it is happening in a democratic country that is doused everywhere with human rights and which is closely linked to the EU within the European Economic Area.  Personally, I am very sensitive to injustice, which is what is driven me to fight the injustice that is happening to European families in Norway, so I would like to call on European citizens to take part in a Europe-wide demonstration against the social system in their cities on 30 May. We must fight for integrity and transparency in the protection of children and respect European values fighting for human rights.

name: Paul BRANNEN
text: – Mr President, as a direct consequence of the Conservative Party’s general election victory, the United Kingdom is now facing an in-out referendum on its European Union membership. This state of affairs is bad news for the UK agriculture sector, it is bad news for the UK food sector, and it is bad news for jobs in the United Kingdom. 60% of UK food exports go to the EU. If the current free trade arrangement was replaced with the current EU tariff levels, then the UK agriculture and food sectors would be looking at tariffs ranging from 11% to 48%. Even at the lowest tariff level, this would kill the competitiveness of the UK agricultural and food sectors stone dead. The time has now come for the UK farming and food sectors to rise up and, with a clear, loud and distinctive voice, make the case for Britain staying in the European Union. The EU is good for the UK’s agriculture sector, it is good for the UK’s food sector, and it is good for UK jobs.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: – Mr President, the European Union is developing, but in economic, social and infrastructure terms, the development gaps are being reduced far too slowly. However, I believe that cohesion remains the Union's most important project. In this respect, I would like to make a plea for the effective and rapid adoption of one of the most complex strategic and programmatic projects in the Central and Eastern Europe region. The idea of infrastructure development in the border areas of the European Union on the basis of a strategy must also start from the need to bring east-west closer and to reduce the obvious infrastructure gaps between these macro-regions. My call to the European Commission is to have a vision of developing and supporting infrastructure in countries that are on the border of the European Union and implicitly to support those Member States that have strategies and projects in this regard.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, in order to turn Europe into a circular economy, boost recycling, secure access to raw materials and create jobs and economic growth, the Commission adopted a Waste Framework Directive that sets the recycling targets for the Member States. Unfortunately, Romania has a landfill rate exceeding 90% and is very far from reaching the targets. Considering the low rates of compliance with the directive in Romania, I would point out that urgent measures need to be taken to put Romania on the green map. Citizens are willing to participate in the selective collection of packaging if they are properly informed and if there is proper collection infrastructure. Penalising waste disposal to landfill through a dumping tax, improving sanitation law and enhancing cooperation between all those involved in recycling systems are steps that need to be taken, and they must be taken into account for the implementation of a much-needed strategic view of Romania’s waste management system.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: – Dear Mr President, the new Digital Single Market Strategy has been met with mixed feelings. One of the points at issue in it is the way in which VAT is taxed. I believe that the one-stop-stay option will actually help reduce the administrative burden and make it easier for companies. The situation is far more complicated when it comes to VAT on books. The gaps in European legislation here are most visible, as evidenced by the recent judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union on the application of a reduced VAT rate to e-books in France and Luxembourg. I believe that this discrimination is inadmissible and unjustified and I call on the Commission to review the overall legislative framework as soon as possible. My country, for example, is one of the few that does not take advantage of the opportunity to reduce the tax on books. It currently stands at 20% and one of the highest in Europe. I believe that the European Union must be a model and corrective to ensure easy access to culture for its citizens.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: – Mr. President, recently Commissioner Jourová, presenting the annual report of the European Hazardous Product Alarm System, said that among such products, as much as 28% are toys, 60% of which are imported from China. They are the second most common safety risk to the consumer after motor vehicles. Worryingly, the number of such toys is increasing year after year. Thus, in 2014, 70 more types of toys were withdrawn from the market than in 2013. While the Commission likes to boast that Rapex works well, it should be taken into account that only after a person has purchased and their child has the product been withdrawn should it be taken into account. For example, if a child is exposed to a chemical from clothing or a toy or eats harmful baby food, the damage has already been done. It is extremely important to protect the youngest on the market. Although the European Commission's blacklist has determined direct sales to youngest consumers through unfair trading practices, children are still swamped with ads addressed only to them, and are being pulled up their sleeves in shopping centres. Protecting the most vulnerable consumers should be a priority for us, and the regulations we have need to come to life in practice.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the discussion on this item on the agenda.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the explanations of vote.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, I support the Commission's initiative to extend the co-financing of the 'School Milk' and 'School Fruit and Vegetables' programmes. I welcome the emphasis on healthy eating habits of children and the promotion of local agriculture, which is linked to the programme. I dare add one more aspect, and that's social. In many countries, including mine, this programme has a positive impact on children from poorer backgrounds by providing them with snacks that they would not otherwise have. However, I fundamentally disagree with the narrowing of the range only to fresh fruit, vegetables and drinking milk. The current composition of the assortment, which also includes juices, purees, yoghurts, cheeses and others, is very well used in my country, the Czech Republic.  I therefore supported the amendment to keep this range, i.e. to extend the range to dairy products, including cocoa. On the other hand, I do not think that we should order Member States to implement the programme and what to deliver to schools. The principle of subsidiarity should apply here. Since these amendments were not adopted, I abstained afterwards and did not support the proposal as a whole.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Mr President, I am very sorry for wasting our time in explaining my vote, but I promised my daughter I would explain why I voted against chocolate milk at schools. I will now switch to Estonian. I was able to vote in favour of Mr Tarabella's report with a calm heart at last, because, earlier, when the French Government had promised to sell Mistral-type attack platforms to Russia, which attacks neighbours and takes away apples, bananas and milk glasses from schoolchildren, rarely leaving these children alive, I had no confidence that it would make sense to vote for this report. But today, when we know that Russia and France have overcome this problem, I was happy to vote in favour of it, and perhaps, if my children behave well, I will also promise them some chocolate milk at home.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, promoting the consumption of fruits, vegetables and dairy products is essential to promote healthier habits in children and adolescents, as well as to promote local production of these foods.  I abstained in the vote on this report because, while supporting its objectives, I miss a political commitment to give the European Union a holistic approach in this area. On the contrary, I regret that agricultural and livestock production is liberalized to forced marches as seen in order to milk quotas, allowing it to be the great agribusiness and distribution chains that ultimately impose the population's eating habits on the basis of their own business strategies.  We have repeatedly denounced how the consolidation of liberalized agri-food has a very negative impact on the incomes of smallholder farmers and the traditional ways of life of rural communities, but it also has serious public health consequences that should not be ignored.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Mr President, I believe that support for this programme to promote fruit and vegetables and dairy in schools is important because it allows precisely healthy eating habits based on fresh fruits and vegetables and also in the consumption of milk and dairy products.  It seems to me that this has been a good space to promote food from organic farming, bring boys and girls from schools closer to production and get up close and personal with the daily work of peasants. And it is also an important space to promote direct purchase from schools to local peasantization. But I abstained from voting precisely because these latter aspects have little or no presence in this programme and, moreover, because I think that this should focus solely and exclusively on fresh produce and admit much less processed product.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, I voted in favour of the decision on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit, fruit and vegetables and milk to educational institutions, as I believe that at a time when Mercel austerity has filled the European Union with armies of unemployed people, the children of poor European citizens should have even this minimum opportunity to be able to participate in free fruit distribution programmes. , fruit and vegetables and dairy products.  But the funds allocated to these programmes are crumbs considering that the European Union has allocated EUR 1.6 trillion to rescue the banks. This applies even more to Greece, as I analysed a few hours ago in my speech on this subject. So in order to tackle malnutrition in Greece and southern Europe, the European Union must abandon its policy of austerity. In Greece in particular, the shameful debt must be erased, the memorandums abolished and the troika evicted.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, how am I supposed to vote on this? We have a subsidy scheme which should be the preserve of individual nations. This is taxpayers’ money being spent at EU level, but it is already in the EU’s hands, and this proposal could possibly make the scheme less bad than it is at the moment. So I supported some of the amendments, for example to make sure that it refers only to fresh fruit and vegetables and not to processed and chocolate milk and everything else that we have heard about this evening. Then I have to consider as well the UK’s interests, as it seems we are in the milk scheme but not in the fruit and vegetables scheme, yet it is all bunched together in one vote. So if I vote ‘no’ I do absolutely nothing to make a bad scheme better. If, on the other hand, I vote ‘yes’, then I am legitimising the idea that these things should be happening at a European Union level, not by individual nations. So what else can I do but abstain?

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of opening interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools because I believe that these programmes are essential for introducing healthy eating habits into children. The amendments adopted today provide a good basis for negotiation with the Council by improving some aspects of the Commission's proposal, such as the distribution of olive oil with accompanying educational measures. They also reduce the weight of the historical criterion for the allocation of funds in the case of the milk program, a criterion that does not apply in the case of fruit and vegetables and which our Delegation has opposed from the outing point.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal to streamline two separate schemes, the School Milk Scheme and the Fruit and Vegetables in School Scheme, makes sense. The promotion of healthy eating among children is very important. Recognising that these schemes are in place, Parliament should be endeavouring to make them as uncomplicated and as fair as possible. Funds should be allocated according to the proportion and numbers of children in each country, and should be targeted at promoting local produce. The promotion of fresh produce, and especially the consumption fresh milk, which is in decline, should be prioritised. The principle of subsidiarity should mean that key decisions are made at national and regional level, as it is here that the needs of local communities can best be addressed. I have a fundamental disagreement with committee amendments which were adopted and which support more funds being spent on advertising EU involvement in the scheme, rather than on the promotion of healthy eating. This is not the most beneficial use of funds. I supported amendments calling for fairer and more efficient use of the funds, allowing flexibility at national level. However, these were not adopted. Therefore I abstained on this vote.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it meets two objectives that are dear to me. First of all, the first virtue of this decision is to merge two programs, which are currently separate, in favour of the consumption of milk and fruit in schools. This is in line with better regulation. Finally, this decision has the effect of increasing funds for the promotion and consumption of local food products among children. This will have the effect of supporting European agricultural sectors which are currently experiencing serious difficulties.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this decision proposing better synergy between the School Fruit Scheme and the School Milk Scheme. Better coordination of the schemes and a unified political approach will increase their efficiency and will bring more positive results. Promoting the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk at European educational establishments will not only provide the nutrients and vitamins that children need but will also help to shape healthier eating patterns, starting at a young age, and to fight the rising incidence of obesity.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to improve the supply of fruit, vegetables and milk to schools. The school milk scheme has been in operation since 1977 and the corresponding fruit and vegetable programme has been in operation since 2009. EUR 22 million | children suffer from being overweight, and adolescents consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended daily rate of fruit and vegetables. The new rules aim to merge EU programmes to promote the use of these products in schools. EU Member States are encouraged to allocate between 10% and 20% of the combined fruit, vegetables and milk delivery programme to education, for example through farm visits or the supply of local products such as honey and dried fruit. In addition, a eur 20 million loan is proposed. To increase the financing of the part of the milk supply programme, which should reach EUR 100 million annually, the amount of the milk supply programme is eur 100 million. Euro.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In approving Marc Tarabella's report, the European Parliament is in favour of new legislation that should allow simple and free distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools in all European countries throughout the year. The aim is multiple: healthy food from an early age, education around food, fight against obesity but also promotion and promotion of the short circuit and local and regional products. No less than thirty million children will benefit in the EU. A very nice initiative by Marc which I of course fully supported.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on the opening and mandate of inter-institutional negotiations on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) 1306/2013 with regard to the programme of aid for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools should allow the distribution of the above products to continue to be distributed to young children aged six to ten. There are, of course, some shortcomings in this text, but this proposal by Parliament has three major consequences. Socially, it helps reduce child malnutrition and provides all children with access to food. From a health point of view, this text promotes the fight against childhood obesity and encourages healthy eating. Finally, at the economic level, it provides support to agricultural sectors in crisis, particularly in ultramarine regions such as Guadeloupe or Martinique. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European programme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools has never worked fully due to over-bureaucratisation and questionable way of implementing them. I believe that with some corrections it could be a good tool for the food education of children and a possibility for some fruit and vegetable and milk supply chains to find distribution space in our territories in collaboration with our educational facilities. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposed text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of opening interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools because I believe that these programmes are essential for introducing healthy eating habits into children. The amendments adopted today provide a good basis for negotiation with the Council by improving some aspects of the Commission's proposal, such as the distribution of olive oil with accompanying educational measures. They also reduce the weight of the historical criterion for the allocation of funds in the case of the milk program, a criterion that does not apply in the case of fruit and vegetables and which our Delegation has opposed from the outing point.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. Of course, I supported the proposed decision to open interinstitutional negotiations, as it provides a quicker path to the adoption of the regulation and thus to provide healthy food to our youngest. The two schemes, which are merging in the proposed regulation into a joint aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions, aim to encourage children to have healthier eating habits. Given the exceptional importance of this scheme, supported by at least EUR 230 million, and its early implementation, today's decision by the European Parliament is a clear signal to Member States to enter into negotiations on that regulation more responsibly and to adopt it as soon as possible with the EP. This will allow the implementation of the common scheme to be implemented and meet the interests and health of primary school children across the EU. I am pleased that the proposed regulation pays greater attention to educating children about the importance of a healthy diet and the importance of products of local or regional origin, such as honey, olives, olives, olive oil, dried fruit, etc.  For Slovenia, where an exceptionally small number of schools have been included in the aid schemes for milk, it is essential that the proposed regulation be adopted as soon as possible, as this would allow Slovenian schools to draw on almost EUR 300 000 of European funds per year for the free distribution of milk and milk products to primary school children.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ One in three children in the EU is either overweight or obese. Studies have shown that children also consume too little calcium. Adults, however, consume only 30 to 50 percent of the recommended amounts of fruits and vegetables and more than half are obese. Unhealthy diets lead to the development of severe diseases that are a burden on the individual, his family and society as a whole. School fruit and milk schemes are an excellent program that creates healthy eating habits from an early age. Likewise, farmers are allowed to place their domestic products directly on school kitchen tables.  The regulation also proposes to reduce administrative barriers to participation in the programme, as a 2011 REPORT by the ECA showed that schools, suppliers and manufacturers have a lot of bureaucratic and organisational barriers if they want to join the programme. My amendment was also adopted, asking croatia to be excluded from the historical criteria adopted at a session of the EP Agriculture Committee.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal to streamline two separate schemes, the School Milk Scheme and the Fruit and Vegetables in School Scheme, makes sense. The promotion of healthy eating among children is important and laudable – although, in reality, Member States should not need an EU scheme to prioritise initiatives aimed at making our children healthier. Recognising that these schemes are in place, Parliament should be endeavouring to make them as uncomplicated and as fair as possible. Funds should be allocated according to the proportion and numbers of children in each country, and should be targeted at promoting local produce. The promotion of fresh produce, and especially the consumption fresh milk, which is in decline, should be prioritised. The principle of subsidiarity should mean that key decisions are made at national and regional level, as it is here that the needs of local communities can best be addressed. I have a fundamental disagreement with the committee amendments which were passed supporting more funds being spent on advertising EU involvement in the scheme, rather than on the promotion of healthy eating. I do not believe is the most beneficial use of funds and for this reason I voted against.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this decision because I believe it is essential that our children have access to a healthy and balanced type of nutrition and it is extremely important that schools, where children eat at least one meal a day, are able to provide it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Health is essentially linked to a healthy diet. Many studies show that eating habits that are acquired in childhood and early adolescence affect us for the rest of our lives. It is therefore particularly important that children and young people have a balanced diet to reduce the risks of improper adult nutrition.  There has been a slow but steady decline in consumption of fresh milk and fruit and vegetables in europe's youth population. If we want to reverse this trend, we must intervene with projects to accompany proper food education in schools, in particular by supporting regional products, fruit and vegetable and dairy production typical of the territories, thus accompanying the issue of health education with that of promoting the agri-food riches of the regions of the Union. Parliament must promote strong action which, without increasing the administrative burden on schools and local authorities, encourages the implementation of food education programmes and the spread of drinking milk and fresh fruit and vegetables in school canteens.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: In writing. This European programme aims to continue to fund the distribution of milk, vegetables and fruit (including bananas) to children aged six to ten. The programme has three major implications: - social impact: by encouraging access to these foodstuffs among children of all population groups, this programme helps to combat child malnutrition, which continues to increase as a result of the crisis; - health impact: this programme contributes to the fight against obesity and, more broadly, against the eating habits responsible for an ever-increasing number of serious diseases in children; - economic impact: by supporting milk, vegetable, fruit and banana producers from Guadeloupe and Martinique, the programme provides additional opportunities for sectors in crisis. It is worth noting, however, the contradiction that the European Commission is in supporting crisis-based sectors in the outermost regions, while at the same time negotiating a free trade treaty with the United States that will focus on health, social and economic dumping. I voted for this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I was in favour of the proposal to open interinstitutional negotiations to amend the aid scheme for schools to supply fruit, vegetables and milk, as I see a drastic decrease in the consumption of fruit and dairy products among young people and the existing aid programmes have not achieved the desired success. The bushy bureaucracy at Member State level and the lack of capacity to extend the objectives of the programmes to the level of trainers are some of the obstacles that have made it difficult to implement aid schemes. Today, we are facing an avalanche of processed products and fast food, which has moved young people away from fresh produce. I believe that aid schemes should be extended to younger ages as it is essential to train nutritional behaviour starting with the pre-school level. I believe that the aim pursued by aid schemes should be extended to trainers by allocating a significant percentage of educational measures. Information programmes should cover trainers and parents. Limiting them only to the level of educational institutions will not produce the expected results. The main objective of school programmes should be to support domestic producers and promote local agricultural potential. I stress that encouraging local producers contributes to the development of short production chains and promotes the consumption of domestic products and agricultural products.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure because it will help our farmers, who are already affected in this particular sector by the insane exchange of sanctions between Europe and Russia. It is a pity that the Socialist rapporteur has not been able to make the most of the scope of the measure and has wanted to reserve a proportion of the aid to the American banana multinationals. We should be more favouring producers at zero kilometres and not global food trade groups.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of opening interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools because I believe that these programmes are essential for introducing healthy eating habits into children. The amendments adopted today provide a good basis for negotiation with the Council by improving some aspects of the Commission's proposal, such as the distribution of olive oil with accompanying educational measures. They also reduce the weight of the historical criterion for the allocation of funds in the case of the milk program, a criterion that does not apply in the case of fruit and vegetables and which our Delegation has opposed from the outing point.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. A healthy and balanced diet must be promoted in the EU to counter the risks of obesity and other diseases linked to poor eating habits. To do this, we need to start from an early age by educating children in schools. Programmes to promote "milk in school" and "fruit and vegetables in school" serve this purpose. Until then they were separated. The European Commission is now proposing to merge them. This will simplify administrative procedures and optimize the effectiveness of both programs. However, it is important to ensure that programs do not lose their original value during the merger process. I voted in favour of the decision to start inter-institutional negotiations on the scheme to support the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the draft law for a common legal and financial framework for milk and fruit in schools in the European Union, which will reduce the administrative burden by seeking to promote the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk among young Europeans. The European Union and the Member States must invest more effort and money in promoting healthy eating among children. I think it is essential to promote a balanced diet from an early age, thus combating childhood obesity and teaching young citizens to learn about food and its origin and to familiarise themselves with their taste by re-approaching young consumers with local producers.  Another result that this vote has achieved is to offer an alternative market to these products. I would remind you that the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is declining in the EU, with negative consequences for Europeans, despite the fact that a healthy and balanced diet is the basis of good health.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. – The proposal to streamline two separate schemes, the School Milk Scheme and the Fruit and Vegetables in School Scheme, makes sense. The promotion of healthy eating among children is important and laudable – although, in reality, Member States should not need an EU scheme to prioritise initiatives aimed at making our children healthier. Funds should be allocated according to the proportion and numbers of children in each country and should be targeted at promoting local produce. The principle of subsidiarity should mean that key decisions are made at national and regional level as it is here that the needs of local communities can best be addressed. As shadow rapporteur on this matter, I had a fundamental disagreement with committee amendments which would see more funds being spent on advertising EU involvement in the scheme, rather than on the promotion of healthy eating. I do not believe this is the most beneficial use of funds. Furthermore, I had tabled a number of amendments which would have allowed the scheme to be fairer while minimising wastage of funds and allowing increased flexibility at national level. Because the committee amendments to which I objected were adopted, I voted against the report.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Tarabella's report on the financing of the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and school milk. This vote makes it possible to start negotiations with the Member States on the merger of the two existing programmes for the distribution of these products: the milk programme introduced in 1977 and the fruit programme established in 2009. Unfortunately, consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk is declining in the 28 Member States. On the contrary, more than twenty million European children are overweight and adolescents eat on average between 30% and 50% of the recommended daily intake of fruit and vegetables. I believe that we must promote healthy eating habits for our children.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Food safety and proper nutrition of children must be a priority for the European Union. According to the latest statistics, the phenomenon of childhood obesity is constantly increasing in all Member States. In order to try to respond to this growing problem, healthy eating habits geared to the conscious choice of genuine and healthy foods must be promoted.  I fully agree with the objective pursued by the programme voted on because it promotes, from a young age, the consumption of healthy food and agricultural products and, above all, because it encourages, through school, proper food education.  I believe a great deal in this type of action and I hope that the Member States will be able to allocate additional national resources to support the actions provided for in the European programme. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The following measure highlights the desire to strengthen the distribution of dairy products and food such as fruit and vegetables to schools, in order to enhance healthy and genuine nutrition, given that the sharp decline in food consumption of the various products is causing severe obesity and other food problems. In addition, the aim is to rationalise the planning and financing procedures so that the objective of a single chapter can be achieved. I found the request interesting and proactive for the sake of our students. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of funding the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools because in recent years there has been a dramatic decline in their consumption, especially among the smallest. Children are not encouraged to consume these foods, which are fundamental to our well-being, because it is more convenient to offer them only highly processed and added foods, which have the advantage of being particularly pleasant, but this phenomenon results in an increase in cases of childhood obesity. I hope that with the adoption of this measure it will be possible to improve the nutrition of children attending primary schools, to make them aware of the importance of healthy, varied and balanced nutrition, which does not mean uneasing, and to introduce accompanying educational measures to bring children closer to agriculture. Many of them have lost contact with nature and animals. In this way, they could begin to get closer to issues such as sustainable production and the fight against food waste.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this proposal for a Regulation which comes together in a single framework two programmes aimed at schools that until now were separated: the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and the milk distribution scheme.  I am voting in favour of opening up the mandate for interinstitutional negotiations because I believe that this new common regime will simplify the administrative procedures of the two programmes by reducing burdens for both national authorities and schools and suppliers. I applaud the educational aspect of the Programme which encourages young people to have healthy drinking habits by bringing them closer to agriculture and educating them to the origin of food, as well as the increase of EUR 20 million for the Milk Programme, allowing, during the transition to future allocation criteria, no Member State to lose funding.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. I support the European Commission's proposal to focus on two 'core products', namely fresh fruit and vegetables (including bananas) and milk. European action aims to tackle poor eating habits and obesity in children more effectively and to strengthen the pedagogical aspects of the two programmes. It is important that children are encouraged at school to eat a healthy diet and to get used to healthy eating habits.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 School milk and fruit schemes operate in different forms in the Member States of the European Union and their success depends largely on the dietary habits established in the Member States and on the conditions under which meals are financed in educational establishments.  In the light of the support schemes known in the Central European region and the latest data on them, I can say that the objective of pooling programmes and applying uniform implementing rules in the Commission's original proposal is difficult to achieve. The latter does not take into account the specificities of the Member States.  The functioning and development of support programmes is important, but the most important focus should be in the future on the benefit of as many institutions and children as possible. I cannot accept the proposal in its current form because it would lead to changes that would benefit only part of the Member States while preventing others from running programmes efficiently and tailored to the country. Several Member States, such as Slovakia and Hungary, would receive less EU funding in the future as a result of the decision, and this is unacceptable to me. For these reasons, I abstained from voting on the proposal.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the unification of the two programmes for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools and the creation of a common legal framework is welcome, given the situation in the fruit and dairy sectors, which are heavily affected by the Russian embargo.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Healthy eating is a key issue for the youngest populations in Europe, as the risk of obesity continues to rise, especially for children. These programs to help distribute fruits and vegetables and milk in schools encourage the consumption of healthy products and educate the little ones so that these eating habits continue outside of school. The new text also simplifies and unify administrative procedures for more effective implementation of programmes. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted to open the mandate for inter-institutional negotiations on the scheme to support the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools. Tarabella's report reinforces programmes to support the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools. Healthy eating is indeed an important issue for European citizens, a diet that plays a major role in combating diseases such as obesity. The European Union is justified in taking action on this issue. The emphasis on local and seasonal products, as well as regional eating habits, is also a step in the right direction. The report also proposes to simplify and unify administrative procedures, with a view to more effective implementation of programmes, while preserving separate programmes, which ensure that the specificities of fruits and vegetables are taken into account, on the one hand, and milk and dairy products on the other.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I believe that school milk and fruit schemes operate in different forms in the 28 Member States of the European Union and have different successes. The latter depends only slightly on the nature of EU legislation, as well as on the conditions under which educational institutions in a Member State operate and the funding of education in the Member States, as well as on eating habits. I see that the objective of pooling programmes and requiring uniform implementing rules in the Original Proposal of the European Commission cannot be implemented. We cannot put the same coat on all EU Member States. It is therefore necessary to consider the amendments to the current programmes. I cannot accept the proposal on the table because it would lead to changes that would benefit only part of the Member States, while preventing others from running programmes efficiently and tailored to the country. As a result, very successful Hungarian programmes would receive less EU funding in the future than in the current situation, which I cannot ignore. For these reasons, I voted against the adoption of the proposal.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. The N-VA supported the report on the school scheme for milk and fruit. In our country, about 1 in 5 young people are overweight, especially younger children (5-9 years old). School projects that promote healthy food can make a valuable contribution. Flemish schools actively participate in this: thanks to Flemish-European funding, about 1250 schools have participated annually in the well-known Tutti Frutti for the past ten years. In the debate over whether this scheme is a government task, positive arguments for the N-VA clearly prevail: the sharp rise in obesity makes encouraging a healthy lifestyle in children necessary. Moreover, the measure is aimed at a very specific target group and the scheme has a positive economic impact because most of the products come from local producers. The N-VA welcomes the objective of making the existing system more efficient and effective and reducing red tape for schools. Nevertheless, the proposal contains a number of points that need to be further tinkered with during the negotiations with the Council. For example, the setting of education measures linked to the EU N-VA scheme is clearly not European competence.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's proposal for a decision on the opening and mandate of inter-institutional negotiations on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No. 1306/2013 with regard to the programme of aid for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools. As a member of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I believe that major attention needs to be paid to food changes affecting children. Schools need to help combat bad habits to promote healthy eating reflexes. The aim is to reduce the number of children affected by malnutrition-related diseases, particularly childhood obesity. Moreover, the measures in this proposal will only help the food producers concerned, who have been hard hit by European austerity policies.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this decision because it is a step forward in public health and good nutrition. However, I regret that it does not make it imperative to supply from local suppliers (particularly bananas from the outermost regions) and that it does not favour short distribution channels.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The declining trends in the consumption of fresh fruits and vegetables and milk have not been reversed, so the relevance of the two school schemes under way remains. Both schemes could be improved, mainly in the areas of promoting the use of local and traditional products, as well as on flexibility in member states' use of funds. In addition, the system for assessing and monitoring the milk regime in schools is weak, and the school fruit distribution system lacks improvement. This is important to measure the effectiveness of these regimens in the medium or long term. Unfortunately, the many amendments we have proposed in this regard have been sinkers. It is regrettable that the whole report insists on the allocation of funds to advertising spending, noting the EU's involvement in the scheme, as opposed to further strengthening the appropriations of these food support schemes in schools.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Both programmes were designed to promote the consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products, which are important sectors of European agriculture, each representing around 15 % of the value of the European Union's agricultural production. In addition to their economic importance, they also play an important role in the context of public health and are suitable for distribution in schools. The reasons that led to the establishment of these two school programmes are still valid in the current situation of declining consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products. The situation is hampered, among other things, by modern trends in the consumption of highly processed foods, which are often high in added sugar, salt and fat and which support young age groups. However, it is questionable whether the combination of the programmes in question will bring about a real improvement in the quality of the service provided to final consumers.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This report is fundamental, as it examines the need to continue and strengthen efforts to combat childhood obesity and encourage healthy eating habits early in life. This is a very important issue to tackle, since childhood obesity is increasing across the EU and healthier eating habits need to be encouraged early. Schemes for distributing healthy products, and supporting educational measures about their use, must be combined and streamlined to become more effective tools in the work to promote healthier eating among young people. In order to support this programme thoroughly, I reject the idea of introducing cocoa into the list of products. I believe that the use by Member States of between 10% and 20% of the fund for educational measures and activities, including farm visits and the distribution of local, regional and national products, such as honey, olive oil, dried fruits and processed fruit and vegetables, is a very positive proposal that needs to be encouraged.
