name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of opening interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools as I consider these programmes to be essential for introducing healthy eating habits into children. The amendments adopted today provide a good basis for negotiation with the Council by improving some aspects of the Commission's proposal, such as the distribution of olive oil with accompanying educational measures. They also reduce the weight of the historical criterion for the allocation of funds in the case of the milk program, a criterion that does not apply in the case of fruit and vegetables and which our Delegation has opposed from the outing point.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. With the two support programmes for school fruit and school milk, the EU has successfully supported a healthy diet for our pupils in the past. This is important because our dietary behaviour at a young age affects our health in old age. A balanced diet can, among other things, reduce the risk of diabetes. I have therefore advocated an extension of these programmes. However, it was important to me to bring together the two grants that have been running in parallel so far. This significantly reduces the administrative burden on the EU and Member States. School fruit and school milk will now be supported with a further EUR 20 million from the EU budget.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Tarabella report because it is high time we invested more effort in promoting healthy eating and the consumption of local foodstuffs among children. It is deeply worrying that the consumption of fruit, vegetables and milk has been declining across the EU, including in the UK. If we want to protect the health of our children, we need to make sure they are provided with healthy foodstuffs and properly educated about healthy eating habits.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools is very important for the health and education of our children. Unfortunately, the data tell us that consumption of healthy food is falling, that eating disorders are on the increase and that overweight is a problem that affects our adolescents. Families are not always able to educate at the table and the school can and must also teach a healthy diet. This will lead to a greater awareness of the territory and the importance of agriculture.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I supported the opening of negotiations to promote the arrival of milk and fruit and vegetables from European producers in school canteens. This provision will allow children, especially the most disadvantaged, to benefit from more balanced meals by incorporating fruits and vegetables. These products are indeed the first sacrificed in family budgets in times of crisis. It is also a way of supporting the fruit and vegetable sectors undermined by the ultra-liberal policies of the European Commission and by imports. The aid provided will particularly support local supplies, which is a good thing. I will also table a motion for a resolution to fill the gaps in the text. I think it is particularly important to also offer children meals with organically grown products and fish from sustainable fisheries.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 I abstained in the vote. Aid schemes for fruit and vegetable consumption as well as banana and milk in schools have a positive impact on society as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain: producer and consumer. In addition, at the same time, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.  While we believe that it may be beneficial to restructure two schemes to give them greater coherence and effectiveness, we voted abstention because the text presented includes amendments which we believe involve a superfluous expenditure on promoting the programme that would be better invested in other aspects, such as in promoting the integration of food education into school curriculums.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the creation of this scheme. In fact, this is a consolidation of two already existing schemes – the School Milk Scheme and the School Fruit Scheme. It should be noted that the milk and fruit sectors combined represent nearly 30% by value of EU agricultural output. Obviously, however, the goal of this scheme is not a financial but a health one. Modern nutrition trends among children show an increasing switch towards unhealthy processed foods, and this scheme is designed to tackle the associated problems. The priorities should be buying fruit, vegetables and milk from local, environment-friendly farmers, and having regional authorities decide who is the best provider for the schools they administer.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of opening interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools because I believe that these programmes are essential for introducing healthy eating habits into children. The amendments adopted today provide a good basis for negotiation with the Council by improving some aspects of the Commission's proposal, such as the distribution of olive oil with accompanying educational measures. They also reduce the weight of the historical criterion for the allocation of funds in the case of the milk program, a criterion that does not apply in the case of fruit and vegetables and which our Delegation has opposed from the outing point.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. 'I do not think it is appropriate for european logos to be applied to products of the school milk and school fruit programme. This form of propaganda is scandalous symbolic politics on the backs of children. In addition, I believe that the school milk programme can be completely abolished. Milk is not necessarily as healthy as we might think. Recent scientific research from Sweden confirms this. For example, drinking milk increases the risk of bone fractures. Several Parliamentarians spoke about the increase in lactose intolerance cases; this is becoming more common in young people. Advocating 'a decline in milk consumption among adolescents', as this resolution does, is therefore problematic for public health. But also for nature, for the climate and for the animals, which are trapped en masse in ever-expanding mega-stables. Instead of focusing so heavily on dairy in schools, we can better use the budget for school milk for more school fruit and vegetables. By doing this, we limit the adverse impact of intensive livestock farming on the climate and give children a healthier food choice. For all these reasons, I finally voted against this resolution.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Yesterday there was only one vote in the European Parliament on the 'decision to open interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables and bananas and milk in educational establishments and on the granting of the corresponding mandate'. The EU thinks it must now also take care of this issue, because children are said to eat less fruit, vegetables and dairy products. I voted against this proposal because I believe that parents need to worry about their children's diet and are happy to do so. As a child, I was always very happy about my break bread, which my mother gave me. This joy should not be taken away from the children, nor should parents. Secondly, education and health policy does not fall within the competence of the EU anyway. In Germany, this is not the responsibility of the federal government, but of the individual federal states, how can it be one of Brussels? Thirdly, this proposal does not fit the principle of subsidiarity. The EU is committed to this at every opportunity, but in practice it always acts against it!

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: Writing. \u2012 School milk and fruit schemes operate in different forms in the 28 Member States of the European Union and have different successes. The latter depends only slightly on the eu legislation. Just as important are the circumstances in which the educational establishments in a Member State operate and the funding of education in the Member States, as well as the eating habits. I see that the objective of pooling programmes and requiring uniform implementing rules in the Original Proposal of the European Commission cannot be implemented. We cannot put the same coat on all EU Member States. Consequently, it is necessary to consider the amendments to the current programmes. I cannot accept the Commission proposal because it would lead to changes that would benefit only part of the Member States, while preventing others from running programmes efficiently and tailored to the country. As a result, very successful Hungarian programmes would receive less EU funding in the future than in the current situation, which I cannot ignore. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, for the reasons mentioned above, I did not support the adoption of the proposal.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. In the face of the phenomenon of obesity affecting more and more young people, I think it is important to spread an audible and powerful message about healthy eating. Eating habits are the result of the education that children receive from an early age. Instilling good habits is therefore a common-sense initiative if we want to limit the harmful effects of obesity on the health of young people. Therefore, it is imperative to support the implementation of the "fruit and vegetables" and "milk" programmes in schools and to ensure that administrative procedures are made as easy as possible. From experience, I have seen schools discouraged by administrative barriers and inconsistency in the decisions of the responsible authorities when their sole objective was to encourage healthy consumption. The overzealousness of administrations does not always target good deeds. This is regrettable and widens the gap of misunderstanding between citizens and Europe. Let us not be "more royalist than the king" and encourage decisions that serve the interests of citizens.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 I abstained in the vote. Aid schemes for fruit and vegetable consumption as well as banana and milk in schools have a positive impact on society as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain: producer and consumer. In addition, at the same time, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.  While we believe that it may be beneficial to restructure two schemes to give them greater coherence and effectiveness, we voted abstention because the text presented includes amendments which we believe involve a superfluous expenditure on promoting the programme that would be better invested in other aspects, such as in promoting the integration of food education into school curriculums.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament on the opening and mandate for interinstitutional negotiations on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 100/2013. 1308/2013 and Regulation (EU) No 1308/2013. 1306/2013 in relation to the support scheme for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments due to the importance presented by the programme for children and young people across Europe.  I believe that this is an excellent program that, in addition to the inclusion of Croatia, allows educational institutions to be supplied with local and regional foods and products, such as olive oil or honey. In some Member States, the current situation in schools is not satisfactory due to the shortcomings present in children's nutrition. Therefore, it is extremely important that these supports ensure effective and efficient implementation of the program with the aim of achieving a healthy and balanced diet.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution giving a negotiating mandate for the report on the school fruit and vegetable and milk programme. The goal of this program is to maintain the good food balance of young age groups, which I welcome. However, I voted against the provisions of the report to change the criteria for allocating the budget by Member State for the milk component, which could lead to a reduction in the financial envelope allocated to France.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 27. 5. 2015 we voted on the opening and mandate for negotiations on a regulation to fundamentally change the parameters of the project "Fruit and vegetables for schools" and "School milk". I voted against this resolution because I personally consider the current framework and the functioning of the project to be fully sufficient and very successful. What bothered me most about the proposal was the planned narrowing of the financially subsidized assortment of products delivered to schools. The proposal, as it stands, very strictly restricts the products supported to fresh fruit and vegetables and unsteached or otherwise modified milk. We can, of course, argue at both lay and professional level about how and if juices and fruit purees or yoghurts, cheeses and sour milk drinks are derived from these raw materials for the child's body, but the fact remains that these are the most supplied and children's most consumed products of this project. Thanks to these secondary products, the whole project is successful in the Czech Republic. It is very commendable that the EU wants to improve children's health in this way, but, according to the information available, I believe that this change will only lead to its deterioration, as children will stop consuming even the little fruit, milk and vegetables that we have been getting into them in this way, and the bins in front of schools will be abounding with tons of rotting subsidised food, which I would very much hate to see.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, school milk and fruit schemes operate in different forms in the 28 Member States of the European Union and have different successes. The latter depends only slightly on the nature of EU legislation, as well as on the conditions under which educational institutions in a Member State operate and the funding of education in the Member States, as well as on eating habits. I see that the objective of pooling programmes and requiring uniform implementing rules in the Original Proposal of the European Commission cannot be implemented. We cannot put the same coat on all EU Member States. It is therefore necessary to consider the amendments to the current programmes. I cannot accept the proposal on the table because it would lead to changes that would benefit only part of the Member States, while preventing others from running programmes efficiently and tailored to the country. As a result, very successful Hungarian programmes would receive less EU funding in the future than in the current situation, which I cannot ignore. For these reasons, I voted against the adoption of the proposal.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mr Tarabella's report. With today's vote, we are calling for the two programmes to be merged into a common framework, with a view to increasing their efficiency and reducing the administrative burden. Schools will thus be able to access these resources more easily, in order to encourage the new generations to consume healthy food products and adopt good eating habits that they will be able to adopt for their lives.  All this, at the same time as Expo 2015, whose theme is "Feeding the planet, energy for life", emphasizes the role of food traditions, education in proper nutrition to promote new lifestyles, in contrast to new social diseases, such as obesity. In short, "feeding the world" means eating in a healthy and correct way and, all this, can only start from school.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's final position on the regulation on the implementation of European programmes for the consumption of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools. These programs encourage the consumption of healthy products, with a focus on local and seasonal products, while taking into account regional eating habits. Until now, the "fruit and vegetables" and "milk" programmes have been implemented and managed separately. By adopting this new text, the European Parliament has positioned itself in favour of simplifying and unifying administrative procedures with a view to more effective implementation of the programmes.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The resolution proposed by the Commission has a dual objective: to encourage the consumption of fruits and vegetables, milk and bananas in schools to support these sectors and to combat poor eating habits that promote obesity. The French fruit and vegetable sector has been in crisis for some years due to unfair competition in sales prices. The dairy sector is in deep doubt with the end of quotas, which worries professionals. A collapse in prices and the disappearance of farms are to be feared. As far as bananas are concerned, this fruit produced by our overseas regions is particularly subject to competition from Central American countries whose prices are also lower than Caribbean bananas. It is therefore necessary to support any action in the direction of defending these different sectors, especially since this resolution gives priority to local products.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this decision to fund the distribution of fruit, vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions for two reasons. On the one hand, because it is a way to educate children about good food hygiene and to try to divert them from industrial junk food. It is a pity, however, that the latter is about to take revenge because of the future TTIP treaty which will bring mediocre American products to Europe. On the other hand, because this decision mitigates the consequences of the Russian embargo by giving disguised subsidies to farmers. Incidentally, it also helps milk producers, victims of the abolition of milk quotas, who protected them, as well as Caribbean banana producers.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution proposed by the Commission which has a dual objective: to promote the consumption of fruit, vegetables, milk and bananas in schools to support these sectors, as well as to combat poor eating habits that promote obesity.  The French fruit and vegetable sector has been in crisis for several years due to unfair competition in sales prices. The dairy sector is experiencing a period of doubt following the abolition of quotas, which worries professionals, a collapse in prices and the disappearance of farms are to be feared. As far as bananas are concerned, this fruit produced by our overseas regions is subject to competition from Central American countries in particular, whose prices are also lower than Caribbean bananas.  It is therefore necessary to support any action in the direction of defending these different sectors, even if we may regret the role we give to the Commission, which is always trying to impose itself on the Member States.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The decision taken by the EP Committee on Agriculture contains a strong position in favour of the continuation of programmes and highlights the many reasons for their strengthening and continuation. Products eligible by Member States participating in the programmes are extended to yogurts and cheeses. The EP increases the financial endowment for the milk programme to EUR 100 million per school year and maintains eur 150 million per school year of the proposal for fruit and vegetables. For both fruit and milk, the EP calls for a 5% increase in EU aid for outermost regions. Agreeing with these considerations, I voted in favour.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I strongly support the continuation and extension of programmes for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments, which play an important role in promoting healthy eating habits and the consumption of agricultural products in the European Union. I also agree with the need to expand the range of dairy products so that lactose intolerant children can also benefit from the programme. It is important that the creation of programmes and decisions on distributed products in schools are involved; in addition to the Member States, the different regions that are best aware of the needs and opportunities of local educational establishments. I would also pay particular attention to the educational activities that accompany the distribution of agricultural products to schools. Knowledge of healthy eating habits, agriculture, environmental protection is extremely important in shaping the quality of life and health of children and young people. Making a habit of eating vegetables and fruits among young people is the best investment in their health and well-being. Let us remember that children follow the example of their parents, who can also play a very important role in this programme by encouraging children to eat vegetables. In order for children in each Member State to benefit from this programme, it is also important to take responsibility for its financing, which means increasing its budget to include dairy products as well.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against it, it is a waste of taxpayers' money. It's the responsibility of parents to snack on their kids. Support for selected products is warcing the market and the EU is using the programme for propaganda among children.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development with a view to opening interinstitutional negotiations to increase coordination of the two regulations and manage programmes more efficiently and help.  Regulations and programmes were created to promote healthy eating habits of children and to encourage the consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products, which are an essential sector of European agriculture, but operate within different legal and financial frameworks and show some significant differences in form and functioning. In this, the European Year for Development, even at expo 2015 in Milan, one of the main topics is proper nutrition. Nutrition plays a significant role and impact on the health of the individual throughout life, and especially in children, because in addition to meeting basic energy needs and nutrients, a well-balanced and proper diet ensures their proper growth and development. Statistics in Croatia also show that unhealthy eating is an increasing problem. Data from the Croatian Institute of Public Health show that as many as 26.4 percent of school-age children are overweight and 11.2 percent are obese, so this statistic positions us in seventh place in Europe in the number of obese children.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the latest data, more than 22 million children in the EU are overweight and at the same time consumption of fruits and vegetables among adolescents is decreasing. In other words, the problem of obesity is becoming more and more large. This is not a statistic that can be passed by lightly. I am of the opinion that the way our children eat should be a priority, since nutrition has a strong role in the fight against certain diseases. Keyly, the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments should be motivating for Member States and have less administrative burden. With the help of schools, we must act responsibly and nurture good eating habits in the youngest citizens. We must not forget that this is an investment in the health of future generations. The other great benefit of this scheme is that it allows for familiarization with the work in agriculture, so adolescents will understand where the products they consume come from and get acquainted with the supply chain, which in turn is educational. I believe that with this scheme, the EU is taking a priority issue and that is why I support it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I support this initiative. Latvian students eat for cents a day, which can be afforded to spend on them from the LV state budget, and this could be a great support for latvian and eastern European students (estonia has a similar situation, for example). The S&D Group's position was to vote in support of the position of the committee responsible.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the opening of interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions. In addition to fruit milk and other milk products, this 'school fruit programme' will also include lactose-free forms. In addition, according to the report, care will be taken in the future to ensure that the products are sourced from local consumers and that they also contain less chemicals. However, I reject the associated EU self-congratulation.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal to merge the School Milk Scheme with the School Fruit and Vegetable Scheme. The merging of these two schemes is beneficial not only to school children but also to farmers and dairy farmers, who have access to a market for their goods.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. School milk and fruit and vegetable distribution programmes have been set up to encourage children to "eat healthy products and adopt good eating habits in response to the rising rate of childhood obesity". In theory, it is a question of encouraging a "healthy" diet. However, on closer inspection, we see that distributed fruits from traditional agriculture, drizzled with pesticides, increase the risk of cancer and that many dairy products, for example, are now causing previously unknown releases. The Commission's proposal aims to merge these two programmes. Parliament's report proposes to expand the range of products distributed, to increase the quantities of milk and to ensure the educational aspect. In the end, however, behind public health issues, it is mainly a question of proposing channels for the flow of European overproduction (15% of European agricultural production). It would be better to question the production methods of these products rather than to want to distribute them with good conscience. I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This Parliament's proposal aims to maintain financial aid for the distribution of milk and fruit and vegetables to children aged six to ten. The main objectives are social, health and economic. From a social point of view, this proposal aims to combat child malnutrition in all classes. Indeed, it continues to increase. Secondly, in terms of health, it helps to combat the bad eating habits that develop obesity in some children. Finally, at the economic level, this text will help milk and fruit and vegetable producers as well as banana producers in Guadeloupe and Martinique. Although some positions are criticised, overall this proposal improves the Commission's. Therefore, I voted for it.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. – I chose to support Parliament’s amendments to the Commission proposal on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables and milk in educational establishments. It is important that the two programmes currently covered by this scheme continue to function, as the Union should play a role in combating the decline in young people’s consumption of fruit and vegetables and milk products.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I backed the Commission proposals for the EU’s merged fruit and milk scheme in schools, as I think that it will promote healthier eating habits among young people. The foundation of good health for our children is a healthy and balanced diet. Providing fruit, vegetables and milk at school will also educate children about healthy eating habits from a very young age.

name: Giulia MOI
text: in writing. \u2012 We are voting in favour of strengthening the two programmes. The promotion of healthy nutrition through the distribution of fruit and vegetables and dairy products is a double victory, both for students and producers.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 Healthy eating in children and adolescents is of the utmost importance, both for their development and for the development of their dietary habits at a later age. Consumption of vegetables, fruits and dairy products is steadily declining in Europe. 22 million Children in Europe are overweight and adolescents consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended daily amount of fruit and vegetables. That is why I consider it very important that European educational institutions provide pupils with an adequate quantity of vegetables, fruit and dairy products during school meals. The document before the EP was about the opening of interinstitutional negotiations and the mandate to be given to these negotiations, which I was pleased to vote on.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I consider it essential that the Union, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, promote healthy eating in the Schools of the Union and, at the same time, bring regional and local products to schools. I am also in favour of including issues such as healthy eating habits and the fight against food waste. Overweight is a reality, affecting about 22 million children.  Given the characteristics of the Outermost Regions, I am in favour of an additional 5 % increase in Union support, with an additional 5% if these regions import products from other nearby outermost regions.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This text provides for the creation of a common legal framework for all Member States to encourage the consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products in schools, as well as to develop related educational activities, such as farm visits, and the distribution of healthy local specialties. It also aims to unify financial arrangements to simplify management and improve its funding.  Healthy eating must be a public health priority, as should the fight against overweight and childhood obesity, which, according to the WHO, affects a third of children aged 6 to 9 in Europe.  Knowing that it is up to Member States to decide on their public health policies, this programme gives them a great deal of freedom in terms of how to apply and the objective of good nutrition for children is a compelling public interest which takes precedence over any other consideration. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: In writing. I voted in favour of opening and mandating inter-institutional negotiations on the system of aiding the distribution of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools. This programme will fund measures to encourage children to consume fruits and vegetables as well as milk and certain dairy products in schools. However, with the risk of obesity and especially children increasing, educating young Europeans on healthy eating is a key issue. With this negotiating mandate, the aim is to simplify administrative procedures in order to implement European programmes more effectively. However, I objected to the provisions which threaten to reduce the amount allocated to France for the milk programme.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With this proposal we wish to stress the importance of programmes for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools and the reasons why they should be continued and strengthened. Furthermore, following the Commission's decision to re-evaluate the proposal, it is important to show our full support for their continuation. In fact, experience gained with the implementation of the current programmes and the conclusions of the external evaluations have shown the importance of ensuring not only the continuation but also the strengthening of these two programmes. At a time when the incidence of childhood obesity is increasing due to bad eating habits, which tend to favour the consumption of processed food products, rich in sugars, salts, fats and added additives, the European Union cannot fail to contribute to the promotion of healthy eating habits and to the consumption of regional and local products. In addition, in order to ensure the visibility of the programme to its beneficiaries throughout the Union, it will be necessary to provide for a common identity and a mandatory EU logo to be affixed to posters relating to the participation of schools in programmes and information material made available to pupils under the accompanying educational measures.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 School programmes are important to keep, as they are a means of educating people about conscious and healthy eating. Unfortunately, young people are increasingly consuming fresh fruit and vegetables and dairy products, so it is extremely important to bring them into school. I therefore welcome the decision to give the mandate for interinstitutional consultation on this subject.  I believe that it is a key issue for The Member States to have a free hands in adapting the programme to their own agricultural and environmental characteristics, and for locally grown fruits and products to be present in packages given to children. A key issue is the education of healthy eating, i.e. the provision of preservative-free, organic-quality food. At the same time, this would not only directly serve the consumption of local products, but also to make them love and promote them!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the opening of negotiations and the mandate for interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions. This decision paves the way for a programme based on quality food aimed at improving the quality of children's nutrition.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of opening interinstitutional negotiations for this aid programme, because I strongly support that it can bring many benefits both to the health of our children and to agriculture in Romania. The two programmes, separated so far, for the supply of fruit and vegetables, on the one hand, and milk, on the other, were developed at different times, on different bases, with different budgets, but with identical objectives: educating children from a food point of view by familiarising them with healthy and fresh products.  The analyses found that the initial objectives are still valid, but the programmes suffer due to a lack of coordination. In this respect, I support the integration of the two from a legislative and economic point of view because this will mean reducing red tape and unnecessary procedures, thus saving financial resources that can be used in these programmes themselves. The integration of the two is very important for the healthy education of children in Romania and throughout the EU, for their future, not least for farmers and producers in the Member States who support and promote healthy products, including those in Romania.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to maintain and make school milk and fruit programmes more efficient. In my view, these programmes can be effective in improving equal opportunities in schools, reducing child hunger and poor nutrition, which are unfortunately present in many countries.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the draft on the school food program. The criteria for budget allocation on this issue are important for Estonia, in particular the use of the so-called historical criterion for the milk budget, which the European Commission has proposed in its proposal. According to the Commission's proposal, the EU milk budget (EUR 80 million) will be distributed among Member States in the light of the number of children aged 6-10 (similar to that currently in force in the fruit and vegetables scheme) and the so-called historical budget criterion should be added. The Commission's objective is not to reduce the budget of Member States that have actively used EU aid under the school milk scheme. A total of EUR 1.57 million was paid for the dairy products consumed in the school milk aid scheme in 2014, of which the SHARE of the EU grant was EUR 662 200 and the additional support from the Estonian state budget was EUR 909 300.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The regulation defiantly states that it aims to cultivate "healthy eating habits" in children, at a time when the wildly unpopular EU and government policy is driving thousands of children from popular families to go to school and starve to death. With 20 pieces of fruit and EUR 4-5 per year for each child for milk distribution, the EU actually subsidises the major dairy and packaging, processing, import, marketing and distribution companies and promotes the products of transnational enterprises, which are the only beneficiaries of such falsified programmes. In fact, the European Parliament's report puts businesses in schools, not to promote healthy eating, but to expand their customers and advertise their products, even with a subsidy! Of course, all this must also be accompanied by an advertising campaign to present the black and white, that the EU is very interested in children and not in the profits of multinationals. It is an urgent need to provide free lunch to all school pupils, as proposed by the KKE in an amendment to the Greek Parliament, rejected by the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that this compromise underlines the importance of school programmes and why they should be continued and strengthened, it is now important for Parliament to adopt a strong position in favour of continuing these proposals, also taking into account the reduction of the administrative burden which constitutes a deterrent to the participation of schools, especially those wishing to participate in both programmes and which are forced to fill in two different types of modules. or undergo numerous sets of checks. For these reasons, I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. Since taking office as a Member of the European Parliament, I have warned almost every session of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development that the existing historical criteria for granting EU subsidies for milk rations in schools are discriminatory to the Republic of Croatia and children in Croatian schools, and I asked for their change.  In addition to receiving the support of the European Commission and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, by passing this report, the European Parliament accepted a proposal to allow Croatia, as a full member of the EU, to participate in this programme. I am satisfied, because it turned out that if we try and work hard, we can succeed, and this is an important program for Croatia and for children in Croatian schools.  By accepting the report that stated the exemption for Croatia from the so-called historical criteria, the European Parliament sent a clear message to the Council that Croatia must not be discriminated against, and I hope that children in Croatian schools will receive healthy and free meals of fruit, vegetables and milk as early as next school year, from local fields from local producers for whom schools will be a new market.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support the decision to start and mandate interinstitutional negotiations on support schemes for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments. It is our responsibility to provide children with a quality childhood, which includes creating healthy feeding habits, and free and healthy meals for schoolchildren are a minimum of conditions.  By uniusing the milk and fruit distribution programme in schools, we provide an answer to worrying data on the falling consumption of fruit and vegetables and dairy products. The situation is all the worse as modern trends show an increase in consumption directed towards products that often contain large amounts of added sugar, salt and fat. In accordance with these legal frameworks are necessary to create a globally harmonised approach towards healthy eating.  The programmes are primarily set up to promote the consumption of fruit and vegetables and dairy products, but I must stress that this is also about supporting important sectors of European agriculture. I also consider it positive that this directive also provides Croatian schoolchildren with the means to provide a free and healthy meal at school.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that it is beneficial for children in schools to receive healthy food as a priority. For this reason, I also support events such as the "School Milk" project in the Czech Republic. It is precisely because of my conviction that I was unable to vote today in favour of the resolution on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments as presented. After the adoption of the amendment, which meant that the aid would not be obtained from flavored milk, the already mentioned Czech project "Milk for Schools" would be significantly damaged. Its results show that children within it drink up to eight times more tasted milk than unsothered milk. In flavored milk, the amount of sugar is already clearly regulated, but if we do not support this type of milk, it may mean that children will be left with a choice of unflavoured milk, which they do not like so much, and far more unhealthy, but "good" drinks. Then it is obvious that they will reach for a second time, and the whole system of promoting milk drinking in schools will miss the effect.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Writing. The principle of subsidiarity is part of the EU's founding spirit. The fact that even fruit and milk in schools are now to be the subject of A European regulation is a mockery of this.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Childhood overweight and obesity pose serious threats to young people in Europe. In the face of increased risks, it is important to encourage a healthy and balanced diet. At this session, we reaffirmed the importance and need to take action at EU level by adopting Parliament's final position on the regulation on the implementation of European programmes for the consumption of fruit and vegetables and milk in schools. I have spoken in favour of this text and I underline the crucial role of these programmes on the food education of young and old in Europe. However, I would like to point out that one of the provisions of the text carries a real risk of reducing the envelope allocated to France in order to develop the milk programme. Together with my colleagues in the French delegation, we voted against this provision.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: in writing. \u2012 This vote demonstrates everyone's desire to continue strengthening programmes in terms of proper nutrition in schools. The directive voted on today helps to increase consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables, including bananas, and dairy products among children, as well as to reduce the number of cases of verified childhood obesity in the Member States.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Tonight, the European Parliament backed by a very large majority (458 votes in support, 97 against) the report on the European programme to help distribute fruit and vegetables and milk in schools.  In Europe, fruit and vegetable consumption continues to fall. European teenagers consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended daily intake of fruits and vegetables. In Belgium, for example, spending on fruit and vegetables fell by 5.8% in 2014. Annual per capita consumption has increased from 95.8 kilograms to 82.7 kilograms in ten years.  For the World Health Organization, however, adequate consumption of fruits and vegetables would prevent more than 1.7 million deaths each year, reduce the risk of obesity and reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. In the European Union, 20 million children are overweight. It is therefore from an early age that you must instill good food reflexes and promote a healthy diet. That is why I have opposed the distribution of chocolate milk, which is decidedly too sweet, as part of this programme which will affect thirty million European schoolchildren.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Every year, some thirty million European schoolchildren benefit from the two EU-funded programmes, the School Milk Consumption Programme (launched in 1977) and the School Fruit Consumption Programme (dating back to 2009). These programs aim to encourage children to eat healthy products and adopt good eating habits, in response to the rising rate of childhood obesity. In January 2014, the Commission published a legislative proposal to merge these two programmes into a common legal and financial framework in order to increase their effectiveness and reduce the administrative burden on national and local actors. In December 2014, the new European Commission presented its work programme for 2015 which stated that the legislative proposal on the merger of the "fruit" and "milk" programmes was suspended until an evaluation was carried out under the CAP simplification exercise. Notwithstanding the Commission's recommendation, in voting on this report, we have decided to continue work to amend the legislative proposal. The adoption of this mandate is therefore a strong signal that Parliament wants the work to continue.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. We all know the importance of adopting healthy eating behaviours, especially among young people. To this extent, this regulatory change establishes a more uniform and efficient legal and financial framework, capable of adequately responding to the global problems of rampant obesity and the continuous reduction of fruit, vegetable and milk consumption among the school community.  To that extent, I am in favour of the amendments contained in this proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council, which is grouped together in a single legal and financial framework two schemes which were currently separate with regard to the distribution of fruit and milk in schools. The proposal aims and well two main objectives: on the one hand to include essential products such as fresh fruit and vegetables in the diet, with the aim of linking with agriculture, public health and the environment, and, on the other hand, to allocate separate financial envelopes to Member States in the fruit, vegetable and milk sector, taking into account the specificities of the type of products and their distribution chains.  Due to the dimension of educational training and economic rationality inherent in this proposal, whose main objective is the promotion of a healthier diet, I voted in favour.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Never as in this period, especially in Italy thanks to Expo 2015, the topic of nutrition is central to public debate. Feeding the planet is also this: allowing our children to have the healthiest and most varied range of products possible at school, which is then the environment in which children spend most of their time. Proper food education passes first of all through the consumption of healthy products, such as fruits, vegetables and dairy products. I believe that making the most of the consumption of these products from an early age can be of great use to stem and prevent malnutrition problems, such as obesity and anorexia, from which more and more children are suffering. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal to open interinstitutional negotiations on the distribution of these products in schools.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – I abstained in the vote. Aid schemes for fruit and vegetable consumption as well as banana and milk in schools have a positive impact on society as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain: producer and consumer. In addition, at the same time, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.  While we believe that it may be beneficial to restructure two schemes to give them greater coherence and effectiveness, we voted abstention because the text presented includes amendments which we believe involve a superfluous expenditure on promoting the programme that would be better invested in other aspects, such as in promoting the integration of food education into school curriculums.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of granting the EP's mandate to negotiate with the Council on the decision on an aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments.  Schools include a healthy diet, which both programmes support and help to create healthy eating habits in children, especially when it comes to fresh fruits and vegetables. Programmes should also, where possible, make use of available local and regional production.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 I call for the negotiation with the other European institutions on this subject to take place in the spirit of the position voted today. The proposals thus adopted and to be included in the free distribution scheme of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools substantially improve their content, their potential contribution to children's health and the possibilities for the disposal of their agricultural products. In particular, I call for the provisions encouraging access to the scheme in certain regions of Europe which, due to the constraints related to its geographical specificity, have difficulty in taking full advantage of the opportunities of this scheme.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ S&D Members of the European Parliament voted in support of the decision on the opening of, and mandate for, interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments. There is an increasing incidence of child obesity as a result of consumption habits geared to highly processed foods. Union aid to finance the supply to children in educational establishments of selected agricultural products should do more to promote healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Healthy nutrition of children and young people must be a priority of each Member State. Fruits, vegetables, milk and dairy products must be part of the school diet. The Healthy Diet Programme must also be part of the fight against obesity in children and young people. I supported the amendments and the resolution by which we gave a mandate to negotiate with the ministers of the individual Member States. The fruit, vegetables, milk and dairy support programme must also include education and greater education for parents and children. Although there have been differing views in the debate on whether or not bananas, yes or no, chocolate milk, which has a higher dose of sugar, is suitable for children or not, I believe that the final legislative form of the regulation will benefit children and young people and their healthy eating habits. According to the supported resolution, nutritionists should also comment on the aid scheme for the provision of fruit, vegetables, milk and milk products in educational establishments.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of the Commission’s initiative. Each year, in a context of increasing rates of child obesity, the School Milk Scheme and the School Fruit and Vegetables Scheme provide nearly 30 million school children across the EU with much needed healthy food products and help children to develop good eating habits. Similarly, at a time of falling fruit and vegetable prices, farmers and rural communities are also guaranteed a secure market for their products. I believe that the merging of the two schemes within a common legal and financial framework would further increase the efficiency and effectiveness of the system and reduce the administrative burden for local administrations in the implementation of the national programmes.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In 2005-2010 the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables in Europe fell. The decline in fruit consumption is 9.4 per cent and vegetables 10.3 per cent. It is similar to the situation for the total consumption of dairy products in the EU. This decreased by 5 per cent between 2006 and 2011. The European Association for the Study of Obesity estimates that between 12,000,000 and 16,000,000 children are overweight in Europe. The number of obese children is between 3 and 4.5 million. Getting overweight has a negative impact on health and well-being at a young age. For this reason, it is essential to introduce healthy eating habits through educational institutions at a young age. Since 1977, the European Union has been implementing a scheme for the distribution of fresh milk in schools. Schemes for the distribution of fruit and vegetables in school institutions are similar. In the 2010/2011 school year, the school fruit scheme reached more than 8 million children from 54,000 schools. In quantity, 44,000 tonnes of fruit and vegetables were distributed. As I consider it important that the existing system for the distribution of healthy diets should continue to be applied and since it is also essential to inform children about the importance of healthy eating, I voted in favour of the report and for the opening of negotiations with the European Council.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Eating habits from youth do not fundamentally change even at an older age and are manifested in the health of citizens. Since prevention is always more effective than dealing with consequences, balanced diets and lifestyles of regular movement therefore deserve greater attention in schools.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution because I consider it one of the most important tasks to promote health, especially in childhood and adolescence. If we now combine the two programmes on school milk and school fruit, we will be laying the foundations for an educational programme for good eating habits. Because what we learn as children, what good nutrition means, remains in our lives. I think it is particularly good that the programme is now also to be linked to other training measures, such as visits to farms. In my own state of Rhineland-Palatinate, the state government has been involved in the school fruit programme for many years and has thus achieved good results. I rate it particularly well that we voted together against Amendment No 49, which would also have allowed the sale of cocoa drinks, strawberry milk and other sugared milk products. That is precisely what we do not want. We want full-fledged and healthy products for children and adolescents and not sweet and coloured milk.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Taking into account the proposal of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, and taking into account the fact that the trend of declining consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables, including bananas and drinking milk, has been established, I support this proposal for a decision on the opening of interinstitutional negotiations and a mandate on the support scheme for the delivery of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments.  I believe that streamlining food distribution in educational establishments is an important task to be addressed in order to stimulate discussions that would result in improved conditions in schools, but also lead to improved children's health.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s mandate for negotiations with the Council, as the proposed programme is a good initiative that has the potential to foster healthy habits at an early stage in life.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision on the opening and mandate of interinstitutional negotiations on an aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions. In the present day, we are facing an increasing number of overweight children due to poor eating habits that contain heavily processed foods, with a large amount of added sugar, salt, fat and additives. According to the OECD, weight gain in humans has become a global problem, with research showing that one in five children aged between five and 17 living in one of the 34 OECD countries is overweight. Slovenia ranks fourth in this ranking. I agree with the report, which says that the distribution of fresh vegetables and fruits should be encouraged in schools, rather than processed products. This should be included in the objectives of school programmes. We must prioritise local and biological products and make children aware of the diversity of agricultural production.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 It is imperative to have greater coordination and synergy between the milk distribution system and the system for promoting fruit consumption in schools, in order to ensure a coherent approach to nutrition, and greater efficiency. Nevertheless, we have reservations about how the systems are implemented. We believe that systems can and must be improved, particularly as regards the promotion of local and traditional products, but also flexibility and efficiency in the use of resources, as it is found that more funds are spent on advertising than on the products themselves. For the above reasons we have decided to abstain.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of the consumption of dairy and fruit and vegetable products in our educational institutions is in agreement. In order to achieve this objective, the bureaucracy encountered during the promotion of the above products should be reduced to a minimum.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal as I believe that encouraging children to eat healthily is essential. The current proposal for a decision could ensure healthy food for our children, broadening the list of products available so far (e.g. healthy, sugar-free or flavouring-free dairy products). In addition, the new approach includes educational elements to help our children learn about the benefits of healthy eating from an early age. In my opinion, this programme shows that the EU is much more effective in some cases than many Member States individually. The proposal to merge existing school milk and fruit schemes, increase funding for the fund and improve the system is heading in the right direction, but I do not think that we should stop here. The implementation of the programme in the Member States requires a broad public consultation, thereby ensuring the use of high-quality local products in the programme. We must take into account that the EU has different regions not only geographically but also in its traditions, which is why the choice and distribution must be carried out more and more at local level. Let the local producers benefit from the programme. Taking into account the central logic of the design of the programme, I believe that we should not be afraid of the idea of common VAT-free foods either, as at present the VAT on foodstuffs in the European Union ranges from 0% to 27%.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution as a whole because I consider it of priority to support programmes for schools that promote the consumption of fresh fruit and vegetables in an educational way by contributing to the promotion of healthy eating habits and the consumption of local products. I voted in favour of the amendment tabled by the Greens calling for the exclusion from distribution in schools of processed fruit and vegetables, which contain added sugars, salt and fats, added sweeteners and/or artificial flavour enhancers (artificial food additives identified by codes E620 to E650). The latter, in fact, have harmful effects on the health of citizens and it would be a nonsense to include them in programmes that would have precisely the aim of promoting a healthy and natural diet. That is why I voted against the amendment tabled by the PPE, which wanted to include the possibility of distributing fermented milk products flavoured with cocoa, that is, non-natural and non-local products. Finally, I voted in favour of the amendment tabled by the S&D calling on the Member States to involve stakeholders on the ground when the national strategy is to be outlined.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 Healthy food for children in Europe must rise to the top of the priorities of the Commission, but also of the Member States. Childhood obesity is reaching alarming levels and calls into question the healthy development that we all want for European children. Nutritional behaviours are acquired from the earliest ages. Therefore, the continuation of the programme for the supply of fruit and milk to educational institutions is not only necessary, but also compulsory. At the same time, educational programmes for which Member States can use between 10% and 20% of financial allocations can be transformed into activities for children that create healthy behaviours for the rest of their lives in terms of nutrition. I voted for this proposal for a decision because I consider it important for a unified and healthy development of European youth. In addition to the positive characteristics of balanced nutrition, we must also stress the economic importance that the programme confers on the development of agricultural production at national and regional level. The European Union's contributions from this programme are injected into the national economy and give new opportunities for development and consolidation of local producers in the market.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted on the "Tarabella Report", a new legislation that should allow a simple and free distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools in all European countries throughout the year. Based on the alarming observation that only 12% of Belgians and 36% of Europeans eat five fruits and vegetables a day, the objective was multiple: healthy food from an early age, education around food, fight against obesity but also promotion and enhancement of the short circuit and local and regional products. Today's vote is great news for the health of the thirty million schoolchildren who will benefit from it.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision on the opening of, and mandate for, interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments. I support the merging of the two existing schemes under the same legislative framework in order to help reduce the administrative burden. The current schemes have operated within different legal and financial frameworks, and have some important differences in their design and functioning. This change will make them more efficient.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. I am delighted by the broad success achieved by my Socialist colleague Marc Tarabella in the distribution of fruit, vegetables and dairy products in schools. This report merges two old programs and simplifies administrative procedures for schools. Above all, it is much more ambitious. In particular, it aims to encourage the consumption of fruit, vegetables and dairy products among young Europeans, to combat obesity and promote a healthy and balanced diet. With financial resources to increase from 197 million euros to 250 million euros, we will not only be able to ensure the distribution of fruits and vegetables and milk in schools, but also finance educational measures to transmit a good lifestyle, raise awareness of all aspects of nutrition and even be able to visit farms to understand where we eat. Finally, with 385 million litres of milk and 65,000 tonnes of fruit and vegetables distributed, distribution programmes give pride of place to the short circuit and to local and regional production.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. – I abstained in the vote. Aid schemes for fruit and vegetable consumption as well as banana and milk in schools have a positive impact on society as they promote healthy eating at an early age and seek to establish direct links between the two ends of the food chain: producer and consumer. In addition, at the same time, two productive sectors – dairy and fruit and vegetable – are promoted, representing approximately 30% of the Union's agricultural production.  While we believe that it may be beneficial to restructure two schemes to give them greater coherence and effectiveness, we voted abstention because the text presented includes amendments which we believe involve a superfluous expenditure on promoting the programme that would be better invested in other aspects, such as in promoting the integration of food education into school curriculums.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This European programme aims to continue to fund the distribution of milk, vegetables and fruit (including bananas) to children aged six to ten. The programme has three major implications: - social impact: by encouraging access to these foodstuffs by children of all population groups, this programme helps to combat child malnutrition, which continues to increase as a result of the crisis; - health impact: this programme helps to combat obesity and, more broadly, against the eating habits responsible for an ever-increasing number of serious diseases in children; - economic impact: by supporting milk, vegetable, fruit and banana producers from Guadeloupe and Martinique, the programme provides additional opportunities for sectors in crisis. Although some of the provisions adopted are questionable, the European Parliament's proposal is notoriously improving that of the European Commission for the upcoming negotiations and therefore deserves to be accepted. I'm voting for.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report as it is necessary to promote healthy eating habits from an early age, in this case from schools. Consumption of fruits and vegetables has fallen by about 10% in Europe in the period 2005-2010. Between 12 and 16 million children are overweight and between 3 and 4.5 million are obese. I also voted against an amendment by the PPE Group which sought to introduce poor quality products into the programme.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in educational establishments across the European Union. It is our responsibility as the European Parliament to promote an active lifestyle and healthy eating habits, starting at an early age. The number of overweight children in the EU has significantly increased, reaching 20 million, and a change of direction, towards improving health through the daily consumption of fruit and vegetables, is urgently needed. My hope is that, by supporting this aid scheme, we will see young Europeans, who are the future of our continent, embracing a healthier way of living and eating.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. While we are finally talking about a report which does not contain all the requests made in the form of amendments concerning the aid programme for the distribution of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk in schools, we must take into account that a consensus general commitment has been reached, and I therefore consider it appropriate to vote positively on that document.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of opening interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit and milk in schools because I believe that these programmes are essential for introducing healthy eating habits into children. The amendments adopted today provide a good basis for negotiation with the Council by improving some aspects of the Commission's proposal, such as the distribution of olive oil with accompanying educational measures. They also reduce the weight of the historical criterion for the allocation of funds in the case of the milk program, a criterion that does not apply in the case of fruit and vegetables and which our Delegation has opposed from the outing point.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. \u2012 The merging of both programmes (milk at school and fruit and vegetables at school) is a good thing. It ensures that with less administration more can be done, and that benefits our children. I voted in favour of increasing the programme's budget by EUR 20 million because the European Union simply has more countries than in the 1970s and 1990s, when the schemes were started. Every child in the EU earns milk, fruit and vegetables at school. This will help in fighting obesity. In addition, it also benefits our farmers, who are still suffering from the Russian boycott of fruit, vegetables and milk products from Europe.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite separate efforts to increase consumption, health and agricultural promotion, both at national and EU level, the trends of decline in consumption of these products have not been reversed, especially for fresh fruits and vegetables and drinking milk, thus continuing to be relevant the reasoning that led to the creation of the two school schemes.  Both schemes could be improved, mainly in the areas of promoting local and traditional products and on flexibility in the use of funds. In addition, the system for assessing and monitoring the milk regime in schools is weak and the school fruit distribution system lacks improvement and is important in measuring the effectiveness of these schemes in the medium or long term. Unfortunately, the many amendments we have proposed in this regard have been sinkers. It is regrettable that, throughout the report, the allocation of funds to be spent on advertising is being insisted on the EU's involvement in the scheme, as opposed to further strengthening the appropriations of these food support schemes in schools.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the opening of interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational institutions. In addition to fruit milk and other milk products, this 'school fruit programme' will also include lactose-free forms. In addition, according to the report, care will be taken in the future to ensure that the products are sourced from local consumers and that they also contain less chemicals. However, I reject the associated EU self-congratulation.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. "Europe – big and small on esb" was the leitmotif for a reform-oriented EU. However, this resolution proves the opposite. Brussels even regulates school meals. The institutional management of values and standards with regard to school meals is particularly noteworthy, because the EU has several responsibilities. The EU is violating parental rights. The EU dictates what schoolchildren should eat and drink. The EU distorts the market for agricultural products. The EU intervenes in Germany's public regulations, because school is a national matter. No one can prove that the administrative burden in everyday life is actually reduced. That is why I am voting against this resolution.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal to amend the aid for the supply of fruit and vegetables, bananas and milk to educational establishments is an improvement on the current programmes, but for fundamental reasons I did not support the proposal. These projects have a weak impact on both the milk market and children's nutritional habits, and there is no reason why the EU would finance such programmes with taxpayers' money.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Recent studies show that the percentage of obese children is dangerously increasing, which is certainly due to the spread of unbalanced diets, rich in junk food. That is why I welcomed the decision to open interinstitutional negotiations on the aid scheme for the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools, which will only improve the trend observed. It is important that nutritious, quality and above all healthy products are consumed from an early age; children fed today correctly will be healthy adults. Another point in the report that I particularly welcome is the promotion of local production which, by shortening transport and the distribution chain, reduces the ecological footprint and promotes the environment. Certainly a good report that shows how much Europe cares about the health of future generations.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 The trends of decline in consumption of these products have not been reversed, especially for fresh fruits and vegetables and drinking milk, thus continuing to relevant the reasoning that led to the creation of the two school schemes. Both schemes could be improved, mainly in the areas of promoting local and traditional products and in the flexibility of the use of funds. The system of evaluation and monitoring of milk regime in schools is weak and the fruit distribution system in schools lacks improvement. It is regrettable that, throughout the report, the allocation of funds to be spent on advertising is being insisted, as opposed to further strengthening the appropriations of these food support schemes in schools.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted with conviction in favour of the programme for the distribution of fresh fruit and vegetables in schools because I believe that it represents a good opportunity to improve the eating habits of the European population. The figures for the increase in childhood obesity are alarming: we must teach young people to consume healthy, quality and nutritious products. School is the best environment to spread this change. However, we must ensure that this change is permanent in the long term: healthy eating is an investment for everyone's health, including from an economic point of view. We cannot therefore overlook the educational aspect of the programme, by adequate support for all those measures that explain to children the importance of a proper diet. I am particularly pleased at the inclusion in the list of products to be distributed of processed products, but not processed products, as it confirms the desire to remove young people from added sugars, preservatives, sweeteners and the like. I also welcome the strong call for the promotion of local production: healthy eating must be good for the individual but also for the environment. Consuming local products reduces the ecological impact by shortening transport and the distribution chain.
